ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: A significant proportion of Veterans with substance use disorders (SUDs) have co-occurring psychiatric disorders, the combination of which frequently leads to high inpatient service utilization. Homelessness and higher risk for suicide is common among this population. The combination of SUD with co-morbid MH diagnoses warrants innovative treatment approaches that: a) identify and treat patients during their most vulnerable periods; b) leverage technology; c) partner with current VA programs (e.g. Home Telehealth) and operational priorities (i.e., VHA Handbook 1160.06), toward the goal of reducing inpatient admissions, enhancing treatment engagement and reducing SUD. This study investigates the effectiveness of Combined Recovery Program (CRP) for Veterans with SUDs in the inpatient setting and Home Telehealth in the aftercare setting. Outcomes are assessed at 1 and 3-month follow-up using a multi-modal approach. The ultimate goal is to increase outpatient utilization, reduce substance use, and reduce inpatient/ED visits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The project presents a new approach to studying mammalian brain development. The proposal is to apply modern molecular tools and new behavioural assays in a mouse-sized marsupial that is born at stage 18 (equivalent to human seven-week gestation) and develops further in their mother's pouch. Longitudinal studies in this model will provide unprecedented access to study the functional and behavioural outcomes of fetal disruptions to circuitry and could be applied to test therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescent relationship abuse (ARA) affects millions of adolescents annually and is defined as intimate partner violence, cyber abuse, or reproductive coercion. Adolescents experiencing ARA often access the emergency department (ED) for care. The objective of this mixed methods study of adolescents presenting to a pediatric ED is to adapt, using a stakeholder-engaged iterative intervention mapping process, an evidence-based ED ARA intervention called ?Real Talk? (that focuses on abuse perpetration reduction using motivational interviewing and was shown to reduce dating abuse perpetration) to focus on ARA prevention (healthy relationship promotion) and ARA victim/survivor services; through a small pilot randomized controlled trial of adolescents we will measure feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary effectiveness (increased ARA knowledge, increased relationship self-efficacy, and decreased self-reported ARA victimization) of the adapted Real Talk brief ARA intervention.
PROJECT_TITLE: Addressing Adolescent Relationship Abuse in a Pediatric Emergency Department

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because our ability to diagnose and treat neurodevelopmental disorders and brain tumors is critically dependent on fundamental understanding of cellular and molecular mechanisms that regulate neural stem cell self-renewal and differentiation in vivo. Research described in this proposal will uncover new and potentially evolutionarily conserved mechanisms governing these processes. If successful, it will have a broad impact on the understanding of human brain development and associated brain disorders.

PHR: Project Narrative Using an ultrasensitive RT-QuIC/PMCA assays, our recent study has indicated that skin samples of patients with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease or Parkinson's disease, neurodegenerative diseases associated with the deposition of misfolded protein aggregates (PrPSc) or ?-Synuclein, contains detectable PrPSc or ?-Synuclein. The aim of the current proposal is to extend our preliminary finding to test a new hypothesis that skin tissues of Alzheimer's disease (AD), the most common neurodegenerative disease, contain the misfolded tau that can be a biomarker for diagnosing, characterizing and predicting outcome of AD.

PHR: Project Narrative  Glaucoma is the leading cause of irreversible blindness throughout the world, and there are currently no options for restoration of vision in persons with blindness caused by this disease. Here we propose a series of novel strategies to advance the audacious goal of replacing retinal ganglion cells (RGCs), the output nerve cells of the eye, which form the optic nerve and are damaged in glaucoma. We will systematically test a series of manipulations to enhance the survival and integration of human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived RGCs in the glaucomatous retina.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute ischemic stroke affects up to 800,000 people per year in the United States and is the fourth leading cause of death. Mechanical thrombectomy has become standard of care for acute ischemic stroke secondary to large vessel occlusion and up to 150,000 of these procedures will be performed annually by 2025. The etiology of the stroke is unclear in 30-40% of LVO cases. Understanding etiology is important for secondary stroke prevention strategies. The goal of this project is to predict stroke etiology based off histologic characteristics of retrieved clots using AI/ML techniques. The first step is to render our data AI ready which is the main focus of this administrative supplement.

PHR: Project Narrative Various adverse and protective environments may affect child development. The Healthy Brain and Child Development National Consortium (HBCD-NC) will follow 7,500 mothers and their children from 24 locations across the U.S. from before birth to 10 years of age to better understand which harmful and protective environments exert the greatest impact on child development. This study will help to improve the health and development of children across the nation.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While rodents and primates have been extensively used as model systems for studying visual processing, a major dichotomy remains that their visual systems are optimized to perform different tasks, such as detecting movement versus detecting fine special pattern. Tree shrew lies phylogenetically between rodents and primates, and has a sophisticated chromatic visual system that is similar to primates; thus lending itself as an ideal model system to resolve this dichotomy and identify cell types and genes involved in retinal pathologies. The proposed studies will establish tree shrew as a model system for studying how visual signals are processed in distinct retinal circuits and routed to higher brain areas, producing distinct visual specializations in different species.

ORG_NAME: BUCK INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given that aging is the biggest risk factor for the onset of Alzheimer?s disease (AD) and related dementias, there is an urgent need to identify genes that explain the link between aging and AD. We have identified that oxidative resistance 1 (OXR1) and downstream retromer function are necessary for the protective effects of dietary restriction on slowing aging and neurodegeneration in the fly models, and alterations in retromer pathway are associated with increased AD risk in humans. The proposed research is relevant to public health as we will determine the conserved mechanisms of action of OXR1 in enhancing retromer function and neuroprotection across species and determine its relevance as a potential therapeutic target for AD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Up to 20% of patients with diabetes mellitus have gastrointestinal symptoms. These symptoms are often distressing and may impair glycemic control. Our studies are designed to improve our understanding of why these symptoms occur in these patients and thereby identify new treatment(s) in the future.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic musculoskeletal conditions (chronic low back pain, knee osteoarthritis, hip osteoarthritis) are the most common causes of long-term disability resulting in a loss of quality-of life for affected individuals and high costs for society. Regular physical activity can reduce disability and improve quality-of-life but can be challenging in the presence of pain and impaired function. This proposal addresses an urgent need for interventions that support physical activity in this population by leveraging the physical therapy intervention to address symptoms of chronic musculoskeletal conditions and support long-term physical activity engagement.
PROJECT_TITLE: Leveraging Physical Therapy to Improve Physical Activity in Older Adults with Chronic MSK Conditions

PHR: Project Narrative Frailty is a common clinical condition in older adults that is characterized by increased vulnerability to disability and mortality, and is a major burden for the healthcare system in the United States. Aging is the main risk factor for frailty; however, families of centenarians delay aging and are protected from frailty. Identifying genes and biological markers that protect from the effects of aging is an important step in the development of effective therapies that protect from and delay frailty.

PHR: Narrative. Alzheimer?s disease (AD) causes dementia in >5M Americans. A current focus at NIA is to identify novel drug targets, that address resilience to AD; also, there is an increasing perspective at NIA that Multi-target therapy may be necessary to overcome AD. We focus on small-molecule Shc blockers that increase resilience to A-beta and other insults. We propose in vivo MTD and efficacy studies in the 5XFAD and ApoE4 mouse model of our lead compound.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Since 2014, overdose deaths involving stimulants, primarily methamphetamine and cocaine, have risen rapidly, especially among Black, Latino, and Native American individuals. We will conduct interviews with people who use stimulants (PWUS), people who provide services to PWUS, and policymakers, to learn the individual, social, and environmental factors that affect whether and how people use stimulants, develop and recover from use disorder (i.e., addiction), and experience overdose. We will use these interviews and prior research to build a simulation model to test how different strategies could reduce use disorders and overdoses in two states ? Massachusetts and South Dakota ? with a focus on understanding differences by urban and rural settings as well as by race and ethnicity, using what we learn to inform national policy.
PI_NAMEs: DEUTSCH, ARIELLE R.; JALALI, MOHAMMAD S. (contact);
PROJECT_TITLE: A community-based systems science approach to assess risk and protective factors and improve the efficacy and equity of intervention strategies for stimulant use, use disorder, and overdose

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The project is relevant to public health because studying how Wnt signaling affects glucocorticoid-induced changes in the trabecular meshwork is ultimately expected to increase our understanding of the pathogenesis of glucocorticoid-induced glaucoma and provide therapeutic targets to the development of safer glucocorticoids. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NEI?s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge with respect to blinding eye diseases.

PHR: NARRATIVE:  This proposal addresses critical issues of central importance to advance our understanding of the mechanisms of dry age-related macular degeneration (AMD). Those include: investigating how AMPK/SIRT/PGC-1? pathway could play a critical role in RPE functions and how its inactivity could contribute to the pathophysiology of AMD. The results and conclusions derived from this study will provide important information that could be used for development of novel treatment strategies for a devastating neurodegenerative disease of the visual system that primarily affects the elderly, minimizes their independence, and impairs their quality of life.

PHR: Project Narrative Demonstrating the technical merit/feasibility of the Affect app in delivering digital care for methamphetamine use disorder (MUD) would potentially improve clinical care for the 1.6 million people in the nation who need treatment for MUD. If shown to be clinically useful, well-received by patients, and effective in retaining participants in the care program, the Affect app will be an important element in efficiently achieving optimum patient outcomes at reasonable cost. Resulting knowledge will be useful to clinicians, technology developers, and researchers when disseminated in publications, offering new insights into innovative means to help individuals with MUD reduce methamphetamine use and succeed in recovery.

PHR: The Yap oncogene is implicated in many human cancers. This proposal aims to study the processes downstream of Yap that cause cancer precursor cells to progress towards cancer. Core A: Administrative

PHR: Project Narrative: Opioid dependence and anxiety disorders represent major burdens to public health and are often comorbid, but the neurobiological mechanisms that link these two conditions is not entirely clear. The locus coeruleus is a brain structure that is activated by stress and inhibited by opioid drugs, but the long term impact of stress on this brain structure and its sensitivity to opioids has not been explored. In this research, we will investigate how traumatic stress causes long-lasting changes in the locus coeruleus that promote behaviors in animals that are similar to those observed in humans diagnosed with both anxiety and opioid use disorders.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding mechanisms of behavior change and moderators of treatment effects is critical for refining and tailoring youth cannabis use disorder interventions, as they currently demonstrate inconsistent outcomes. One influential and understudied factor is outcome expectancies, which are known to influence subjective effects and future cannabis use and may serve to moderate and mediate treatment effects. Examining the role expectancies play in youth CUD interventions will provide critical information to strengthen interventions, understand who may benefit most, and help clinicals tailor treatments to fit their client?s initial presentation.

PHR: Project Narrative Congenital Ichthyosis (CI) describes a heterogeneous family of inherited disorders of cornification that plague patients with life-long symptoms, including hyperkeratosis and/or scaling of the skin. Patagonia is pioneering an innovative topical isotretinoin ointment for the treatment of CI, PAT-001, which will selectively deliver isotretinoin to critical layers of the skin with minimal systemic absorption, mitigating the risk of side effects associated with systemic isotretinoin therapies. This Phase 2 clinical trial will establish the safety and efficacy of PAT-001 for a disease that has no FDA-approved treatments.
PROJECT_TITLE: Ph2.Study of PAT-001 for Treatment of Congenital Ichthyosis IND122058(7/27/2016)

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Many individuals with chronic conditions do not experience the full benefit of evidence-based medicine due to social, behavioral, and economic factors that may act as barriers to effective care. We will apply advanced analytic techniques to predict high risk of socially determined care needs, create an EHR-linked dashboard that can prioritize patients with the highest needs, and evaluate the acceptability and use of the dashboard in 3 participating primary care practices (Richmond, CA; Rainier Valley, WA; and Aurora, CO). We will use transparent analytic approaches and user centered design to ensure that our results and tool can be widely disseminated and effectively adapted and replicated to different clinical contexts.
PROJECT_TITLE: Care System Analytics to Support Primary Care Patients with Complex Medical and Social Needs

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative There is a severe underrepresentation of African individuals in genetic studies of neurodevelopmental disorders (NDDs), including intellectual disability, autism spectrum disorders, and attention deficit disorder. We propose to address this inequity through the NeuroDev Kenya project, which aims to collect blood and clinical, medical and demographic data from 800 Kenyan children and adults with NDDs, as well as their parents, and age- and ancestry-matched unrelated controls. We will share all data (phenotypic and genetic) and materials (blood DNA) from the study, and integrate the project with extensive capacity building activities. NeuroDev will create a critical foundation for NDD genomics research in Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: NARRATIVE Sexual and gender minority youth disproportionately report experiencing teen dating violence, as well as a number of associated adverse health outcomes, however few studies have assessed the prevalence and severity of online forms of teen dating violence known as cyber dating abuse (CDA). This research aims to investigate experiences of CDA among sexual and gender minority youth in the Deep South and evaluate the acceptability of future innovative digital violence prevention messaging and strategies. The long-term goal of this innovative research is to understand the context of CDA among marginalized youth and to inform the development of digital messaging campaigns and interventions to prevent violence and promote healthy adolescent relationships.
PROJECT_TITLE: A double-edged sword: Examining the role of technology inperpetuating and preventing teen dating violence among sexual and gender minorityyouth in the Deep South

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Influenza virus causes tens of millions of infections annually in the United States alone. The  ultimate goal of the proposed analyses is to understand how viral diversity generated during  influenza virus infection impacts disease dynamics on the within-host, between-host, and population  scales. A thorough characterization of this diversity will aid in the development of novel control  strategies which are effective against a broader range of influenza virus strains.

PHR: Through comprehensive analyses of brain proteomic data, we recently identified the ERK signaling pathway, specifically within microglia, as a central feature of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and a likely pathogenic mechanism. In this proposal, we will use a novel cell type-specific in-vivo proteomic labeling approach together with drugging and gene deletion studies to systematically define the distinctive roles of ERK signaling within neurons and microglia on AD pathogenesis. If successful, our studies will lead to identifying novel treatment targets and biomarkers for AD.

PHR: Project Narrative Chronic migraines and other headaches and are debilitating neurological conditions that affect millions of Americans, resulting in hundreds of thousands of ER visits annually where many patients are prescribed opioids. Thermaquil has discovered a new way of stopping migraine and other headache pain by noninvasively blocking cranial pain signal transmission that has led to the discontinuation of narcotics and other addictive pain medications. This project will test the Thermaquil system in a randomized controlled trial to demonstrate safety and effectiveness for stopping headache and migraine attacks and preventing migraines and other headaches.

ORG_NAME: VA NEW JERSEY HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Chronic repeat mild traumatic brain injury (rmTBI) is a neurodegenerative disease with neuroinflammation that afflicts individuals who have received repeated mild concussions. It appears to be present in a large percentage of professional players of contact sports and has been found in many studies of military veterans. Symptoms may include memory and emotional problems, suicidality and dementia. The disease typically progresses over a period of years or decades, and there is currently no known treatment that can slow or cure this process. Our laboratory has developed a novel immune regulatory drug (JM4) that shows remarkable beneficial effects in multiple models of neurodegeneration. We will test the hypothesis that JM4 will downregulate chronic inflammatory responses and block or reverse the development of rmTBI. We have recently received FDA approval for use of JM4 as an investigational new drug, and successful findings in this study may lead rapidly towards development of the first treatment for this devastating disease.

PHR: NARRATIVE Blepharospasm is a neurological disorder characterized by over-activity of the muscles around the eyes, leading to excessive blinking, eye spasms, impaired eyelid opening, and sometimes involvement of the lower face and jaw. In the current studies, we describe a multifaceted approach for the detection, discrimination, and measurement of these different problems, so that they can be better studied.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - Overall This application proposes the founding of a Tissue Mapping Center at Vanderbilt University associated with the Human BioMolecular Atlas Program (HuBMAP). The mission of this Tissue Mapping Center is to build a platform of integrated technologies for imaging and molecular analysis that enables the construction of comprehensive 3-dimensional molecular atlases of the human eye and pancreas. Our proposal leverages the unique analytical and computational resources of the Mass Spectrometry Research Center and the VU-Biomolecular Multimodal Imaging Center at Vanderbilt University, the world-class clinical environments of the Vanderbilt University Medical Center and University of Alabama at Birmingham, and unique technical expertise at Delft University of Technology to create a capability to characterize human tissues at a level of understanding unrivaled by current technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREV AND HEALTH PROMO
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of New Mexico Prevention Research Center will build on our strengths and expertise to provide leadership in prevention research through community engagement, training, communication, and the translation of research into practice and policy. We will collaborate with community partners to reduce chronic disease and health disparities by studying the dissemination and implementation of effective strategies to promote physical activity in rural Navajo communities in New Mexico.
PROJECT_TITLE: Healthy Places--Healthy People: A Toolkit for Promoting Active Living in Navajo Communities

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: FUND FOR PUBLIC HEALTH IN NEW YORK, INC.
PHR: Project Narrative Clinical decision support (CDS) has the potential to facilitate guidelines-based care and improve management of hypertension, but optimal strategies to implement and scale CDS remain unclear. This project aims to examine whether practice facilitation delivered in concert with CDS implementation can significantly improve guidelines-based care and hypertension control versus CDS alone. Identifying strategies that increase the success of hypertension-focused CDS are important to address the high burden of hypertension in the U.S., a leading risk factor for cardiovascular disease.
PROJECT_TITLE: Assessing the use practice facilitation to optimize scale up of CDS for hypertension management

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many adult organs, including the intestine, grow and shrink repeatedly across an animal?s lifetime to respond to its dynamic functional needs. During physiological shrinkage, live cells are purged out of the tissue (extrusion) and stem cells are culled, yet we know virtually nothing about the mechanisms that underlie these size- controlling behaviors. Here, we will leverage powerful live imaging and analysis methods developed by my lab to address fundamental questions about cell extrusion and stem cell behaviors during intestinal shrinkage; the knowledge we generate will create a conceptual framework that will inform vertebrate and possibly human studies of the intestine in both health and disease.

PHR: Narrative: Coronary artery disease is a major health problem in the world, leading to significant morbidity and mortality. In studies proposed here, Drs. Muzumdar and Dutta will evaluate the potential of a new peptide called Humanin to protect the heart following ischemia-reperfusion and prevent progression to heart failure in a clinically relevant mouse model of aging, and examine the mechanisms that mediate the cardioprotection. Humanin could be a potential new treatment option for treatment of acute myocardial infarction and prevention of progression to heart failure in the elderly.

ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The CARRIAGE II program is a direct counterattack to the growing crisis of antimicrobial resistance and emerging infectious threats, comprising a series of related implementation and quality improvement projects unified around the common goal of arresting and potentially reversing the spread of antimicrobial resistance in VA healthcare facilities and beyond. CARRIAGE II projects will target the behaviors and processes at the critical points in the chain of infection that facilitate the development and spread of antibiotic-resistant pathogens, thereby breaking the cycle of transmission and improving Veteran health and safety. The findings from this QUERI program have the potential to transform biosurveillance, infection control, and antimicrobial prescribing practices throughout the VA healthcare system. We expect CARRIAGE II to have substantial and long-lasting impact in improving the quality of care and safety of our Veterans by informing future VA-wide prevention and patient safety efforts.

PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance This proposal was developed to elucidate the most salient risk factors for one of the most persistent health disparities affecting the HIV+ population ? neurocognitive impairment (NCI) ? among the group most impacted by the HIV epidemic ? sexual minority men (SMM). At present, empirical insight into the etiology of HIV- associated neurocognitive disorders (HAND) is limited, which has prevented the development of empirically supported treatments for HAND. By integrating prominent theories of social psychology and neuroscience, this study aims to provide insight into the interactive impact of socio-structural syndemic factors (i.e., poverty, trauma), minority stress, and physiological factors (i.e., inflammatory cytokines) on NCI risk among HIV+ SMM, thus paving the way for the informed development of urgently needed intervention strategies for HAND.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This research will generate a novel line of high-impact evidence regarding connections among methamphetamine use, social relationships, and cognitive functioning among people with HIV across the life course (ages 18-87) and will highlight pathways to develop interventions to maintain brain health for this population. The Principal Investigator will utilize innovative and rigorous statistical methods including time-varying effect modeling and cross-lagged structural equation modeling by leveraging the NIH?s previous and ongoing investments in HIV and methamphetamine research at the University of California, San Diego. An understanding of how social relationships mediate the impacts of HIV and methamphetamine use on cognitive function across the life span can inform future treatment responses and care interventions designed to reduce substance use and negative impacts on cognitive function among people with co-occurring HIV and substance use disorders.

PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer?s disease is a devastating terminal disease with no cure, and rapidly increasing worldwide prevalence, posing a global crisis to the healthcare economy. There is a critical need to identify at earlier stages of the disease to better develop preventative and treatment strategies, however there has yet to be a standard test that is easy to admit with a high accuracy at early stages of the disease. The objective of this proposed project is to develop and commercialize an acoustic-based liquid biopsy that will serve as a platform for conducting simple blood tests with rapid processing times and high accuracy for a large suite of exosomal based biomarkers for Alzheimer?s disease present in the patients? blood ? an industry first.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Title: The role of cognitive skills and language experience in grammatical processing This work represents a novel exploration of individual differences in reading ability in both children and adults, with the goal of understanding which factors lead to poor comprehension. Low literacy attainment is linked with poor health outcomes and increased levels of infant and child mortality in the population (DeWalt & Pignone, 2005), and is even more closely associated with poor health than the number of years of school completed (Baker et al., 1996).

ORG_NAME: SOUTH TEXAS VETERANS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Patients with social risk factors, including poverty, being a minority, lack of an education, and living in rural areas are all associated with having worse health outcomes and having more difficulties recovering after surgical procedures. We will study the effect of social risk factors and rurality on health outcomes after surgery to identify patients that would benefit from care pathways that help poor people. One problem is that medical records usually do not contain information about social risk factors. We will use multiple data sources to try to determine which social risk factors have the most effect on surgical outcomes. These studies will help us understand outcomes in patients receiving care within and outside of the VA and how to use that data to improve our ability to identify patients that need extra help. In addition, a better understanding of which social risk factors lead to poor outcomes will help us to design care pathways that provide services and treatments that will improve outcomes after surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Co-occurring attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and alcohol problems are associated with long- term morbidity, disability, and poor treatment prognosis, posing high direct and indirect costs to these individuals and society. College is a period during which youth with ADHD are especially vulnerable for the escalation of risky alcohol use, yet key psychological, behavioral, and environmental factors that amplify risk during this critical developmental period are largely unexamined. The proposed study seeks to integrate foundational components of behavioral economics models of addiction and novel daily diary methodology, with the goal to elucidate predictors and moderators of alcohol problems among college students with and without ADHD. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: A nervous system is made up of individual neurons wired together in highly specific patterns. The goal of this research is to understand how these patterns form by identifying the proteins neurons use to select their partners and determining how the process is genetically regulated. The results will help us understand how innate behaviors are encoded by the genome and explore links between circuit development and neurological disorders.

PHR: Narrative The overall goal of this project is to determine whether the Human Herpesvirus 6A (HHV6A) latency gene U94A plays a role in Alzheimer?s disease. The study is motivated by recent multiscale network analyses of Alzheimer patients that revealed specific and significant association of Alzheimer disease (AD) with HHV6A. We use Alzheimer patient derived cells and a new mouse model to test the overall hypothesis that U94A, which is expressed during latent HHV6A infection, is a disease-modifying factor that impairs the normal function of neurons and glial cells, and may increase patient vulnerability to other AD causing factors thereby accelerating AD onset and pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposal, 109 Therapeutics will develop a novel, opioid-sparing anesthetic wound dressing for partial- thickness dermal wounds (e.g., second-degree burns, skin graft donor sites, abrasion injuries). By combining moist wound healing and extended-duration analgesia, this technology has the potential to change how pain from dermal injury is managed. Significant value may be realized by patients, providers and society by improving patient satisfaction, reducing opioid-related adverse events, and lowering overall costs of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREV AND HEALTH PROMO
PHR: Clarkston, Georgia is a refugee settlement and migrant gateway city that accepts thousands of migrants each year. A Prevention Research Center at Georgia State University (the GSU PRC) that is to be housed in the diverse community of Clarkston will provide a unique opportunity for a community-academic partnership focused on migrant health and community needs. This proposed mixed-method implementation study seeks to adapt the evidence-based parenting program, SafeCare, to evaluate two methods of implementation, as addressing early adverse experiences of children is a key to improving long-term mental and physical health.
PROJECT_TITLE: Addressing Social Determinants of Health in the Most Diverse Square Mile in America

PHR: Project Narrative ?NIA Collaboratories for Artificial Intelligence and Healthy Aging? or AHA Collab will serve as the coordinating center for AI and Technology Collaboratories for Aging Research (AITC). In addition to providing strategic leadership, efficient coordination, creative dissemination, and effective project management, review, evaluation, and reporting services, AHA Collab will feature AHA Combinator?an incubator that not only matches technologies with capital but also more importantly connects funded pilot projects with strategic and tactical guidance, resources, and mentorship. AHA Collab activities will be focused on potentiating the success of the AITCs and successfully translating research to application for the benefit of older Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Our ability to understand and treat neurological disorders is limited by the gaps in our knowledge of the regulatory mechanisms that enable synaptic plasticity. Neuronal RNA binding proteins (RBPs) are essential regulators of RNA metabolism and have been implicated in diseased states. This study will seek to characterize RBP-RNA interactions in functioning neurons to uncover novel regulatory mechanisms that promote synaptic plasticity underlying learning and memory.

PHR: Project Narrative Various adverse and protective environments may affect child development. The Healthy Brain and Child Development National Consortium (HBCD-NC) will follow 7,500 mothers and their children from 24 locations across the U.S. from before birth to 10 years of age to better understand which harmful and protective environments exert the greatest impact on child development. ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Autophagy, the fundamental process by which cells clear aggregated proteins and damaged organelles, is the key to maintaining neuronal homeostasis. Since many neurological disorders such Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and Huntington's disease are caused by the accumulation of the abnormal proteins or damaged organelles, the enhancement of autophagy has been suggested as a potential therapeutic strategy. This project investigates the role of a novel neuronal autophagic pathway, the DIRAS pathway, in neuronal autophagy and in the degradation of aggregation-prone proteins.

ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: Community Living Centers (CLCs) provide care for over 40,000 vulnerable Veterans every year and serve as a safety net setting for many Veterans who cannot find care in non-VA nursing homes. This award will support Dr. Hartmann's research on measuring and improving the quality of CLC care, helping Veterans who live in CLCs have better outcomes. Dr. Hartmann's work to date with CLCs across the nation shows this is possible. CLCs that use techniques she developed have, for example, improved care and risen in their quality rankings. This award will expand this type of research, helping the VA system better provide high-quality Veteran care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Youth violence remains a significant public health problem, and evidence suggests that youth communicate threats on social media that are implicated in offline violence (i.e., cyberbanging). The role of social media in youth violence and the pervasive use of social media by modern youth calls for interventions that integrate new technology in addressing youth violence. The objective of this career development and research plan is to obtain high quality training and conduct advanced research to inform the development of a social media-based intervention that enhances street outreach programs to reduce cyberbanging implicated in youth violence.
PROJECT_TITLE: Preventing Youth Violence through Technology Enhanced Street Outreach: A Community Engaged Approach

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREV AND HEALTH PROMO
PHR: Narrative: NORC, the University of Washington, Prevent Blindness, and the American Academy of Ophthalmology propose an ambitious strategy to maintain and enhance the Vision and Eye Health Surveillance System (VEHSS). Building on our success in building the foundation of the VEHSS, our proposal details and demonstrates our plans to preserve, maintain and protect CDC's significant investment to create the VEHSS, to expand the scope of VEHSS to include new datasets and county-level coverage, and to design and conduct an innovative study to conduct multi-level validation of vision and eye health indicators to be used in VEHSS.
PROJECT_TITLE: Research to Enhance the US Vision and Eye Health Surveillance System

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREV AND HEALTH PROMO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preventing weight gain in adults through modest changes in the home food environment has the potential to be an important strategy for addressing the obesity epidemic. This implementation research will establish a model for scaling up interventions developed through community-based participatory research through a regional 2-1- 1 system that reaches those most at risk for obesity.
PROJECT_TITLE: Emory Prevention Research Center

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREV AND HEALTH PROMO
PHR: Deaf sign language users and people with hearing loss comprise two populations that are overlooked by most public health research, surveillance and programs. The mission of the Rochester Prevention Research Program (RPRC) is to promote health and prevent disease with these two populations through community- based participatory research (CBPR). RPRC, Deaf communities, and other stakeholders are working together to study the implementation of Deaf Weight Wise, an evidence-based healthy lifestyle program to treat and prevent obesity with Deaf adult sign language users.
PROJECT_TITLE: Rochester Prevention Research Center

PHR: Public Health Significance This timely, culturally-tailored intervention study has the potential to markedly improve the standards of overdose and HIV/HCV prevention among at-risk veterans. Peer-led interventions for substance use disorders have proven effective at reaching stigmatized, at-risk populations, and this intervention contributes to the evidence base for remediating the health impacts of opioid use by advancing a tripartite (education, navigation, and support) protocol to reduce risks. The products of this pragmatic trial will be of great interest to the wide range of community-based and civic healthcare organizations committed to reducing opioid-related harms while fostering social and healthcare engagement among veterans.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative The kynurenine pathway has been implicated in both stroke and depression, but has never been evaluated in post-stroke depression. We will evaluate whether the inhibition of a key enzyme of this pathway ? kynurenine 3-monooxygenase (KMO) ? will prevent and/or minimize the development of post-stroke depression in aged mice, and if this will produce a more robust effect in aged females. We will use a multi-faceted approach using both pharmacological and genetic animal models to inhibit or delete KMO levels, and we will investigate changes in KMO and kynurenine pathway metabolite levels to determine if this is a potential therapeutic strategy to prevent post-stroke depression and enhance recovery after stroke.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep plays an integral role in creating, consolidating, and storing memories. This project will investigate the role of hippocampal interneuron activity during rapid eye movement sleep in contextual memory formation, using optogenetic manipulation of a specific interneuron population, electrophysiological recording, and imaging of hippocampal population activity. Such studies are crucial to understanding the underlying neurobiological mechanisms of learning and memory as well as providing insight into how sleep disruption and disease can lead to a disruption in normal cognitive processing.

ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is common in Veterans, affecting 47% of those with a diagnosed sleep disorder. OSA treatment improves health, and positive airway pressure (PAP), the mainstay of OSA therapy, is effective. However, adherence to PAP is low: 24% of patients stop therapy within 3 months and another 23% stop use by 1 year. This project seeks to identify and validate breathing patterning metrics from sleep study and PAP machine respiratory signals as adherence predictors. By repurposing respiratory signals obtained during routine clinical care, this project would allow for targeting of interventions to improve adherence in Veterans that would most benefit ? those most likely to become nonadherent. Since no new equipment or testing is necessary, this project has the potential for streamlined integration into clinical care, saving time for Veterans and increasing VA healthcare efficiency.

PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer?s disease is a public health crisis with no disease-modifying treatment, so prevention is key to reducing its prevalence. The proposed research will elucidate the extent to which infection with Herpes Simplex Virus Types 1 and 2, Cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr Virus, Toxoplasma gondii?measured four times over ~25 years?and SARS-CoV-2 (the virus that causes COVID-19) are associated with subsequent cognitive and functional decline and diagnoses of mild cognitive impairment and dementia, measures of Alzheimer?s disease pathology from blood samples, and accelerated biological aging. Results will advance our understanding of whether common infections increase the risk for Alzheimer?s disease and related dementias and how they might do so.

Our studies will provide new information into mitochondrial and molecular mechanisms in neuronal cell types in key reward brain regions in cocaine action.

PHR: Narrative Microglia, the primary immune cells and the sensor of the brain's health, play a pivotal role in the maintenance of brain homeostasis, but lose their functions during the course of aging and neurodegenerative diseases. The goal of this proposal is to develop treatment for protection neurons from apoptosis and microglia from acquiring neurodegenerative phenotype using noble gas xenon (Xe), which can ultimately become a novel AD therapy. We plan to investigate the protective effect of Xe on the AD brain homeostasis and design a method for Xe delivery in the optimal concentration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ST. JOSEPH'S HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In C9orf72 frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) the disease mechanisms cause concurrent degeneration of forebrain cortical and spinal and cortical motor neurons, therefore resulting in the clinical deficits in cognitive and motor functions. In ALS, a contribution of the observed spinal motor neurodegeneration has been attributed to spinal cord astrocytes, but little is known about the role of cortical astrocytes and its regulation of cortical forebrain neurons. This research proposal aims to examine the regulation of cortical astrocytes in the disease pathology contributing to the neurodegeneration of cortical neurons in C9orf72-FTD/ALS and its subsequent contribution to cognitive impairment and dementia in this patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Skyrocketing opioid-related overdose (OD) deaths are an urgent public health issue that demands an effective response, and changing the standard of post-OD emergency department (ED) care must be part of the solution. Relay?a peer navigator-led secondary OD prevention intervention administered by the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene?has demonstrated feasibility and acceptability, and could be rapidly scaled up in state and local health departments throughout the U.S., but rigorous study is needed to establish its effectiveness. The proposed research is relevant to CDC?s mission because it advances the science of OD prevention and can inform programs and policies for ED-based interventions for secondary prevention of opioid OD.
PROJECT_TITLE: Randomized Controlled Trial of Relay- NYC's Nonfatal Overdose Response Program

PHR: NARRATIVE  Alzheimer?s Disease (AD) is a devasting degenerative brain disease that is increasing in prevalence and there is no effective treatment. Although very rare forms of the disease are caused by inheriting abnormal genes, most cases have no definitive genetic cause, although many risk-associated genes have been identified. These studies will focus on the role of one risk-associated gene, angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) and its function in processing abnormal proteins produced in the brain in patients with AD that lead to neuron death and dementia.

PHR: Project Narrative Disorders of blood development are responsible for a number of diseases including leukemia, myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), and clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP), but most of our current therapies for treating these disorders are not able to distinguish between diseased and healthy blood cells. The apoptolidins and ciromicins are compounds produced by soil bacteria which appear to only target specific types of blood cells, including those found in disorders of blood development. We propose to determine how these compounds are able to affect some cells, but not others, with the long-term goal of developing more effective and less toxic treatments for these deadly disorders.

PHR: In 2015, over 12,000 Veterans had percutaneous coronary interventions (PCI) in VA hospitals nationwide. Drug eluting stents reduce the risk of restenosis compared to bare metal stents but require longer dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and a thienopyridine inhibitor to prevent stent thrombosis and myocardial infarction, but with higher risks of major bleeding. Currently, newer 2nd-generation drug eluting stents have replaced the 1st-generation stents, and more potent DAPT agents offer lower risks of myocardial infarction. Shorter duration DAPT could lower the risk of complications from major bleeding and treatment costs. However, there are no large trials to assess the benefits or risks of shorter DAPT. Veterans receiving PCI in the VA have 2-4 times the risk of death or myocardial infarction compared to patients in largely non-VA research studies. Thus the question of DAPT duration remains critically important in the VA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: We will perform a detailed cartography of the metabolic programing of the immune cells in the gastrointestinal tract and adjacent tissues and probe the role of metabolism in driving HV pathogenesis by administration of a western diet (WD, rich in fats and sugars, low in fiber) and therapeutic interventions with statins and assessment of their impact on the reservoir seeding, maintenance and reactivation. We developed and optimized the assays necessary for the proposed studies and established strategic collaborations with academic and industry leaders in this field. Importantly, if our strategy is successful, our project could have a major impact in the management of HIV patients, either alone or in combination with latency reversing agents, and will represent a significant step towards a better control of HIV.

PHR: Project Narrative A functioning retina is the result of an extraordinary orchestration of complex pathways responsible for its development and homeostasis; any deficits in these pathways may lead to disease and loss of sight. We have recently shown that a powerful and unbiased state-of-the-science forward genetics approach can be used to identify novel gene-phenotype associations that are crucial to retinal health, and we propose now to exploit this strategy to identify and characterize genes and pathways that regulate: 1) retinal development and homeostasis, 2) retinal immune surveillance, and 3) early diabetic retinopathy. Our long-term goal is to leverage our research results for the discovery of novel therapeutic targets for retinal diseases and in the development of new retinal regeneration strategies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The nucleus of the solitary tract (NTS), located in the brainstem, contains a heterogenous population of neurons that are implicated in both the inhibition of pulsatile LH secretion during stress and the facilitation of elevated LH secretion during the preovulatory LH surge. The objective of this work is to anatomically and functionally characterize individual NTS neuronal subpopulations in the regulation of LH secretion. Enhanced understanding of the diverse neural pathways that regulate LH secretion may provide a framework for developing therapies for amenorrhea, infertility, and stress-related reproductive disorders.

PHR: LAY NARRATIVE  This project seeks to address which brain cells are involved in controlling the drive to sleep with a focus on the preoptic area of the hypothalamus that is known to be involved in sleep regulation. These questions will be addressed by the new technique of single nucleus RNA seq.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To prevent self-removal of endotracheal and nasogastric tubes, and intravenous lines, older critically ill patients in the intensive care unit are often restrained with traditional wrist restraints causing agitation, increased use of sedatives, prolonged immobility, and delirium, all of which can lead to long-term cognitive impairment similar to Alzheimer?s Disease and Related Dementias. Healthy Design has developed a novel restraint alternative intended to allow freedom of movement while deterring entanglement of vital tubes and lines thereby reducing the need for these harmful interventions. Successful completion of this project will result in a sustainable source of the Exersides? Refraint? System novel restraint alternative through early consultation and contracting to strengthen the Company?s infrastructure and position it for strategic partnership or organic growth through revenue.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Healthy Brain and Child Development National Consortium study (HBCD) will follow 7,500 mothers and their children from locations across the U.S. from before birth to 10 years of age to better understand which harmful and protective environments exert the greatest impact on child development. This study will help to improve the health and development of children across the nation. The proposed HBCD National Consortium Administrative Core (HCAC) will provide the leadership and overall management of the consortium to ensure the project?s success.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The blood-cerebrospinal fluid barrier (BCSFB) plays an essential role in removing metabolic wastes, drugs and toxins from the brain. This project will investigate a novel transporter-mediated drug elimination pathway at the BCSFB and explore the impact of aging on BCSFB drug transporter expression and function. These studies will build a functional and mechanistic framework for future studies to investigate the specific impact of BCSFB drug transporters and aging on CNS drug disposition, pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics.

PHR: Emergency care work is inherently important to society as it involves life-threatening injuries and situations that affect people from all backgrounds. This research aims to design and develop novel wearable technologies that can improve care coordination during prehospital encounters across distributed emergency care teams, and ultimately, improve patient outcomes and achieve patient-centered care delivery and coordination.
PROJECT_TITLE: A novel approach for supporting care coordination across distributed emergency care teams

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: The City of Philadelphia has the second highest opioid overdose death rate in the United States. In response, Philadelphia has developed an overarching overdose prevention strategy, the Resilience Project, which includes both services targeted toward people who use opioids and neighborhood environment interventions that address the blighted conditions where most overdoses occur. The objective of this proposal, Studying the PhilAdelphia Resilience Project as a Response to Overdose (SPARROw), is to leverage a natural experiment to evaluate the effectiveness and implementation of two highly innovative Resilience Project programs targeted at the time and place of opioid overdose: (1) the Alternative Response Unit (ARU) that accompanies ambulances responding to overdoses and aims to deliver harm reduction and care linkage to people who refuse hospital transport, and (2) blight remediation of abandoned buildings and land.
PI_NAMEs: MEISEL, ZACHARY FRANKLIN (contact); SOUTH, EUGENIA C;
PROJECT_TITLE: Studying the PhilAdelphia Resilience Project as a Response to Overdose (SPARRow)

PHR: Project Narrative Our center (University of Alabama at Birmingham and University of Alabama) will join other centers from the consortium in enrolling pregnant women and their infants in a comprehensive prospective, longitudinal and multimodal data collection. We will examine variability in outcomes and the effect of substance exposure in utero as well as other experiences in development and the interaction with genetic, biological and endocrine system. Our center, has extensive experience in participating in similar multicenter studies and, will be able to enroll dyads of mothers and their infants.

PHR: Narrative Alzheimer?s Disease (AD) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease that is the most common cause of dementia, and a significant healthcare burden worldwide. This condition results in progressive memory loss and cognitive decline, which lead to dramatic repercussions for affected individuals and their families. Many genetic studies have identified sex differences to be a critical factor in AD risk, progression, and severity across individuals, but precisely which sex-related mechanisms are responsible for these differences remain unknown. These studies systematically dissect the mechanisms underlying these observed differences using cutting-edge experimental and computational methods to predict sex-specific causal variants, regulatory regions, genes, and pathways; and systematic experimental characterization of predicted drivers using mouse models to better understand the mechanistic basis of sex-related differences in AD. These results will form the foundation for a deeper understanding of AD and new therapeutic development against this devastating disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will provide insight on how kidney cells respond to lipotoxicity-induced injury and identify genes that regulate those responses. Lipotoxicity involves the toxic accumulation of lipids in non-adipose tissues that can lead to cell injury and death and has been implicated to play a role in the pathogenesis of diabetic kidney disease. Understanding the molecular mechanisms of lipotoxicity in kidney disease may contribute to the development of therapeutic strategies for which there is a largely unmet need.

PHR: Project Narrative With old age and heart failure (HF), diaphragm dysfunction renders the diaphragm susceptible to mechanical ventilation related complications. Our preliminary data in rats demonstrate that HF+Aging massively impairs skeletal muscle vascular function and, if this occurs in the diaphragm, may be a contributing factor to the high mortality rates in COVID-19 ventilator patients with HF. This proposal seeks to identify the mechanistic bases for HF+Aging diaphragmatic dysfunction with and without the added insult of mechanical ventilation and identify rapidly-implementable strategies to mitigate that dysfunction.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Diagnostic delays for infectious diseases contribute to worse clinical outcomes, increased healthcare costs and, for some infectious diseases, outbreaks of great public health importance. We will use existing large data sets along with machine-learning techniques and expert clinical guidance to detect patterns of healthcare visits representing diagnostic delays. Our goal is to characterize the incidence, risk factors and clinical impact of diagnostic delays for a wide range of infectious diseases to inform future interventions.
PI_NAMEs: KUNTZ, JENNIFER L.; MILLER, AARON C; POLGREEN, PHILIP M. (contact);
PROJECT_TITLE: An expert-guided machine-learning approach to estimate the incidence, risk and harms associated with diagnostic delays for infectious diseases.

PHR: NARRATIVE Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a major problem among military veterans, yet its biology is poorly understood. The VA MVP is an ideal setting for study of this problem, and we are completing a Cooperative Studies Program project (CSP#575B) in the MVP, to identify genetic risk factors relevant to PTSD and related traits via genomewide association study (GWAS). Our project has already been highly successful at mapping gene loci, so far for PTSD re-experiencing and related traits. With more subjects there will be increased power to map relevant traits; we will continue GWAS of PTSD and related traits in the expanded sample. We will use approaches in post-GWAS analysis that permit testing of causality among correlated traits (e.g., Mendelian Randomization, MR). We will complete phenomewide association studies of PTSD top GWAS-identified genes (e.g., CRHR1 and others), PTSD polygenic risk score (PRS) analysis within MVP, and MR to detect causal mechanisms related to PTSD pathogenesis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of the proposed research is to elucidate the mechanisms by which ?-Amyloid (A?) and its variants contribute collectively to the pathology of Alzheimer?s Disease. Despite the myriad Alzheimer?s Disease therapeutics targeting the production and clearance of the A? peptide, a cure is yet to be identified. This work aims to elucidate the role of the p3 peptide in amyloid plaque formation, ultimately refining the currently accepted amyloid model.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it develops new brain imaging methods to improve the spatial and temporal resolution, and applies them to study visual processing of faces. The methods developed here will broaden our ability to answer questions about the spatiotemporal trajectory of neural computation in the human brain. In the field of vision, a principled understanding of the computational steps of face perception could lead to a better understanding of visual impairments.

IC_NAME: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Structural discrimination affects the wellbeing of minoritized emerging adults. Emerging research suggests that the fostering of critical consciousness may support wellbeing for these youth. My research expands the study of minoritized emerging adults? wellbeing in three important ways through: examining the longitudinal, bidirectional relationship between critical consciousness and wellbeing, considering the role of critical consciousness in moderating the known relationship between discrimination and well-being, and centering of the role of community-based organizations in fostering wellbeing.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity continues to be a barrier to kidney transplantation for some patients with end stage kidney disease, even though there is no clear evidence to support weight loss prior to transplantation. The proposed Symposium on Obesity and Kidney Transplantation will bring health services researchers, clinicians, allied health professionals and patients with obesity together to discuss current clinical practice, cutting edge research and patients' lived experiences to develop an agenda with specific research questions for future inquiry.
PROJECT_TITLE: Symposium on Obesity and Kidney Transplantation

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative This proposed study seeks to determine if ambulatory surgical centers (ASCs) offer a less costly setting for delivering high-quality pediatric dental surgical procedures than hospital outpatient departments (HOPDs). This study will compare the cost and quality of care of pediatric dental surgical procedures delivered in ASCs and HOPDs using three complementary datasets: the universe of procedures paid by Medicaid; a sample of procedures paid by commercial insurers in 35 states; and the universe of procedures in Florida. Quality will be measured across four dimensions: cost, receipt of timely care, receipt of safe care, and receipt of equitable care.
PROJECT_TITLE: Comparing Quality of Care for Pediatric Dental Procedures Conducted in Ambulatory Surgical Centers and Hospital Outpatient Departments

Through these efforts, the Consortium Coordinating Center significantly magnifies the impact of SBE activities and findings.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Teleophthalmology using retinal cameras in primary care clinics has been shown to improve diabetic eye screening rates and visual outcomes, but remains greatly underutilized in the U.S. This multi-center randomized controlled trial proposes to test the effectiveness and generalizability of a promising implementation program (I- SITE: Implementation to Sustain Impact in Teleophthalmology) for sustaining increased diabetic eye screening rates using teleophthalmology in rural health systems. This research seeks to identify methods for successful integration of telemedicine technology into rural primary care workflows to prevent blindness from diabetes, the leading cause of blindness among working-age U.S. adults.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early diagnosis and identification of predictors for dementia is crucial as it allows for intervention with prevention and treatment strategies which can stop or delay progress. This 2-year project will develop and validate a real-space navigation test with a fully immersive virtual reality headset that detects signs of dementia by measuring navigation and gait abilities. The knowledge generated during this study will help scientists and engineers understand how navigational abilities change in older adults at risk of developing Alzheimer?s disease and could be useful to develop an affordable and accurate test to predict and detect cognitive decline using a portable virtual reality system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Efficient alternative splicing of RNA through the minor spliceosome is imperative for human health, as underscored by our discovery of the association between aberrant minor intron splicing and Early-Onset Cerebellar Ataxia (EOCA). This project examines how a single nucleotide substitution within the U12 snRNA, a critical minor spliceosome component, causes human EOCA due to selective detrimental splicing in a tissue and time-dependent manner, while complete loss of U12 snRNA activity causes early embryonic lethality in mice. Our work will provide insight into the little understood mechanisms of U12-dependent minor intron splicing and its impact on gene expression, and how minor spliceosome dysfunction can disrupt early embryonic development or lead to human disease.

PHR: NARRATIVE Mitochondrial dysfunction is a key contributor to the reduced muscle function and subsequent decline in quality of life in the elderly. Uncertainty around the nature of the mitochondrial dysfunction presents a barrier to developing targeted interventions. The proposed experiments will combine state of the art tools to assess mitochondrial structure-function changes in aged skeletal muscle and heart mitochondria to define the mechanisms of dysfunction with age.

PHR: Project Narrative This project will help elucidate a novel role of a major regulatory protein complex, mTORC1, on the efflux of most essential amino acids from the lysosome through SLC38A9. Deregulated mTORC1 activity has been implicated in a range of diseases, including cancer. These results will provide a novel mechanism for how mTORC1 promotes growth by regulating the acquisition of essential nutrients from the lysosome via SLC38A9 and may also identify new therapeutic agents to impact SLC38A9 transport function.

PHR: NARRATIVE Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is the most common endocrine disorder in women of reproductive age, affecting ~5 million women in the U.S. and over 100 million globally. The metabolic system is particularly susceptible to the deleterious effects of prenatal androgen excess. Prenatal androgen excess induces reproductive and metabolic (e.g., insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia) imbalances. Studies detailed in this supplement are targeted towards delineating the mechanisms at the hypothalamic, liver, and adipose tissue level that contribute to the development of metabolic dysfunctions.

PHR: Narrative Osteopenia, which affects approximately 43M Americans, is a common skeletal condition that is defined by an accelerated loss of bone mass that can lead to osteoporosis if not treated. Bone Health Technologies has developed OsteoBoost, a wearable vibration device that is designed to provide safe, effective, and convenient mechanical stimulation to the hips and spine to mitigate bone loss associated with osteopenia. In this Commercialization Readiness Pilot (CRP) project, we propose to expand upon our Phase II work to support regulatory approval and commercialization of a cost-competitive OsteoBoost device.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The National Academy of Medicine has called for the inclusion of older adults in cancer research; yet, knowledge gaps remain with respect to important patient-reported outcomes, such as functional status, resiliency, and treatment toxicity, in this population. The proposed research seeks to test the feasibility and preliminary effect of one of the first virtual health supportive care clinical trials using physical therapy and progressive muscle relaxation among older adults with advanced lung cancer.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Patients who are older or suffer from conditions that cause chronic pain that interferes with their lives are at considerably higher risk for adverse effects of opioid medications. Therefore, addressing the specific needs and health challenges of these populations through innovative pain management strategies that can be implemented in primary care settings is urgently needed. To address these needs, our team designed a multi- faceted, person-centered and scalable program that can be implemented in primary care practices and which aims at improving pain management for older adults and those with functional disabilities or increased social risk.

PROJECT_TITLE: Addressing Opioid Use Disorder in Older Adults through Primary Care Innovation (OUD-PCI)

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The learning health system (LHS) is a new and rapidly evolving delivery system where, in its ideal, each patient encounter provides an opportunity to make the next patient encounter better. This program aims to develop the human capital to support that ideal. We will develop new LHS leaders by training junior faculty to apply patient centered outcomes research (PCOR) methods and conduct PCOR research within the opportunities and challenges of functioning health systems.
PI_NAMEs: ASCH, DAVID A; LANE-FALL, MEGHAN BROOKS (contact);
PROJECT_TITLE: Learning Health Systems Mentored Career Development Program

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A dynamic multimedia platform, known as the Collaborative for Aging Research and Engagement (CARE) Platform, guided by community based participatory research approach and the user centered design process to engage and educate African Americans ages 45 and older to participate in clinical Alzheimer?s disease and related dementia (ADRD) studies. Outcomes focuses on increasing brain health and ADRD health literacy and intention to participate in clinical ADRD research studies. Next steps will be to use and leverage existing state Alzheimer?s Association networks to scale this work to a regional and national level and the long-term impact will be to increase breadth and depth of engagement in aging research such that research and findings can be more representative of underrepresented populations and thereby help reduce health disparities in ADRD.

PHR: Project Summary/Abstract  Myotonic dystrophy causes progressive disability and premature death. The burden on affected individuals, care givers, and families is high. This proposal seeks to develop the essential clinical research tools that are needed to evaluate new drug treatments for myotonic dystrophy. The long-term goal is to promote the development of treatments that prevent the disease, slow the progression, reduce the disability, or reverse the symptoms.
PI_NAMEs: JOHNSON, NICHOLAS ELWOOD (contact); THORNTON, CHARLES A;
PROJECT_TITLE: Establishing Biomarkers and Clinical Endpoints in Myotonic Dystrophy Type-1

PHR: The NEI?s audacious goal, to ?regenerate neurons and neural connections in the eye and visual system,? requires translation-enabling animal models that recapitulate human retinal disease in order to evaluate strategies to regenerate photoreceptors. Here we propose to develop, characterize and disseminate two promising model systems that are closer to human visual anatomy and function than current mouse and rat models: the 13-lined ground squirrel (diurnal, cone-dominant rodents with large brain regions dedicated to processing visual information) and the tree shrew (non-rodent, primate-like mammals that are also cone dominant). The project will first validate these models by comparing their cellular-resolution phenotype with that seen in patients with similar gene mutations, then, evaluate and optimize integration of transplanted iPSC-derived cone photoreceptors in normal and diseased 13-lined ground squirrels and tree shrews.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer?s disease (AD) is the most common form of dementia in humans, yet there is no cure for AD and the increasing incidence of AD in developed countries poses a tremendous cost to society as lifespans increase. There are two forms of AD, those that have genetic determinants and those that arise sporadically upon aging and comprise the vast majority (~95%) of new AD cases diagnosed. Given that alterations in brain mitochondria appear early in the development of sporadic AD, we propose studies to further characterize the role of ECSIT, a key regulator of mitochondrial function in the development of AD.

IC_NAME: National Center for Complementary & Integrative Health
PHR: Project Narrative: Mindfulness-based interventions like MBCT and MBSR may provide additional treatment options for acute hard-to-treat psychiatric conditions including treatment-resistant depression, GAD, and PTSD. However, the specific therapeutic mechanisms underlying MBCT/MBSR are not well understood, nor is it known whether these are shared with other therapies, or provide novel and potentially complimentary treatment components that can be used in combination. Elucidating MBCT mechanisms can enhance ongoing refinement and optimal targeting of psychotherapy interventions for PTSD and other acute psychiatric disorders.
PROJECT_TITLE: Neural Mechanisms of Mindfulness-based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) for Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic kidney disease (CKD) affects millions of people in the United States; the only cure is a kidney transplant. Investigation into kidney development will promote the advancement of nephron replacement approaches, including tissue engineering and therapeutic interventions. This project aims to study the mechanism by which kidney endothelial cells (ECs) are patterned in the kidney and develop methods to promote vascular and nephron maturation in organoids.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Oregon Health & Science University in partnership with Kaiser Permanente Northwest Region proposes a Center of Excellence and K12 Training Program in Learning Health Systems Science (NW PCOR LHS COE & K12) with an overarching objective to develop our nation?s leaders and innovators in Learning Health Systems (LHS) science. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a common congenital heart disease that affects 1 in 3000 children, and while TOF surgical repair is part of standard care in the first year of life, some patients have poor valve function and heart disease. There is a need for additional information about which patients will develop heart disease to guide the timing of surgery and improve our scientific understanding of this condition. The purpose of this proposal is to develop magnetic resonance (MR) techniques to understand myocardial metabolism following TOF repair.

PHR: NARRATIVE The overall goal of our Vision Research Core is to provide expertise, facilities, and equipment to foster and expand vision research at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. This will be accomplished by four Cores. The Vector and Gene Delivery/Quantitative Molecular Biology Core will facilitate the use of gene delivery and molecular biology methods by core users. The Pathology and Imaging Core will facilitate the use of microscopy, histopathology, specialized tissue staining methods, and image analysis by core users. The Animal Models and Eye Organ Culture Core will facilitate the use of non-human primate, feline, rodent and other animal models of ocular disease to assess visual function, and the use of other visual structure and function outcome measures. The Biostatistics and Epidemiology Resource Core will facilitate proper study design and proper data analysis methods for Core users.

PHR: Kara Zivin, PhD, MS, MA serves as a productive Department of Veterans Affairs Health Services Researcher, consistently recognized nationally and internationally as a leader in behavioral health (BH) services research and policy. She demonstrates persistent dedication to improving care for Veterans with BH conditions. Her work aims to enhance clinical and functional outcomes through evaluation of intended and unintended consequences of policies and health system initiatives on overall access to, quality of, and costs of care for those with BH conditions, to mitigate BH provider burnout, and to address gaps and unmet needs for perinatal BH care. The proposed Research Career Scientist Award will support her continued research to promote care for Veterans, as well as an expanded role in service, mentorship, and training early career scientists in the next generation of VHA health services researchers and leaders.

PHR: Project Narrative Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) affects between 10-25% of Veterans and significantly impacts the military, the individual, and society. Several psychotherapies, including cognitive processing therapy (CPT), have been recommended as efficacious for the treatment of PTSD. Yet many individuals show limited benefit from such treatments. There is therefore a urgent need to identify relevant factors that may affect treatment response in PTSD. Accumulating evidence indicates that cognitive deficits adversely affect psychotherapy efficacy in PTSD. However, research is critically needed that examines the pathways by which cognitive functioning affects treatment outcomes to provide an empirical basis for the development of appropriate rehabilitation interventions. The proposed study aims to systematically examine how memory dysfunction affects treatment outcomes during CPT, including memory for treatment, treatment utilization, PTSD symptoms, and functional outcomes, with the goal of guiding development of novel rehabilitation interventions.

PHR: EHS-Net Food Safety Project Narrative Foodborne illness has been, and continues to be, a tremendously important public health problem in Minnesota. Case-control studies have implicated eating at restaurants as a source of nonoutbreak-associated infections with several disease agents (e.g., Salmonella, Campylobacter, and E. coli O157:H7). These studies, along with the substantial burden of foodborne illness outbreaks associated with commercial food establishments, were primary reasons for the formation of the Environmental Health Specialist Network (EHS-Net). Foodborne outbreaks associated with commercial food establishments still occur commonly. In the last 20 years, EHS-Net has made great strides in characterizing and publishing contributing factors and antecedents to foodborne illness in these establishments. The Minnesota Department proposes to synthesize completed EHS-Net work; conduct additional contributing factor and antecedent studies; and, develop, implement, and evaluate intervention studies at commercial food establishments.
PROJECT_TITLE: Environmental Health Specialists Network (EHS-Net) - Practice based research to improve food safety

The proposed study aims at developing a nanomolar activator of SIRT6 and validating its activity in an animal model that is directly relevant to many cardiovascular diseases.
