IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Stroke is the leading cause of motor disability in the United States. Offline processing during sleep can benefit motor performance, but it remains unclear underlying neural mechanisms during sleep-dependent processing in the motor recovery after stroke. This proposal aims to investigate the timing of sleep and underlying neural mechanisms that can optimize the effect of rehabilitation and test whether the stimulation delivered precisely at that timing of sleep can optimize sleep-dependent processing and, thus, enhance motor recovery after sleep.

PHR: Project Narrative Multiple myeloma (MM) is an incurable hematopoietic malignancy that progresses from benign monoclonal gammopathy precursor conditions. Oncogenic mutations in MM are similar to those found in the precursor conditions, and it is not clear what ultimately drives tumorigenesis. Understanding these mechanisms may lead to the development of therapeutic strategies to prevent cancer development in these patients.

PHR: Project Narrative Full exploration of the linkages between biology, biomedical engineering, biophysics, and architecture as well as translation of scientific evidence into clinical practice requires the bridging of disciplines in specific target areas that are central to multidisciplinary science. The Alzheimer?s Disease Clinical and Translational Research (ADCTR) Training Program at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (Rensselaer or RPI) will be dedicated to providing an integrated and multidisciplinary platform to train predoctoral students at the interface of architecture, biology, biophysics, and biomedical engineering focusing on the quantitative linkages that define this interface and preparing trainees for careers in applied sciences and clinical research. Our partners at the Icahn School of Medicine Mount Sinai (ISMMS or Mount Sinai) will be the clinical arm, providing students with field and clinical training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals with rheumatoid arthritis, the most common form of autoimmune inflammatory arthritis affecting at least 1% of the worldwide population, are prone to atherosclerosis, disability from chronic articular inflammation and erosive joint damage, and a diminished lifespan; however, the drivers and mediators of these outcomes are poorly understood. In addition, there are no robust predictors of which RA patients will and will not respond to specific pharmacotherapies. Establishing a mechanistic link between the chronically stressed brain and these high impact outcomes will inform mechanistic follow-up studies, validate the performance of psychosocial questionnaires and biomarkers as proxy measures, and, perhaps most importantly, support the testable concept of stress/anxiety/depression management as a novel area of intervention for reducing articular and systemic inflammation, CVD risk, and increasing the likelihood of treatment response in RA patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many patients with Alzheimer?s disease and related dementias experience unnecessary trips to the hospital. There is a need to create an effective method for clinicians to monitor patient and caregiver wellbeing at home so clinicians can intervene prior to the need for hospital care. To address this need, we will develop and test the prototype of ?Digital Outpost?, the first low-cost, commercially-viable remote patient monitoring platform specifically designed to engage caregivers of patients with ADRD to improve patient and caregiver wellbeing while saving health systems costs and keeping patients in their own home.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREV AND HEALTH PROMO
PHR: Project Narrative The UAB Center for the Study of Community Health supports community-based research, prevention, outreach, and education to enhance community health in Alabama, a Deep South state with significant health disparities beginning early in life that persist across the life course. CHEER will test the independent and combined effects of two system-level interventions to improve health and quality of life among residents of disadvantaged urban communities. Translation and dissemination will inform the development of cost-effective family and community-level interventions with potential for wide dissemination and scalability.
PROJECT_TITLE: CHEER Center for the Study of Community Health

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Periodontal diseases, amongst the most common infections suffered by humans, are caused by oral bacterial species working synergistically to enhance overall pathogenicity. This study aims to understand how the virulence of an asaccharolytic periodontal pathogen, P. gingivalis, is modulated by folate availability. Understanding how asaccharolytic pathogens responds to folate deficiency is critical to development of novel antimicrobial tactics to prevent infections by these organisms.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Understanding diapause and its ability to suspend and preserve life Project Narrative As a natural form of ?suspended animation?, diapause is a dormant state which can suspend embryonic development and preserve life for an extended time without compromising following health and life. However, our knowledge of how diapause works, especially in a more complex vertebrate system, remains limited. Here we study diapause through two complementary angles ? signaling pathways and functioning mechanisms ? using a naturally short-lived African killifish for its remarkable ability for staying in diapause to survive the drought for up to years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative There are currently no curative therapies for glioblastoma (GBM), which is almost universally fatal. Cells within these tumors are governed by the same molecular forces that shape the developing brain, but instead of maturing into adult cell types are stalled indefinitely at progenitor stages. This project asks where and why GBM cells are stuck in their developmental trajectories and attempts to exploit the molecules that normally drive terminal astrocyte differentiation during development in the hopes of maturing, and thus slowing, GBM tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Infectious ailments affect more than 400M people worldwide annually, accounting for almost 30% of disability- adjusted-life-years (DALYs, i.e. number of years lost due to ill-health, disability or early death), and for many of these conditions, bringing affordable diagnosis & effective therapeutic drugs to the point-of-need is key to reducing morbidity and mortality. In this regard, micro-fluidics technology can be used to develop diagnostic tools for pathogen detection that offer quick turnaround, clinically relevant detection limit, & portability, and drug discovery platforms for therapeutic drug synthesis that offer rapid screening, high throughput, & reduced cost. The rising popularity of such technology and its growing demand is driving innovation toward devices that need to exhibit precision, durability, repeatability & reliability, and the proposed stochastic simulation-based technology would support the development of such robust solutions, resulting in safer, more effective biomedical devices that improve public health globally.

PHR: Chronic low back pain (CLBP) is one of the most personally and fiscally costly conditions in the VA. In addition to pain and disability, older Veterans (i.e., those age 65 and older) are vulnerable to serious side effects from exposure to invasive procedures and toxic medications. Often patients with CLBP do not experience relief from the many treatments they receive when these treatments are spine-centered rather than patient-centered. There are many conditions outside of the spine that can cause CLBP and disability such as hip arthritis, fibromyalgia, and depression, but healthcare providers often do not recognize and treat these conditions as part of treating CLBP. We have developed protocols tailored to the needs of older adults for treating important CLBP and disability-causing conditions. The purpose of the proposed clinical trial is to compare the efficacy of Aging Backs Clinics that treat older Veterans with CLBP using these protocols as compared with usual care. The potential for improving outcomes for patients and saving precious healthcare resources is substantial.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deaths linked to the synthetic opioids fentanyl and its derivatives increased over 10-fold between 2013 and 2020; compounding this crisis is the rapidly increasing co-use of opioids and stimulants, particularly methamphetamine and cocaine. The proposed studies will provide a better fundamental understanding of the complex interaction between fentanyl and methamphetamine, and investigate the effectiveness of a new therapeutic approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Narrative: Firearm violence is a significant problem for youth and women in intimate partner relationships with a history of violence. Permit-to-purchase (PTP) laws create robust background check systems to screen out individuals prohibited from owning guns. This proposal seeks to extend our knowledge on the effectiveness of PTP laws by examining their effects on youth violence and intimate partner violence.
PROJECT_TITLE: The Role of Permit-to-Purchase in the Primary Prevention of Multiple Forms of Violence

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Contingency management has successfully increased opioid abstinence and medication adherence in many clinical trials, and buprenorphine is an effective pharmacotherapy in the treatment of opioid use disorder, yet both remain underused as methods to address the opioid epidemic. The purpose of this SBIR fast-track project is to enhance the dissemination of contingency management and increase prescribers? willingness to serve buprenorphine patients by implementing an incentivized collaborative care model that links their practice to a digital health program that features contingency management at its core. If successful, this project will lead to substantially enhanced access to contingency management services and buprenorphine treatment on a national scale.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Significant and persistent disruption to the dynamic gene regulatory process during neurodevelopment through genetic and environmental risks can lead to neural disorders such as Intellectual Disability (ID) or Autism Spectrum Disorders. The goal of this research proposal is to identify the transcriptional regulatory mechanisms by which intrinsic genetic factors and extrinsic environmental factors control post-embryonic neuronal maturation. This work will contribute to a novel understanding of neurodevelopmental disease vulnerability and will inform new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREV AND HEALTH PROMO
PHR: Project Narrative  The Fertility Clinic Success Rate and Certification Act (FCSRCA) of 1992 requires fertility clinics that perform ART procedures (i.e., handling eggs and embryos) in the United States to report pregnancy outcomes to surveillance organizations, such as the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Our research effort will use empirically based human factors engineering and behavior science methods to design and evaluate an ART Provider and Patient Resource to Improve Communication about Outcomes and Treatment (APRICOT). APRICOT will enable fertility clinics to collect pregnancy outcome information efficiently and effectively from prior ART patients and their other healthcare providers.
PROJECT_TITLE: ART Provider and Patient Resource to Improve Communication about Outcomes and Treatment (APRICOT)

PHR: Public Health Relevance Osteoarthritis (OA) is the most common form of arthritis and a major health concern affecting over 30 million in the US, a number expected to rise substantially as the population ages. Gpnmb is a protein known to have anti-inflammatory and chondroprotective properties. The proposed studies will test the anti-inflammatory properties of recombinant and peptide forms of Gpnmb treatment on cartilage homeostasis in post-traumatic (DMM) and age-related OA in vivo. A better understanding of the anti-inflammatory and chondroprotective effects of Gpnmb will be an essential shift in the standard care for the treatment of OA and be helpful in developing new therapeutic strategies to selectively prolong articular cartilage health and function in patients with cartilage deterioration and loss.

PHR: Project Narrative Uganda is a ?hot spot? for emerging infectious diseases (EID) outbreaks - many occurring in border locations with great potential to spill over in the Great Lakes region of Africa. There are key national capacities that require strengthening for the effective neutralization of global health threats. The current proposal seeks to leverage on-going surveillance approaches to generate evidence regarding which components and models are effective in enhancing surveillance of public health threat if international concern.
PROJECT_TITLE: Operational Research for Disease Surveillance Enhancement in Uganda (ORDiSE-U)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: NARRATIVE Of those with Human Immunodeficiency Virus-1/ AIDS (HIV-1) patients, 60% experience sensory neuropathy (HIV-SN), the most common HIV-1-associated neurological disorder worldwide, for which there is no FDA- approved effective treatment. We will study the mechanisms associated with this nociceptor-based chronic pain in a mouse model, to determine the specific pain pathways that govern SN, which we know are different from central nervous mechanism-related pain. Results will form the basis for developing effective treatments for the HIV -SN patients who now must suffer without hope.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inherited retinal degeneration diseases like retinitis pigmentosa (RP) are caused by genetic defects leading to photoreceptor cell loss, irreversible loss of vision and eventual blindness. However, it is unclear how photoreceptors die or how to slow/stop/reverse this process. To better understand the disease mechanism and develop new therapies, we propose to: investigate whether the PARP dependent cell death pathway acts as a common RP mechanism; identify compounds which promote photoreceptor survival in new RP zebrafish model via perform in vivo phenotypic drug screening; and validate identified compounds in established mouse RP models.

PHR: Project Narrative HIV-1-related neuropathic pain affects millions of people, and treatment options are limited and not always effective. The development of new, effective, and safe approaches for pain management is urgently needed. The proposed studies will significantly impact the field of HIV-1- related chronic pain management by providing a new combination therapy, cannabidiol and Beta-caryophyllene, that is effective, safe, nonaddictive, can target chronic pain-related comorbidities (e.g. anxiety and depression), and it will also have a significant impact on the opioid epidemic.

PHR: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is an obesity-related condition that affects 1.3 million Veterans, reduces quality of life, and is associated with greater risk of cardiovascular disease. Despite the potential of weight loss to reverse OSA, real-world impact is limited. Veterans seldom receive weight loss services due to a lack of counseling and poor accessibility of current weight loss offerings. Furthermore, there is uncertainty around the benefits of modest weight loss in achieving meaningful outcomes in OSA. To overcome access and knowledge gaps, this trial will examine the effectiveness of a population health approach to weight loss care among Veterans with OSA. We will use a remote lifestyle-based weight loss intervention that is self-directed, low- technology, and likely low cost. We propose a pragmatic trial of proactively delivering this novel intervention among patients with newly diagnosed OSA. We will test whether such an intervention improves weight and meaningful outcomes including sleep-related quality of life, sleep symptoms, and cardiovascular risk.

ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Postoperative infections are prevalent, affecting up to 40 Veterans each day, and costly, adding upwards of $25,000 per infection to healthcare costs. They are the most common surgical complication, yet, current risk prediction tools still suffer from poor predictive accuracy. We hypothesize that accuracy could be greatly improved by including dynamic postoperative vital sign data. This vital sign data is routinely collected during inpatient stays but some feasibility questions have been raised by our initial needs assessment. We are seeking Pilot funding to perform a developmental formative evaluation that will answer our questions. Using a mixed methods study design, first, we will evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and potential usefulness of a decision support tool for use at hospital discharge. Second, we will examine the completeness of vital sign data and explore the potential biases of using incomplete national Corporate Data Warehouse vital sign data in our model. These results will inform a larger study to develop and test a prototype of our tool.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is the most common liver disease in the U.S. and progresses to liver fibrosis. Hepatic Stellate Cells (HSCs) that normally exhibit a quiescent phenotype (qHSCs) and store Vitamin A, activate into Collagen Type I-expressing aHSCs/myofibroblasts in response to metabolic liver injury to produce the fibrous scar. Phenotypic changes in HSCs occur without a change in the DNA sequence but are regulated on an epigenetic level (e.g. specific modifications in the chromatin structure), characterization of the gene expression and epigenetic changes specific for primary human HSCs isolated from normal, and NASH livers will identify new targets for antifibrotic therapy.

PHR: NARRATIVE Sleep-wake disturbances are associated with important adverse outcomes in older persons, including cognitive and functional decline. These disturbances are under-diagnosed in older persons due to the poor sensitivity of existing sleep questionnaires, the frequent co-occurrence of multiple disturbances, and the burdensome nature of objective sleep testing. We propose to develop and test age-appropriate, comprehensive subjective and objective sleep assessment tools to facilitate identification of older persons with sleep-wake disturbances.

PHR: Project Narrative Cardiovascular diseases have a huge impact on the health of people in the United States, accounting for one in four deaths. These diseases have a significant heritable component to them; however, their genetic architecture is still not completely understood. This project aims to identify and characterize the role of rare coding variants in cardiovascular diseases which are believed to play a large, as-of-yet uncategorized role in disease risk.

PHR: Project Narrative Recent research has proposed that negative food safety culture be considered an emerging risk factor for foodborne illness outbreaks due to its significant impact on outbreaks (Griffith, Livesey, & Clayton, 2010a). SNHD proposes to explore food safety culture as experienced by food handlers and restaurant managers and share findings by creating resources geared toward restaurants. This study aims to foster positive food safety culture which may improve adherence to food safety practices, thereby potentially reducing foodborne illness transmission at the retail food establishment level.
PROJECT_TITLE: SNHD Food Safety Culture

PHR: Project Narrative  Mice have much longer telomeres than humans. While telomere shortening is a key mechanism of human aging, laboratory mice do not exhibit telomere-mediated aging. In this application, we plan to develop a genetically engineered mouse strain with humanized telomere homeostasis. Such mice should become an improved model for studying human aging and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use disorder is a chronic, relapsing condition that imposes serious detrimental physiological and psychological consequences to the afflicted as well as a severe burden on the American taxpayer. The adaptive, dynamic response of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis to stress is impaired following chronic alcohol use, directly underlying the high rates of stress-induced relapse to drinking in abstinent alcoholics. The results of these studies will provide mechanistic insight into sexual dimorphisms involved with maladaptive stress-induced hypothalamic synaptic plasticity following chronic alcohol exposure.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our research project is designed to improve the health and survival of children, adolescent, and adults living with HIV who suffer most from the world?s leading infectious causes of death: tuberculosis (TB) and HIV. Our team is uniquely positioned to develop, implement, and evaluate evidence-based, innovative approaches to prevent, find, and cure HIV-associated TB in five CDC target priority countries. Our research will develop innovative new strategies to improve our ability to FIND and PREVENT TB, while determining the most cost- effective prevention strategy and promoting best practices to SUSTAIN the impact of our work.
PROJECT_TITLE: Closing -TB GAPs - for people living with HIV: TB Guidance for Adaptable Patient-Centered Service

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will demonstrate the feasibility of using existing secondary administrative claims data to further our understanding of clinical and demographic risk factors for Guillain-Barr Syndrome (GBS) onset and identify disparities in GBS testing, treatment, and outcomes. The project is relevant to the mission of the National Institute on Neurological Disorders and Stroke because it focuses on GBS, a rare cause of inflammatory peripheral neuropathy associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Our findings have the potential to inform future research into biological mechanisms of GBS onset, guide improvements in clinical care delivery, and facilitate efforts to find new and better treatments for this rare, but extremely serious condition.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer?s disease is one of the world?s leading public health concerns, but unfortunately, efforts to develop effective treatments for Alzheimer?s disease have been unsuccessful. Here, I propose a novel therapeutic strategy for targeting bioenergetics deficiencies in Alzheimer?s disease, with the goal of mitigating cognitive and psychiatric impairments. Recently, the nuclear receptor REV-ERB?, which regulates circadian rhythm, has been shown to influence cellular bioenergetics, and thus, I hypothesize that pharmacological activation of REV- ERB? may improve bioenergetics and alleviate cognitive impairments in Alzheimer?s disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One in three patients miss follow-up appointments after discharge to the home following childbirth. Missed appointments can contribute to failure to identify life-threatening maternal complications such as stroke, heart failure and postpartum depression, as well as infant complications such as breastfeeding problems and excessive weight loss. In this proposal, we will use systems engineering and industrial design methods to continuously innovate and improve the process of postnatal care.

PROJECT_TITLE: Re-engineering Postnatal Unit Care and the Transition Home to Reduce Perinatal Morbidity and Mortality

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study is a 10- to 15-year post-trial observational follow-up of CALERIE (Comprehensive Assessment of the Long-term Effects of Reducing Intake of Energy), the first randomized controlled trial of calorie restriction (CR) in humans. The CALERIE trial demonstrated that 2 years of CR leads to significant improvements in markers of healthspan and an attenuated rate of biological aging compared to ad libitum intake. With a goal of informing public health strategies that promote healthy aging, the proposed study will examine the legacy effects of the CALERIE trial to determine the effectiveness of CR exposure in early to mid- adulthood in reducing the rate of biological aging and the risk of age-related chronic disease.

PHR: Project Narrative Over the next five years, the Arizona Prevention Research Center will integrate evidence-based strategies across public health and health care delivery systems to expand policy, systems and environmental change efforts designed to create healthy places, and maximize community-clinical linkages to prevent chronic disease and promote health. Our Center activities and public health practice-based evidence research project will address major sources of health disparities in Arizona Latinos and the social determinants of health that contribute to them. Products from our center will lead to Community Health Worker strategies and programs to reduce chronic disease and address social determinants of health that are scalable and sustainable throughout the state and beyond.

PROJECT_TITLE: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Research Centers - 2019

PHR: While diabetic retinopathy (DR) cases are rising globally, and newer treatments are emerging, there is a lack of biomarkers reflecting retinal vascular health. We propose that the RNA levels (mRNA and miRNA) and inflammation in circulating angiogenic cells (CACs) will serve as a biomarker of DR. We will perform RNA sequencing of CACs in DR patients and study how a change in miRNA levels leads to retinopathy using rodent models.

PHR: Project Narrative Levodopa is the primary treatment for Parkinson?s Disease, a neurodegenerative disease that afflicts 1 million Americans. Unfortunately, levodopa has serious side effects and loses its efficacy over time. Using Sinopia Biosciences?s computational drug discovery platform, we identified a small molecule that we subsequently tested and validated in relevant rodent and primate models, providing a unique mechanism for treating Parkinson?s Disease. This proposal will complete preclinical drug development for this compound in order to advance to the clinic.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Peer victimization is a serious problem that is related to detrimental behavioral, social, and emotional adjustment for youth, including aggression and substance use. Although most research on the topic has focused on marginalized victims (i.e., those with low social status), growing evidence suggests that high-status youth are also at risk for victimization which is troubling as high-status youth are already more likely to be aggressive and to engage in substance use. The proposed project will have significant public health implications by elucidating circumstances under which victimization and social status predict health-risk behavior and maladjustment for adolescents.

IC_NAME: National Center for HIV/AIDS, Viral Hepatitis, STD, and TB Prevention (NCHHSTP)
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Men who have sex with men (MSM), especially young Black and Latino MSM, have the highest rates of HIV diagnoses in the United States. The goal of the proposed Type II Hybrid Study is to improve pre-exposure prophylaxis screening, counseling, initiation, adherence, and persistence in young Black and Latino MSM in two high-priority settings.
PROJECT_TITLE: mChoice: Improving PrEP Uptake and Adherence among Minority MSM through Tailored Provider Training and Adherence Assistance in Two High Priority Settings

ORG_NAME: US HELPING US, PEOPLE INTO LIVING, INC.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Stark racial disparities in HIV prevalence and incidence continue to persist among sexual minority men (SMM), especially Black SMM aged 18 years and above and the extremely high risk of HIV among young Black SMM portends further devastation unless primary prevention efforts among this population become much more successful. Although social network interventions have been understudied, there is growing empirical evidence of moderately high increases in PrEP initiation among Black SMM via social networking strategies (SNS). The proposed ground-breaking research has strong public health significance as it applies an innovative SNS model that leverages the existing social networks of Black SMM while harnessing qualitative data that elucidate ?bright spots? of primary HIV prevention efforts to increase PrEP initiation among Black SMM.

IC_NAME: National Center for Complementary & Integrative Health
PHR: Project Narrative: Mindfulness-based interventions like MBCT and MBSR may provide additional treatment options for acute hard-to-treat psychiatric conditions including treatment-resistant depression, GAD, and PTSD. However, the specific therapeutic mechanisms underlying MBCT/MBSR are not well understood, nor is it known whether these are shared with other therapies, or provide novel and potentially complimentary treatment components that can be used in combination. Elucidating MBCT mechanisms can enhance ongoing refinement and optimal targeting of psychotherapy interventions for PTSD and other acute psychiatric disorders.
PROJECT_TITLE: Neural Mechanisms of Mindfulness-based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) for Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite many years of research and development, only four cholinesterase inhibitors and memantine have been approved by the FDA for the treatment of Alzheimer?s disease (AD). Recent reports have implicated necroptosis, a form of cell death, to be activated in human (AD) brains and we have developed a novel approach to target the protein-protein interactions involved in necroptosis without affecting their other crucial functions. The purpose of this grant is to develop novel molecules that target proteins involved in necroptosis and to test them in human AD patient derived induced pluripotent stem cells.

PHR: Project Narrative Photoreceptors are the main detectors of light that relay visual information to the brain. This proposal investigates the key molecular interactions that mediate selective wiring of photoreceptors to their respective synaptic targets. The long-term goal of this research is to uncover the molecular basis of retinal wiring in order to devise new forms of therapies to treat and restore vision.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative This study will assess trends in health system ownership of physician organizations (POs) that serve patients with low socioeconomic status (SES) and the impact of health system ownership on SES disparities in access to care and quality of care in a national sample of POs. To identify mechanisms through which SES disparities change following PO ownership conversions, we will use both a decomposition analysis and a qualitative analysis of primary data collected from 30 POs that have achieved reductions in SES disparities and 30 community-based organizations and providers that partner with these POs. This study will determine the benefits or unintended consequences for vulnerable populations of PO ownership by health systems, the role of physician market concentration and other market characteristics in explaining trends in SES disparities, and the specific strategies that POs are using to address social determinants of health and reduce SES disparities.
PROJECT_TITLE: Integrated health systems, market concentration, and socioeconomic disparities in quality of care

PHR: Environmental pollutants as well as plant, microbial and host-derived products can bind to aryl hydrocarbon receptors (AhR). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health as it develops innovative, holistic strategies to improve functional and patient-reported outcomes after one of the most common surgical procedures in the United States, ventral hernia repair. This paradigm shift highlights the inter-relatedness of the abdominal wall, lower back, diaphragm, and pelvic floor, which contribute to activities of daily living and quality of life and can be modulated by physical therapy. This will lead to significant advances in therapy for ventral hernia and other abdominal core related diseases which is directly relevant to the part of the NIH?s mission that concerns reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Narrative: By 12th grade, 10% of youth have been victims of sexual violence and much of this violence was committed by their adolescent peers. The SUSI campaign, a social marketing campaign to promote social norms that protect against sexual bullying and violence, has been funded by CDC's RPE program and implemented in Georgia High-Schools since 2014. The purpose of this project is to conduct formative and summative evaluation of the SUSI campaign's impact on sexual violence among high-school students, including sexual and gender minority youth.
PROJECT_TITLE: Effectiveness Evaluation of `Step Up Step In? (SUSI): A Campaign to Promote Social Norms against Sexual Violence

PHR: Project Narrative The AVRC P30 Core facility serves as a centralized vision research resource in Atlanta where faculty from Emory University, Georgia Institute of Technology, Georgia State University, Morehouse School of Medicine, and The Atlanta Veterans Administration Medical Center can undertake joint studies in vision research. The P30 Core facilitates the research of investigators holding NEI R01 grants by providing access to equipment and services that would not be possible on individual R01 grants. The P30 Core also promotes the research projects of pre- and postdoctoral fellows supported by our NEI Training Grant (T32 EY007092-34), recently renewed for five years (2020-2025) and buttresses active recruitment of new tenure-track research faculty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative CLC-2 is a transmembrane ?ion channel? that facilitates movement of chloride, the most abundant negatively charged ion in the human body. Chloride movement through CLC-2 generates electrical signals throughout the brain, but exactly how this influences brain activity is not yet well understood. This project aims to understand the molecular structure of CLC-2 at high resolution, in the presence and absence of a small-molecule chemical probe that can be used to study CLC-2 function in the brain.

PHR: Public health relevance: Opioid addiction has grown into a major epidemic in the United States, as individuals addicted to opioids, including heroin, face great difficulty in suppressing their drive to consume the drug, even long after their previous use of their drug. The proposed studies will focus on understanding those neural systems that underlie the suppression and inhibition of heroin seeking. The findings of this work may have significant future benefit in the creation of better treatments that strengthen the ability to inhibit heroin use.

PHR: Project Narrative This proposal outlines a plan to develop the technology for measuring the Optoretinogram, or ORG: the all- optical recording of functional activity of retinal neurons and their connections in a living eye. We employ a unique combination of technologies (OCT, adaptive optics, interferometry, eye-tracking) that together enable in vivo access to the early visual processing elements in the retina in humans. In the end, we envision powerful, clinically deployable tools suited to test and accelerate the new generation of treatments aimed at regenerating neurons and neural connections in the eye and visual system.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  How the behaviors or experiences of one?s grandparents might affect our own health is not clear, but examples of the influence of transgenerational inheritance on metabolism, longevity, and even behavior have been documented in several model systems, and is surmised to exist in humans; furthermore, trans-kingdom signaling between bacteria and host cells might play a role in influencing behavior and transgenerational inheritance. We found that C. elegans can ?read? the identity of bacteria through the bacteria?s own small RNAs, and subsequently use that information to influence behavior, avoiding the pathogen and passing this information on to four generations of progeny ? and it may have co-opted a genomic ?parasite,? a retrotransposon, to do so. We propose to use this system to identify the molecular regulators of the process, and to understand the logic of the system and its evolution.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Leveraging electronic health record data from a large cohort of PrEP patients, the proposed study will identify latent classes of PrEP persistence among patients with substance use. Findings will identify latent subgroups at increased risk for poor PrEP outcomes and the characteristics that predict problematic patterns of PrEP use. These results will inform the development of differentiated behavioral interventions to support sustained PrEP use in substance-using populations who are at increased risk for HIV and for falling out of PrEP care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative For a gene to function properly, it must be active in the right place, at the right time and in the right amount. Changes in any of these features can lead to disease. This proposal uses mathematical theory and experiment to understand how information about the appropriate place, time and amount of gene activity is encoded in the genome, to help determine the causes of disease directly from DNA sequence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Narrative Firearms-related injuries are a leading cause of pediatric morbidity and mortality in our country. This project will develop and then evaluate a website designed to teach children how to engage safely with firearms. Results will have significant implications for improving public health by reducing unintentional pediatric firearms-related injuries and deaths.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The GenitoUrinary Development Molecular Anatomy Project (GUDMAP) has been instrumental to research on urogenital development and diseases. Our proposed work will greatly enhance the current GUDMAP database by targeting structures and organs that have not been covered, as well as by extending into building spatially resolved high complexity molecular atlases. Our application of single cell omics, spatial transcriptomics, multiplex imaging, light sheet microscopy, and advanced computational multi-dimensional atlas building will also help to elevate GUDMAP to a higher level with unprecedented coverage and resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The breakdown of immune tolerance mechanisms, including regulatory T cells, in rheumatoid arthritis leads to the proliferation and aberrant activation of autoreactive pro-inflammatory T cells that contribute to disease progression. The proposed research will develop immunomodulatory biomaterials capable of providing sustained, localized presentation of immunomodulatory cues and examine how these materials may be used to rebalance and enhance key T cell subsets to restore immune homeostasis in murine. This work will result in biocompatible tools to locally control T cell differentiation and function, and apply these tools to provide critical information on how altered function of regulatory T cells impacts the development of autoimmune arthritis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Since their discovery almost 50 years ago how opioid receptors facilitate the development of dependence and withdrawal at a circuit level is still not known. To address this question, we will chart the global cell-type identity, shifting connectivity, and ensemble activity of opioidergic networks by examining brains throughout various stages of addiction. By leveraging cutting-edge neuroscience technologies, we will map and profile neuronal ensembles and cell-types that mediate opioid action in the rodent brain.

ORG_NAME: BUCK INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH ON AGING
PHR: OVERALL TMC - PROJECT NARRATIVE  Many stressors, including aging, can cause cells can enter a state termed senescence. Senescent cells are likely important drivers of many age-related pathologies, from neurodegeneration to cancer, but are poorly characterized. Within the SenNet Consortium, we will establish a Tissue Mapping Center to characterize senescent cells -- molecularly, spatially and during aging -- in three very different human tissues: ovary, breast and skeletal muscle.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ocular inflammatory disease represents an important and disproportionate cause of visual morbidity, yet real- world data to inform appropriate health policy regarding disparities in its development, progression, treatment patterns, and economics are lacking. Indeed, the restricted scope of prior case series and population studies render the epidemiology of uveitis to be poorly understood, particularly for vulnerable populations in the healthcare safety net setting. This project seeks to leverage the strengths of two unique databases, a national medical claims database and electronic medical record data from our local healthcare safety net, which contain large and diverse cohorts of patients, to explore health disparities in the development, progression, and treatment of ocular inflammatory diseases ? a foundational step in innovating targeted interventions to mitigate these disparities.

PHR: One of the foundations of rehabilitation is to assist patients in achieving the outcomes that matter most to them. In the context of the dysvascular amputee, the choice of amputation level profoundly affects many key outcomes. When peripheral vascular disease or diabetic foot ulceration necessitates an amputation at either the transmetatarsal or transtibial level, current clinical practice does not have the tools available to inform the surgeon about the probable patient specific outcomes at each amputation level, nor the tools to help patients make a decision that helps them achieve their outcome preferences. The proposed research will lead to the development of a patient decision aid and a decision support tool that will inform Veterans and their surgeons about anticipated outcomes and enable them to make an amputation level decision that will allow patients to achieve the functional outcomes that best meet their goals and priorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Sensory hair cells in the inner ears of mammals are responsible for hearing by converting vibrations in the air into nerve impulses, which are interpreted as sound; when these cells are damaged or killed, they do not regrow, causing permanent hearing loss. Our proposed research plan will examine the sensory hair cells of zebrafish, which are very similar to the hair cells of mammals, but quickly regenerate after they are killed to restore function. We will study the complex genetic interactions and processes that regulate genes involved in hair cell regeneration in zebrafish, in order to learn about why hair cells of mammals do not regenerate and provide clues to help eventually restore hearing.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed studies of the visual experience of infants are relevant to public health because impaired vision and visual learning have long term consequences across many domains of a healthy and successful life. Disrupted visual experience in infancy is evident in the continued risk in perceptual, cognitive and school achievements and is implicated in the nexus of disrupted visual learning and motor development of children with more general developmental disorders. Determining the expected and normative early visual input in infancy and its links to infant eye- movements and behaviors is expected to give rise to new diagnostics and behavioral interventions for at-risk infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public Health Relevance: Periodontitis, a common oral inflammatory disease, which affects ~10% of the global population and ~50% of Americans aged >30 years, has been associated with increased risk for extra-oral systemic diseases such as diabetes, cardiovascular disease, inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, preterm birth, and osteoporosis. This project aims to understand the molecular mechanisms governing periodontitis disease process and the potential causal role of periodontitis and associated oral bacteria in inflammatory bowel disease. Successful completion of this study will not only provide mechanistic insights into the pathogenic contribution of periodontitis to inflammatory bowel disease but will also help in developing targeted therapies for periodontitis and inflammatory bowel disease, thereby leading to personalized medicine approach to improve both oral health and systemic health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal will identify and characterize the posttranslational modifications (PTMs) of the proteome of emerging viruses (the `viral PTMome') as well as the modifying enzymes that control viral PTMs and thereby virus replication and pathogenesis. We will use an integrative approach that combines proteomics and gene-targeting screens with molecular, biochemical, and virus infection studies to address fundamental unanswered questions in virology, which will spur entirely new lines of treatment for a range of infectious diseases that represent public health threats.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it seeks to establish the efficacy of an innovative and scalable intervention to addresses two prevalent and debilitating conditions, falls and urinary incontinence, which together affect 1 in 2 older adult women. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will generate new tools to study alternative splicing and expression of Homer1a, a dominant negative post-synaptic scaffolding molecule with important functions in synaptic regulation. One splice variant, called Homer1a, exhibits regulated expression and disrupts Homer scaffolds as a dominant negative variant. We will generate a transgenic mouse in which Homer1a is tagged with a green ?uorescent protein, and the long scaffolding forms of Homer encoded by the same gene will be tagged with a red ?uorophore to allow for tracking of the time course, sub cellular distribution, and the ratio of the two isoforms under various conditions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because if focuses on understanding the links between air pollution and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and whether inflammation plays a role in this connection. Once such information is obtained, there is the potential for ALS prevention efforts, new therapeutic targets, and blood-based biomarkers for use in clinical studies. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of The National ALS Registry?s mission that pertains to understand environmental risk factors of ALS.
PROJECT_TITLE: Linking long-term air pollution exposure with inflammation, ALS risk, and disease progression

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Men in the United States have an exceptionally high prevalence of overweight and obesity, but are dramatically underrepresented in weight loss programs because they find them unappealing. This project evaluates engagement in and efficacy of a novel, game-based mobile weight loss program designed to be appealing to men. The program is designed to be especially effective and engaging because it features both gamification features known to enhance enjoyment and motivation and facilitate desired behaviors and neurotraining in basic brain capacities needed to resist impulses to eat tempting foods.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: NORTH AMERICAN PRIMARY CARE RES GROUP
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of the proposed national Practice-Based Research Network (PBRN) conferences to be convened annually from 2020 through 2022 is to enhance the skills and knowledge of clinicians and researchers in evidence-based research in order to reform the health of the U.S. population and the quality of the primary health care they receive. The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) conference grant to support these PBRN meetings will facilitate AHRQ in achieving its mission to generate evidence that will make health care safer, higher quality, more accessible, equitable and affordable----especially primary care practice?by promoting collaboration among conference attendees and partners to disseminate research design, quality improvement, positive outcomes, innovations and results and ultimately transforming the delivery of primary care health care. Through this conference, the intent is to ensure the produced evidence is understood and used among clinicians and researchers.
PROJECT_TITLE: National Practice-Based Research Network Conferences 2020 to 2022

PHR: Project Narrative Focused ultrasound can noninvasively excite or suppress neural activity and is uniquely positioned to transform current neurotherapeutic paradigms for curbing opioid use and misuse, particularly for neuropathic pain where high efficacy of treatment over placebo has yet to be shown. However, a central challenge for developing ultrasound-based neuropathic pain therapies is the lack of adequate tools for robust study of dorsal root ganglion filtering under focused ultrasound sonication. This research proposal leverages ultrasound neurostimulation technology and electrophysiological tools to engineer novel ex vivo and in vivo systems for the study of the effect of ultrasound on dorsal root ganglion excitability and neuropathic pain conditions.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative The LHS-K12 Program is targeted towards junior faculty who have previously obtained a clinical or research doctoral degree. The purpose of the LHS-K12 program is to equip Scholars with the unique skill set required to conduct research within the learning health system by capitalizing on already available educational opportunities within our organization, while also creating new opportunities in educational domains where gaps exist. Additionally, we believe the LHS-K12 program is the first step in helping us change the culture within our organizations to one that values the integration of research, clinical care, and quality improvement to improve our ability to develop, implement, test, and disseminate innovative and transformative solutions for health care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Brain tumors have surpassed the leukemias as the leading cause of cancer-related death in children. Therapeutic options for pediatric brain cancers have shown little expansion over the past few decades and the prognosis for many tumor types (especially high-grade gliomas) remains bleak. The research proposed here will identify tumor-associated contacts with the brain microenvironment that guide cellular state transitions, account for tumor grade and can be weaponized to therapeutic ends.

PHR: This project builds on a growing body of evidence that supports an association between periodontitis and Alzheimer?s disease (AD) and related dementias (ADRD). By assessing clinical and microbial features of periodontitis in a longitudinal manner, along with key elements of the inflammatory response, within an established, rigorously developed diverse community-based aging study in Northern Manhattan, we have the unique opportunity to investigate a potentially causal association between periodontitis and incident ADRD, assessed through a comprehensive battery of neuropsychological tests, as well as through established neuroimaging and fluid biomarkers of AD. Given that a substantial proportion of AD cases occurs in the absence of established risk factors other than aging, and that periodontitis is largely preventable and treatable, identification of a novel, modifiable risk factor for AD would be extremely valuable from a public health standpoint and would influence the design of early intervention strategies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gastroparesis is a chronic gastrointestinal motility disorder with no cure, which causes significant burden to patients and the healthcare system. The proposed research aims to identify the cellular mechanisms underlying this disease, by focusing our analysis on immune cells residing in the human stomach. Knowledge from this research is likely to result in the identification of novel cellular pathways that can be targeted therapeutically to treat, reduce symptoms, and cure gastroparesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: This project will identify which Medicaid enrollees are at highest risk for stimulant overdose, and when they are at highest risk. The study?s results will provide generalizable knowledge about individual-level and social factors that predispose to or protect against stimulant overdose. Such factors can be the targets of intervention at the national, state, county, and local levels to ameliorate the effects of these causes, as well serve as the basis of future research to better understand the underlying causal mechanisms. The results can also be used pragmatically to identify high-risk individuals for the purpose of targeting scarce resources for evidence-based approaches to overdose prevention.
PROJECT_TITLE: Stimulant Overdose in the Medicaid Population: Who is at Risk, and When are They at Risk

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public Health Relevance Statement: Treatment of pain remains a major unmet need. Opiates continue to be useful pharmacotherapy for treatment of moderate to chronic pain but suffer from severe side effects that has led to an epidemic in America. The development of safe, effective and well tolerated pain medications without side-effects based on peripheral CB1 receptors will be a major advancement in the treatment of pain that would greatly enhance both quality and length of life of patients both in the US and worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Polycystic kidney disease is a chronic, progressive disease in which the kidney accumulates cysts and loses its ability to properly filter blood. Proteins that localize to the primary cilia are known to inhibit kidney cyst formation, but the pathway that drives this cyst formation remains unknown. In this research proposal, we will use a novel mouse model to define the ciliary signaling that drives renal cyst formation potentially revealing new therapeutic targets for polycystic kidney disease.

PHR: Narrative:  Vision loss exacts an enormous toll on individuals and on society, and progress has been slow in developing therapies for restoring vision in the blind. To greatly reduce the time required to develop effective cures for blindness, we have a new way of imaging the retina that can provide information about whether retinal cells benefit from new therapeutic approaches. This novel functional imaging technique will be applied to evaluate photoreceptor replacement therapy in the fovea, the area of the retina that mediates high quality vision. Success in restoring vision at this location will provide strong evidence that this type of therapy could restore usable vision in patients and regenerative therapies should move rapidly into clinical trials.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Project Narrative Community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) is a leading cause of hospitalization and inpatient antimicrobial use in the United States. However, diagnostic uncertainty at the time of initial treatment and following negative cultures is associated with prolonged exposure to broad-spectrum antimicrobials. We propose a large multicenter cluster randomized controlled trial to test two approaches to reducing the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics in adult patients with CAP a) routine use of rapid diagnostic testing at the time of admission and b) pharmacist-led de-escalation after 48 hours for clinically stable patients with negative cultures.
PROJECT_TITLE: Reducing Antimicrobial Overuse Through Targeted Therapy for Patients with Community-Acquired Pneumonia

PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to develop a new clinical imaging modality, referred to as visible-light optical coherence tomography (vis-OCT), to improve the clinical care of glaucoma. The new vis-OCT clinical modality will offer the highest resolution and new functional imaging capabilities to grade the earliest glaucoma damages that are unable to be detected currently.

PHR: Project Narrative Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection has been correlated with the development of childhood asthma; however, the mechanisms for this phenomenon have not yet been elucidated. In this project, I plan to evaluate the effects that RSV has on the developing lung that may be driving increased susceptibility to asthma during early life. By identifying the cells and structural alterations involved in these mechanisms, it may be possible to alter the response to RSV and decrease subsequent development of asthma.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE OF THE APPLICATION The GDPM would like to propose a Project for 5 year with two research proposals for the first year that will expand upon EBS implementation and the nationwide survey on sero-prevalence of hepatitis B and C, including: (1) Determining best implementation practices of nation-wide scale up of EBS surveillance of infectious diseases, and (2) Molecular Epidemiology of Blood-Borne Hepatitis Viruses in Viet Nam, 2018. The research aim at: 1) Use lessons learned from the EBS mixed methods evaluation interventions to improve EBS implementation in Vietnam; and, 2) Provide the necessary database for policy making and action plan development on viral hepatitis prevention and control, as well as diagnosis and management of patients in curative facilities, respectively. The Projects will help Viet Nam in advancing infectious disease detection and response, and further tighten the Viet Nam MOH - USCDC cooperation. Advancing Infectious Disease Detection and Response in Viet Nam Page 1 RFA-GH-19-009
PROJECT_TITLE: Advancing Infectious Disease Detection and Response in Viet Nam

PHR: Project Narrative Non-healing corneal wounds are a challenging condition with limited treatment options that can lead to significant loss of vision. We are proposing a trial to test a promising new treatment using stem cell derived factors to use as an eye drop to accelerate wound healing in these settings. This trial will specifically test the safety and early efficacy of this treatment and help bring this promising approach to the clinic for corneal diseases and potentially other conditions.

ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: There is large body of evidence demonstrating that aerobic exercise effectively improves many outcomes relevant to Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) including; anxiety, depression, insomnia, and cognition. Recognizing the promise of exercise as a rehabilitation strategy for helping veterans with PTSD, a team of investigators developed an exercise intervention 12 weeks in duration, integrating a combination of aerobic and strength training with concentration training based on mindful breathing techniques. The initial pilot study demonstrates the strong potential of Integrative Exercise for improving overall quality of life, sleep quality, cardiovascular fitness, and PTSD symptoms. This proposal is to conduct a definitive efficacy study of Integrative Exercise versus an active health education control condition: Illness Management and Recovery (IMR). The overall goal is to determine if integrative exercise is effective rehabilitation intervention for combat veterans with PTSD.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Increasing trends in infectious diseases now highlighted with the COVID-19 pandemic demonstrate the need for a robust public health surveillance structure bolstered by health information technology (HIT). The project objectives are to evaluate interoperability approaches for electronic vaccination data exchange between HIT systems for infectious disease surveillance, vaccinations, and electronic health records (EHRs). The project results will guide future electronic data exchanges, and learnings will improve processes to enhance the surveillance of infectious diseases with overarching goal of better healthcare quality.
PROJECT_TITLE: Advancing Population and Public health Reporting and Outcomes with Vaccination data Exchange (APPROVE)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative: Epilepsy is characterized by recurrent seizures and is frequently resistant to antiepileptic drugs. This new proposal focusses on the design of a novel neurotechnology to control seizures based on the new finding that the neuro electric field plays a crucial role in the generation propagation of seizures electric field coupling.

ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: There is increasing recognition that social determinants of health (SDHs)?personal circumstances and environmental factors that shape an individual?s daily life?contribute to meaningful variation in clinical and economic outcomes. Systematic procedures for assessing and addressing SDHs in health care settings could improve prevention and treatment efforts. In order for the Veterans Affairs (VA) system to achieve this goal, there is a need to evaluate the impact of SDHs in Veterans to determine the best candidates for integration into the electronic health record. The proposed study will leverage national surveys of the general VA population and Veterans at high-risk for hospitalization to identify SDH factors associated with health care utilization, cost, community bed days, and patient experience outcomes. We will partner with VA leadership, clinicians, patients, and caregivers, to prioritize SDHs that are actionable (i.e., addressable through VA or community services) and develop recommendations for SDH measure screening procedures and electronic health record integration.

PHR: Nearly 60-85% of Veterans with amputations experience life-limiting pain at the location of the amputated limb called phantom limb pain (PLP). This type of pain, is a major problem with few treatment options. PLP has profound impact on Veteran?s daily function and ability to fully participate in life. Veterans with amputations have unique, unmet needs given additional co- morbidities. Although several rehabilitation interventions are promising, advances in designing novel rehabilitation interventions has been limited because we don?t have a full understanding of the underpinnings of PLP in the unique Veteran population. The objective of this project is to 1) develop and test a comprehensive pain evaluation that encompasses advanced neuroimaging and patient-reported outcomes. This project will ultimately lead to a future CDA-2 proposal testing non-pharmacological interventions (non-invasive brain stimulation + mirror therapy).

PHR: The overall impact goal of the Optimizing Function and Independence QUERI program (?Function QUERI?) is to improve VA care by implementing and evaluating evidence-based clinical programs (EBPs) to maximize function and independence in vulnerable Veterans. Function QUERI will achieve an immediate impact on care by expanding access to three EBPs: group physical therapy for knee osteoarthritis (Group PT), supervised walking for hospitalized older adults (STRIDE) and caregiver skills training (Caregivers FIRST). Long-term impacts will be to enhance VA?s capacity to rapidly adopt evidence-based practices through advancing understanding of how to scale proven implementation strategies for national dissemination efforts and building VA?s implementation capacity and workforce.

PHR: Contact PD/PI: Calvert, Peter Deane PROJECT NARRATIVE This work seeks to understand the molecular mechanisms of retinal photoreceptor protein compartmentalization. Retinal degeneration and blindness may be caused by improper delivery of proteins to specialized regions within photoreceptors, the light detecting cells in our eyes. Understanding the mechanisms that control photoreceptor construction, and what goes wrong with this process in blinding diseases, will help find new therapies to extend or restore vision. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Backwards lymph flow in the intestine and mesentery may underlie protein-losing enteropathy (PLE). Here, we will apply a novel approach to functionally image and quantify lymphatic transport from the gut to the lymphovenous valve to better understand the role of lymphatics in PLE. We will evaluate a ?2-hit? hypothesis that (1) impaired lymphatic flow and (2) inflammatory loss of valve integrity combine to drive clinically significant PLE.

PHR: Project Narrative: Although effective treatments are available for neovascular AMD, no treatments have been proven to prevent the onset or progression of geographic atrophy. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it aims to understand to molecular mechanism of photoreceptor degeneration that occurs in advanced form of this disease. Understanding molecular mechanism will improve understanding of the pathogenesis of dry AMD and it would certainly provide a powerful avenue for development of novel therapeutic strategies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) in its late forms, ?dry? or ?wet?, is the leading cause of blindness in developed countries. Early intervention and therapy can significantly reduce the progression of early to late AMD. Hence, the identification of patients with early AMD and referral to an ophthalmologist is critically needed to help prevent vision loss. To achieve this goal, we propose to develop an automated screening and prediction system that can be widely deployed to identify these individuals at risk of vision loss.

PHR: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic disease that causes swelling, or inflammation, and cell death in the brain and spinal cord. Blood vessel damage in the brain is important in both active inflammation and neuron death in MS. In addition, people with MS with vascular disease comorbidities, like high blood pressure and high cholesterol, have more disability. Over time, this death of neurons leads to limitations in patient participation and health-related quality of life. This study explores the relationship between blood vessel disease in the brain, neuron death, and clinical limitations in MS. We will follow people with MS with and without vascular disease comorbidities for 2 years to study how clinical performance and brain imaging changes across time. My long-term goal is to develop and study treatments that address MS-related blood vessel disease in order to protect the brain against cell death and ultimately improve the lives of Veterans living with MS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Rates of opioid and methamphetamine-related harms (including overdose death) have increased dramatically in recent years. Nevada (NV) and New Mexico (NM) are two Mountain West states that have been disproportionately burdened by the opioid epidemic and also have high rates of MA use. We propose a multi- site mixed methods study in NM and NV to identify risk and protective factors for MA use and related harms, and identify promising prevention, treatment, and harm reduction strategy to reduce MA-related harm in the context of an entrenched and ongoing opioid overdose epidemic.
PROJECT_TITLE: A Multi-Site Mixed Methods Study of Methamphetamine Use in the Mountain West

PHR: Severe loss of vision occurs due to dry age-related macular degeneration (dry-AMD) in millions of individuals and there is neither a cure that can stop the degeneration nor a therapy that can restore vision lost due to the retinal degeneration. Success of this proposal will lead to new clinical approach for treating dry-AMD patients by conventional intravitreal injection of viral vector carried multi-characteristic opsin (vMCO). This gene-agnostic approach will allow treatment of other retinal degenerative diseases such as retinitis pigmentosa, Stargardt and cone-rod dystrophy.

PHR: Project Narrative This study provides foundational work towards the development of Alzheimer?s disease (AD) risk screening biomarkers in the human retina that can be applied at the population level to identify those who are at the earliest pathologic stages of AD, prior to the onset of clinical symptoms. The retina can serve as a non-invasive ?window to the brain? that can be imaged using standard optometry and ophthalmology techniques, allowing for screening for AD risk at routine eye exams in older adults, and subsequent referral for more extensive AD risk evaluation using more invasive techniques at specialty clinics. The outcome of this research is expected to facilitate the design of a longitudinal cohort study of retinal biomarker changes in AD, which will determine which retinal biomarkers are sensitive and specific at each stage of AD.

PHR: DOE: Project Narrative The Tony Mazzocchi Center (TMC) will conduct 1,430 workshops that will reach 28,900 DOE site workers, Tribal members and community residents with 355,200 hours of training over the proposed five-year grant from 2020-2025. To meet our training goals, TMC has direct access to 3,742 USW and CWA members employed at DOE sites; to other employees located at 12 DOE Nuclear Weapons Complex sites; and to community stakeholders including Native American Tribe members, local vocational schools, fire departments, and community organizations. We will conduct required HAZWOPER courses as well as a range of other classes, including radiation worker safety, industrial hygiene training, OSHA outreach training, accident investigation training, effective health and safety committee training, and disaster response training, including response to disasters related to climate change.

Dr. Edwards is one of the Principal Investigators of EPPIC-Net?s Clinical Coordinating Center (CCC), which works to promote and facilitate clinical trials of non-opioid treatments for pain. This K24 application would allow Dr. Edwards to devote more time to patient-oriented research and mentoring under the EPPIC-Net umbrella. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The lack of cultural diversity in biomedical research exacerbates health disparities and increases biases experienced by these communities. This ultimately fuels the lack of generalizability of medical and behavioral interventions related to Alzheimer Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD). This project aims to establish a novel approach by creating and evaluating a research registry to recruit, enroll, and retain under-resourced diverse communities into an ADRD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use in pregnant women has increased over the past decade, highlighting the importance of efforts to understand how environmental and other exposures during pregnancy affect brain development and child outcomes. The PRELUDE consortium for the HEALthy Brain and Child Development study will recruit 2720 pregnant women in the 2nd and 3rd trimester and follow their children to age 10, using neuroimaging, behavioral assessments, EEG, biosample collection, and assessments of parent-child interaction and the home environment. This research will lead to greater understanding of factors affecting early childhood brain development, allowing targeted interventions and improved outcomes for mother-child dyads.

PHR: Antibiotic-resistant bacteria such as methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) increase patient morbidity and mortality. Thus, they are an important public health concern. MRSA infections are responsible for over 100,000 U.S. hospitalizations each year and cause more deaths each year than human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. Patients with MRSA infections have a two-fold higher risk of death compared to patients with susceptible infections. The use of gloves and gowns/contact precautions by healthcare workers aims to prevent patients from acquiring MRSA infections from other patients. However, tremendous controversy exists about the pros and cons of contact precautions. The proposed work will lead to a greater understanding of the factors associated with transmission of these bacteria and more cost-effective use of gloves and gowns/contact precautions to prevent the transmission of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) are two devastating and fatal neurodegenerative disorders that are clinically distinct but show an overlap in genetic factors and central nervous system (CNS) neuropathology in the form of cytoplasmic TDP-43 depositions, but the mechanistic basis of their shared and distinct circuitry remains unknown at the molecular level, preventing the identification of needed therapeutic targets. Here, we use single-cell high-resolution profiling of epigenomic and transcriptional alterations in post-mortem CNS samples from ALS and FTLD with motor neuron disease (FTLD/MND) patients to elucidate their underlying mechanism of action, shed light on their common and distinct circuitry, and identify genetic and cellular factors that drive TDP-43 neuropathology and corresponding neurotoxicity, using patient derived cells and in vivo model systems. This ambitious proposal has the potential to (a) provide mechanistic insights into the development of ALS and FTLD/MND, (b) identify genetic modifiers of TDP-43 pathobiology, and (c) reveal functional risk variants and target genes for therapeutic intervention using gene modifying therapies.

PHR: Diseases of the retina are significant human health problems that impact numerous individuals with reduced vision or blindness. The proposed studies focus on understanding the molecular mechanisms that control the formation of retinal cells in mammals. This information should expand our knowledge of retinal development and may provide insights into diseases of the retina, as well as aid in the development of rational interventions for the treatment of retinal diseases or injuries.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ability to visualize synapses in the brains of living individuals (i.e., in vivo) has recently become possible with the availability of a radiotracer that binds to a protein present on synaptic vesicles. We have shown that young adults with cannabis use disorder have lower hippocampal synaptic density and worse memory, however, whether similar alterations in hippocampal synaptic density occurs in cannabis-using older adults is not known. The goal of this study is to use brain imaging to determine whether there are changes in synaptic vesicle density and memory among cannabis-using older adults.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Controversy exists over the risk to benefit ratio of medical marijuana for adults with chronic non-cancer pain (CNCP) on chronic opioid therapy (COT). The primary goal of this proposal is to assess whether medical marijuana, when added to a behavioral prescription opioid taper support program, improves pain and reduces opioid dose in adults on COT for CNCP more so than the behavioral intervention alone. This information is critical to better inform patients and clinicians about the extent to which medical marijuana use may be beneficial or harmful to this patient population.

ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Our ultimate goal is to create an alkaline fuel cell that uses sugars in the blood as a renewable power source for implantable and wearable medical devices. We envision our bio-harvester connected as a shunt across the arterial/venous blood supply like how Gore-Tex inserts are used to create an AV fistula for dialysis patients. Blood would flow through a dialysis-like membrane harvester that harvests glucose (aka blood sugar) molecules in the blood stream. These sugar molecules would be the fuel source for an alkaline fuel cell. External circuits with super-capacitors and/or rechargeable batteries would enable power management for wearable devices. As a first step toward this goal of a fully implantable system, we propose to develop under this SPiRE an external glucose/sugar-based fuel cell as a technology demonstrator of our larger vision. Such a system has potential advantages over standard battery technology in terms of energy density, size, and weight but more importantly would allow us to research the issues surrounding these power sources. 1

PHR: Project Narrative: Whole brain functional imaging at neuron resolution scales could provide major scientific insights and lead to medical diagnostics, surgical guidance, and next-generation interventions. However, this lofty goal is difficult to achieve due to many physical and technological barriers. We introduce a new wearable and transparent ultrasound array technology that promises whole-brain functional imaging in animals with both optical and ultrasonic imaging capabilities. This array technology promises near-neuron resolution scales, and potential for whole-brain imaging of blood-flow changes, blood oxygenation changes, and neuron activity.

PHR: Project Narrative Substance use disorders are a significant public health issue, and one of the leading causes of drug relapse is exposure to stress. This project investigates specific neuronal subpopulations involved in anxiety-like stress responses with the long-term goal of understanding their contribution to relapse. In doing so, we hope to uncover new potential therapeutic targets in the treatment of maladaptive stress responses including affective and substance use disorders.
