IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loss of hair cells (the sensory cells of the inner ear) accounts for much of hearing loss and vestibular disorders, which in the United States afflict at least 50 and 15 percent of people over 70, respectively. Recent data suggest a critical role for the group-1 RFX transcription factors in hair cell development and maturation. Understanding the roles of group-1 RFX transcription factors and their target genes in hair cell development will shed necessary light on pathways important for hair cell regeneration and development of therapeutics for hearing and balance dysfunction.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People living with HIV (PLWH) are at the higher risk for impaired cognitive functions due to higher use of legal and illegal opioids that could affect their immune functions and exacerbate CNS (central nervous system) impairment. However, little is known about the HIV harboring cell types in brain, effect of therapy on specific CNS cell types, and the modification of brain functions by opioid use. Results of these innovative single-cell studies will generate cellular part list for brain regions and will illuminate novel insights into transcriptomic and epigenetic landscapes of CNS and how they are altered by HIV and opioid use.

ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: This research in veterans with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) will provide new information on the mechanisms determining the patients' exercise intolerance and the efficacy of regular physical activity to improve this shortcoming by alleviating the patients' neurocirculatory abnormalities. Specifically, we will focus on the role of nerves originating in working limb muscles in determining the patients' exercise intolerance and compromised fatigue resistance before and after a chronic exercise intervention. By focusing on a specific mechanism, this project will evaluate the validity of exercise as an alternative treatment strategy with the overall purpose of improving the quality of life of veterans with HFpEF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative In this BRAIN Initiative Optimization project, we will develop and disseminate high-density, flexible electrode arrays with thousands of low-noise, multiplexed electrodes and we will provide all of the tools, resources and training required to use this new technology in neuroscience experiments. We will enable BRAIN Initiative investigators and the broader neuroscience community to interface with the brain at a previously impossible large scale. This optimized technology will enable novel fundamental neuroscience research and next generation neuroprosthetic systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Muscle wasting starts early after spinal cord injury (SCI) and is a candidate mechanism interfering with the survival and recovery potential of the spinal cord injured patient. High thoracic level SCI concurrently exacerbates acute hypercortisolism and systemic muscle wasting, compared to low thoracic level SCI. This project will investigate the cause of acute SCI level-dependent hypercortisolism and determine whether protecting muscle from exposure to glucocorticoids attenuates systemic muscle wasting during the acute phase of high thoracic level SCI.

PHR: This proposal will investigate the mechanisms of treatment response in opioid use disorder (OUD) through investigation of the cognitive effects of opioid agonists and antagonist medications used in OUD relapse prevention. We shall use validated probes of three major cognitive domains with functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI), novel extended-release injectable preparations of opioid partial agonist buprenorphine, and antagonist naltrexone in OUD patients. The proposal is an innovative investigation of the cognitive effects of the next generation of extended-release relapse prevention medications aiming to elucidate the mechanisms of OUD treatment response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Translational models for understanding human brain function in health a disease need translational  tools that bridge the modality gap between many existing invasive and noninvasive techniques. Whole  brain directional functional connectivity as obtained from layer specific functional magnetic  resonance imaging is such a tool gaining increased versatility in human research. Here we develop,  validate and apply the required tools to perform these measurements non invasively in the non human  primate model at unprecedented magnetic field strength.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA damage response and repair pathways are attenuated with aging; if left unrepaired, accumulated damaged DNA may disrupt tissue homeostasis, enabling an aging milieu favoring tissue degeneration, cancer, and metabolic dysfunction. Using human tissue, induced pluripotent stem-cell derived human colon organoids, normal human colon cells, and genetically altered mouse models, we will test the novel hypothesis that age- dependent induction of local epithelial non-pituitary growth hormone suppresses DNA damage response, reinforcing DNA damage. We propose that local growth hormone is an adverse determinant of age-associated DNA damage accumulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Child abuse and neglect, child exposure to intimate partner violence, and parental opioid overdose are critical public health issues that impact health and development across the life course, yet limited research has examined the impact of access to affordable housing on the prevalence of these adverse childhood experiences (ACEs). We will employ a rigorous analytic method, generalized linear mixed models, to assess the impact of the low-income housing tax credit program on these three specific ACEs. Results will indicate whether the Low-Income Housing Tax Credit program, the largest federal affordable housing program, is an effective primary prevention strategy to reduce child abuse and neglect, intimate partner violence, and opioid overdose.
PROJECT_TITLE: Evaluating the Impact of Low-income Housing Tax Credits on child abuse and neglect, intimate partner violence, and opioid overdose

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Uveal melanoma (UM) is the most common primary eye cancer in adults with over half of patients developing metastatic disease to the liver. We have identified a new interaction between BAP1 and HDAC1 that may be driving tumor progression when BAP1 is lost. Ultimately, this proposed research will help us understand this interaction providing us new insights into the progression of this deadly cancer.

IC_NAME: National Center for Complementary & Integrative Health
PHR: Narrative This project aims to develop a broadly applicable platform for targeting and modulating activity of neurons and other electrogenic cells anywhere within the body. This approach will be further applied to interrogate circuits connecting the enteric (gut) neurons to the midbrain pathways delivering insights into the role of gut-brain connections in modulating dopamine-dependent behaviors. Our technologies and findings would pave way for development of organ-centric therapies for neurological and mental conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the U.S., more than 52 million women and 27 million men experience some form of sexual violence in their lifetime. By intervening early in adolescence, to create school environments that are nurturing, protective, and reduce risk, we can potentially prevent sexual violence before it begins. This study supports the rigorous evaluation of a middle school program to reduce sexual violence to generate evidence regarding the primary prevention of an understudied adolescent public health issue.
PROJECT_TITLE: Evaluation of the Youth-centered Environmental Shift (YES!) Program to reduce sexual violence in middle schools

PHR: This project seeks to address racial/ethnic disparities within the substance use disorder (SUD) cascade of care for youth involved in juvenile justice (YJJ). This is critical given the high rates of substance use among YJJ and poorer SUD treatment outcomes among racial/ethnic minority youth. Specifically, the project will utilize a multi- level assessment of state-reported juvenile justice (JJ) data, survey responses from key personnel within JJ and community mental health centers, and interviews from YJJ and their families to identify where disparities exist within the SUD care cascade, as well as factors that promote or mitigate such disparities, with the potential for findings to inform the promotion of culturally SUD treatment for racial/ethnic minority YJJ.

IC_NAME: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities
PHR: Project Narrative  Colorectal cancer (CRC) is one of the leading causes of cancer mortality in the United States, and African Americans (AfAms) still fare worse in CRC incidence and mortality compared to European Americans (EuAms). We propose to examine whether combining both fear-reduction and racially-targeted norm-based messages will increase at-home stool-based CRC screening receptivity and uptake for all African American regardless of level of racial identity. Given low return rates of at-home screening kits, we will also explore whether making an explicit commitment to return screening kits is associated with increased kit returns.

PHR: Project Narrative Falls are the leading cause of injury-related death in adults above the age of 65, and Care Facilities (e.g. assisted living, nursing homes) bear a substantial portion of the cost due to liability. Yet, this simple motion can be avoided if non-injurious falls and changes in gait parameters, both of which are predictors of future injurious falls, are recognized in time for preventative healthcare measures to be enacted. ASSET, in partnership with the University of South Carolina, is leveraging floor vibrations to detect non-injurious falls and changes in gait parameters as an affordable solution that alerts Care Facilities before an injurious fall occurs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Firearm access is consistently and strongly associated with increased risk of firearm suicide, a leading cause of death in the United States, but firearm suicides cannot be explained by firearm access alone. One additional factor may be opioid-related harm (e.g., opioid use disorder, overdose), which has increased exponentially since 1999. This study seeks to examine the synergistic impacts of firearm access and opioid-related harm on firearm suicide risk at both the population and individual levels.
PROJECT_TITLE: Firearm Access, Opioid Use, and Firearm Suicide Mortality

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREV AND HEALTH PROMO
PHR: Project Narrative This research is necessary to advance methods for using comprehensive healthcare data to estimate chronic disease burden, assessing the reliability and validity of those methods, and comparing to traditional systems. Furthermore, this project will generate and evaluate diabetes incidence and prevalence and will share those estimates via a unique dashboard with public health authorities for the purposes of disease surveillance and prevention.

PROJECT_TITLE: Leveraging Electronic Health Data to Assess the Burden of Diabetes among Young Adults

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The effects of music on memory in naturalistic settings are not yet well understood. In this  project, we aim to study how memory for films is affected by the presence or absence of the film  score and whether these effects can be measured neurally. This work will help develop new  neural measures of music-evoked episodic memory as well as expand our understanding of music's  effect on memory under natural conditions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Synucleinopathies such as Parkinson?s Disease, Lewy body dementia and multiple system atrophy affect millions of Americans and yet they lack proper disease modifying treatments. PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study is significant because the large number of individuals under criminal justice supervision with Opioid Use Disorders (OUDs) have limited access to pharmacotherapy treatment, an intervention found to reduce substance use, HIV-risk behavior, and criminal activity. The proposed study is innovative because it would be the first RCT in the US assessing the effectiveness of CAM2038, an extended-release buprenorphine (XR-B) formulation versus extended-release naltrexone (XR-NTX) with jail inmates prior to release. The public health impact of the proposed study would be widespread, as findings from the implementation learning collaborative could facilitate the implementation of long-acting opioid medications with jail populations, enabling this treatment to be scaled-up throughout many areas of the US with high rates of OUD. In addition, the findings from this study will be a valuable addition to the literature, as there is no evidence regarding the economic value of XR-B and limited evidence regarding the economic value of XR-NTX for opioid use disorder with a jail population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Protein-DNA interactions regulate the spatial- and temporal-specific gene expressions in cells. We propose to develop a high-throughput tool for co-analyzing protein-DNA interactions and gene expression within the same cells. PHR: Project Narrative Our project seeks to develop our platform technology to produce microglia from human induced pluripotent stem cells for the treatment of adult-onset leukoencephalopathy with axonal spheroids and pigmented glia. PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it offers new and improved strategies to efficiently and accurately diagnose the etiology of acute febrile illness, a requisite for effective disease control and treatment. The proposed research is relevant to the US Centers of Disease Control and Prevention as it will inform regional assessments and demonstrate a pathway for implementation of improved diagnostics by key stakeholders in a region that is highly endemic for emerging infectious diseases.
PROJECT_TITLE: GH20-005, Conducting Integrated Infectious Disease and Public Health Research in Peru

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Narrative Our proposed K12 program, CATALyST (Consortium for Applied Training to Advance the Learning health system with Scholars/Trainees), is a partnership based on decades of successful regional training and research collaborations among Kaiser Permanente Washington, University of Washington (Schools of Nursing, Medicine, Pharmacy and Public Health), and the VA Puget Sound Health Care System, and a newer collaboration with the recently founded Washington State University College of Medicine. We are committed to expanding the cadre of embedded researchers conducting learning health system research in delivery systems through mentored career development. Our mentored K12 program will accelerate the efficiency and effectiveness of learning health system research by training the next generation of researchers in this growing field.
PROJECT_TITLE: CATALyST: Consortium for Applied Training to Advance the Learning health system with Scholars/Trainees

PHR: Project Narrative This study examines the influence of sociodemographic statuses and transitions among those now entering midlife on comorbid health outcomes in early midlife, as well as the role of life-course alcohol use and social and neighborhood environments for midlife health. Drawing on longitudinal data from a diverse community sample from age 10 to 47, the study investigates the long-term malleability of environmental factors and seeks to identify promising intervention targets to design and tailor prevention programs from early adolescence to midlife. The goal of the study is to provide midlife researchers and health practitioners with specific recommendations for preventive interventions addressing public health priorities for midlife adults.

ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: Swallowing dysfunction (dysphagia) is a significant healthcare burden for Veterans, especially those of advanced age. More than 102,905 evaluation and 77,786 treatment procedures for oropharyngeal dysphagia were completed by speech-language pathologists in the VA in 2016. Dysphagia frequently results in serious health consequences for Veterans, including malnutrition, dehydration, aspiration pneumonia, and death. Yet, the framework used to measure and predict rehabilitation outcomes is poorly supported. The proposed research will improve the current understanding of dysphagia, validate clinical tools for measuring treatment outcomes, and create predictive models that empower clinicians, patients, caregivers, and healthcare networks to establish realistic expectations for dysphagia rehabilitation. This will notably improve healthcare resource utilization, as well as the quality of life of Veterans suffering with dysphagia.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Periviable birth is among the leading causes of infant death and childhood disability, with disproportionate impact in low-income and minority communities, and although relatively rare, the CDC estimates that extremely premature deliveries result in societal costs exceeding $26 billion dollars annually. To optimize high-stakes periviable counseling encounters, we propose to test, in a multisite, randomized controlled trial, a decision support intervention (i.e., Periviable GOALS DST) developed by our research team to facilitate informed, shared decision-making regarding neonatal resuscitation among women who present to labor and delivery at periviable gestations (from 22 0/7 to 24 6/7 weeks gestational age) and their physicians. The proposed work stands to improve the quality of periviable care by enabling more informed and patient-centered decisions, and our results will have immediate clinical relevance because the regional and institutional diversity of our trial sites, which improves generalizability, allowing for broad application and dissemination of the tool.
PI_NAMEs: KUPPERMANN, MIRIAM ; TUCKER EDMONDS, BROWNSYNE M (contact);
PROJECT_TITLE: Promoting Shared Decision Making in Periviable Care: A randomized controlled trial of the Periviable GOALS Decision Support Tool

PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance Statement) Patients with end stage HNSCC have few therapeutic options. We have developed an experimental means of treating HNSCC in patients who have failed other treatments. This approach involves production of very potent chemotherapy within the tumor mass, itself. If this strategy is found successful in HNSCC, other tumor types might be addressed in a similar fashion. Such tumors include soft tissue sarcoma, glioma, and cancer of the cervix, among others, which represent a significant and unmet need from the perspective of public health.
PI_NAMEs: ROSENTHAL, EBEN L; SORSCHER, ERIC J (contact);
PROJECT_TITLE: Phase I - II Study of Ad/PNP(IND14271,1/19/10)for HNSCC(OrphanDrugDes,14-4438,6/8/15)

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Microglia are genetically implicated in the susceptibility to the progression of Alzheimer's disease (AD), which has stimulated enhanced focus on these cells and their regulatory pathways as therapeutic targets. There are growing evidence to suggest sialic acid-binding immunoglobulin-like lectins (Siglecs) and their sialoglycan targets may provide just such an opportunity. Based on our preliminary studies, we propose to identify specific Siglec inhibitory pathways in microglia at different stages of AD pathogenesis, which could open new potential avenues for developing mechanism-based therapy for AD.

ORG_NAME: VA NORTHERN CALIFORNIA HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Project Narrative Stroke is the leading cause of chronic disability in the United States. Each year, approximately 795,000 strokes occur accounting for over half of all acute inpatient neurological admissions across both Veterans Affairs and civilian medical settings. Persons 45-64 years of age now account for approximately half of total stroke care costs, a shift heralding an urgent need for rehabilitation to not only reduce disability and attendant costs of care, but optimize stroke recovery for persons in the productive and vital years of their lives. As a result, there is a critical need to identify rehabilitation methods that promote genuine recovery. The current proposal investigates methods to optimize induction of neuroplasticity in an effort to enhance walking function in Veterans following stroke. We will test three approaches to delivering paired associative stimulation, a non-invasive form of neuromodulation with known influences on neuroplasticity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) Identifying the mechanisms linking daily work conditions and corresponding strain reactions to unsafe commuting is a precursor to intervention development. The proposed project synthesizes a video-based naturalistic driving approach validated in the transportation safety community with a daily survey methodology widely used in occupational health research to explicate the process through which daily work conditions and work-related strain reactions influence worker safety while commuting.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer?s disease is a devastating neurodegenerative disorder which significantly affects cognitive functions. The proposed research will investigate the neural circuit mechanism through which prolonged manipulation of hippocampal activity by gamma frequency sensory stimulation acts to improve learning and memory. This technique has the potential to develop into a powerful, non-invasive therapeutic to rescue neural activity deficits, disease pathology, and improve cognition in patients with Alzheimer?s disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The precise aspects of dysglycemia and glucose homeostasis that drive the risk of Alzheimer?s disease and Alzheimer?s disease related dementias are unknown, hampering development of successful prevention strategies. The proposed research will leverage wearable technology to investigate the association of glucose homeostasis, from continuous glucose monitors, with incident neurocognitive indicators of Alzheimer?s disease and Alzheimer?s disease related dementias in the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis. This study will suggest new mechanisms of Alzheimer?s disease and Alzheimer?s disease related dementia development, identify new primary and secondary prevention targets, and have the potential to change clinical care

PHR: Project Narrative (Relevance to Public Health) The proposed work directly tests sex differences in morbidity and mortality rates at older ages in response to cohort selection in utero. Our project may ultimately assist in connecting life history theory to predictions regarding male more than female mortality rates at advanced ages. In addition, results may identify subgroups that, by virtue of their birth cohort and individual-level life course experience, appear most susceptible to greater risk of common chronic disease (e.g., cardiovascular disease).

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because medication adverse events cause substantial morbidity and cost, yet little is known about how patient and caregivers can participate in monitoring and reporting medication adverse events occurring in the home and community. The proposal will describe outpatient medication adverse events from a previously unexplored Patient Safety Organization database, then develop a text-message-based patient-initiated medication adverse event reporting tool for identifying ambulatory events related to the high-risk medications warfarin, insulin, and opioids. The project is relevant to the priorities of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ), including medication safety, ambulatory care safety, patient and caregiver engagement, the role of Patient Safety Organizations, and adverse event reporting.
PROJECT_TITLE: ExPERTS-PC: Engaging Patients in Event ReporTing for Safety in Primary Care

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will advance clinical and public health knowledge regarding the incidence of and trends and disparities in mortality and morbidity during pregnancy and the first year postpartum due to drug use, self-harm, and violence. Our research will also change clinical practice by finding ways to identify women ? in hospital- based settings ? at high risk for future morbidity and mortality due to drug use, self-harm, and violence, and lay the foundation for developing preventive strategies. The evidence from the proposed research will extend the current knowledge about maternal morbidity and mortality to encompass non-obstetric causes that are of substantial and growing importance.

PHR: Project Narrative Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a life-long neurodevelopmental disorder that affects approximately 1% of the general population, and there are currently no effective treatments due to a limited understanding of the underlying pathophysiology. This work focuses on identifying points of dendritic dysfunction that converge across multiple models of leading candidate ASD genes. This project will advance our understanding of the cellular processes that contribute to ASD and will potentially lead to novel therapeutic targets and new treatment strategies.

PHR: Project Narrative Cellular pathways implicated in aging and longevity are under circadian regulation, and in turn, aging leads to circadian disruption and damped circadian gene expression. We hypothesize that age-related declines in circadian gene expression affect longevity pathways and health. Therefore, interventions that can rescue circadian function may extend healthspan and lifespan.

PHR: Preclinical Development of Novel OX1R Antagonists for Treatment of Substance Use Disorder NARRATIVE: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Cocaine use disorder (CUD) is one of the most seriously impactful forms of substance abuse disorders (SUD) with significant socio-economic burden to humankind; including causing >20% of fatal drug overdoses in the US amounting to >15,000 deaths yearly. Currently there is no FDA approved medication to treat CUD. This research should provide highly impactful and innovative treatment modalities for CUD via modulation of several signaling pathways implicated in CUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID) have been recognized as an important cause of clinical dementia. The goal of the MarkVCID consortium, of which the University of Southern California is a participating site, is to be perform rigorous validation of imaging and fluid-based biomarkers for small vessel VCID to be ready for large scale clinical trials to evaluate novel interventions of VCID.

PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer?s disease is a public health crisis in the US and a growing health disparity, with African Americans at disproportionate risk for the disease compared to non-Hispanic whites. This project proposes to investigate earlier-life, individual- and community-level stress exposures?adverse life circumstances and trauma (ie, extreme poverty, residential instability, crime, police and community violence, incarceration, racial discrimination), mental disorders and their symptoms, and poor sleep (eg, abnormal duration, fragmentation)?as determinants of known midlife risk factors for poor cognitive outcomes in later life in two high-risk predominantly African American cohorts followed longitudinally for 35 years. Results will help clarify links of stress exposures with midlife dementia risk, identify vulnerable subgroups for targeted prevention of Alzheimer?s disease, elucidate the role of social inequities in determining racial disparities in Alzheimer?s dementia, and establish a midlife cognitive baseline for future longitudinal follow-up of this valuable cohort.

PHR: Effects of a major natural disaster on the pace of aging in a nonhuman primate model Age is the strongest predictor of risk for a multitude of diseases, yet the extent to which natural disasters impact aging remains unclear. This project investigates how and in what ways a major natural disaster, Hurricane Maria, has modified the pace of aging in a nonhuman primate model, the rhesus macaque. Our results will reveal how and to what extent a natural disaster impacts the onset of age-related declines, which will inform the targeted development of behavioral and physiological interventions that could reduce the burden of aging-related disease in our aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In recent years, the number of overdoses involving stimulants (e.g., cocaine, methamphetamine) has increased dramatically in the US and in the hotspot states of Massachusetts and Rhode Island. In order to develop effective strategies to curb this epidemic, formative research is needed to identify multilevel factors that may be contributing to this crisis in the most affected geographic areas. This study will utilize a rigorous mixed-methods approach that involves the: 1) collection of quantitative and qualitative data from people who use and distribute stimulants and other drugs; 2) novel analysis of the drug supply; and 3) the assembly of local working groups comprised of stakeholders from across the overdose prevention and response continuum who will help to unpack the mixed-methods findings and identify a package of locally-tailored, yet scalable interventions that can be swiftly implemented to combat the stimulant overdose crisis in the hardest-hit regions of Massachusetts and Rhode Island.
PI_NAMEs: GREEN, TRACI C; HUGHTO, JACLYN WHITE (contact); RICH, JOSIAH D;
PROJECT_TITLE: Preventing Overdoses Involving Stimulants (POINTS)Study

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is an important yet poorly understood neurodegenerative disorder that shares clinical, pathological, and genetic features with dementias including Alzheimer's disease, Frontotemporal dementia, and Parkinson's disease. We propose developing high-throughput experimental approaches to identify and characterize functional genetic variation underlying PSP risk. Ultimately, this work may yield mechanistic insights into the pathogenesis of neurodegeneration and provide novel therapeutic targets, while serving as a model for future studies of neurological disease.

PHR: Centenarian cognitive superagers have exceptional cognitive function despite extreme exposure to the strongest risk factor for cognitive impairment and Alzheimer's disease, aging. The ?Resilience/Resistance to AD in Centenarians and Offspring? (RADCO) Study gauges cognitive resilience among centenarian cognitive superagers and their offspring using cognitive testing, neuroimaging, blood biomarkers, and neuropathology and translational studies will identify protective factors and underlying mechanisms that confer resilience or in some cases, even resistance against cognitive decline and dementia.

PHR: Narrative We propose to develop a portable hand-held xenon inhalation device to rapidly attenuate opioid withdrawal symptoms (OWS), on demand, which emerge spontaneously or upon initiation of and/or maintenance with buprenorphine or naltrexone treatment in people with opioid use disorder (OUD). Reducing OWS is an unmet clinical need worth solving because the morbidity and mortality associated with OUD, driven largely by unprescribed opioid use to alleviate OWS, is substantial and costs society an estimated $80 billion/year. If effective against OWS, xenon inhalation likely would be superior to existing treatments because of its rapid effects and favorable safety and side-effect profiles, and xenon therapy can be disseminated by our experienced team in a capital efficient manner with exit potential.

PHR: Project Narrative Retinal degeneration is a major cause of visual impairment and blindness in humans, but there are few effective treatments available to the many patients in need. The goal of this project is to advance the pace and efficiency of research regarding treatments for retinal degeneration disease by developing novel spontaneous (not induced) nonhuman primate models of human retinal disease. By developing new and better animal models, and making those models available to the wider vision research community, this project will speed the development and efficacy testing of innovative therapies, including cell and gene therapy, that will reduce the morbidity caused by retinal degeneration diseases in humans.

PHR: The proposed research activities will contribute to the prevention, detection, response and containment of public health threats posed by infectious diseases and to reduce the resulting burden and disabilities in Colombia. For Year 1 of this proposed cooperative agreement, three projects are proposed that address research issues on relevant infectious diseases for Colombia, with the ultimate goal of improving public health. The three projects are centered on research of acute febrile illness (AFI) and related aspects to guide public health interventions and detect emerging threats to better define the burden, risk, and effectiveness of available prevention interventions to mitigate their impact.
PROJECT_TITLE: Excellence in Research for Emerging and Reemerging Diseases of Public Health Interest in Colombia at the National Institute of Health

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is a rare genetic disorder in which the motile cilia of the respiratory tract do not function, leading to recurrent infections. Interestingly, myeloid cells, which are not ciliated, are also dysfunctional in PCD patients. Our study of the mechanism by which the PCD-associated protein CCDC103 promotes normal myeloid cell proliferation and migration by stabilizing microtubules will contribute new knowledge to our understanding of how myeloid cells move and grow in the context of many classes of disease.

PHR: NARRATIVE There is an urgent need to improve care provided to patients with dementia (PWD) and their caregivers by health care systems (HCS). Few evidence based non-pharmacologic interventions have been embedded in HCS and tested for effectiveness. Pragmatic clinical trials conducted within HCS are ideally-suited to test the effectiveness of such interventions but they require specific expertise, methods, data sources, and industry partnerships. The knowledge, investigative experience, collaborations, and evidence generated by the proposed National Institute on Aging Alzheimer's disease (AD)/AD-related dementia (AD/ADRD) Collaboratory has the potential to transform the delivery, quality, and outcomes of care for Americans from all backgrounds suffering with AD/ADRD.

PHR: NARRATIVE FOR OVERVIEW The Aging Adult Brain Connectome (AABC) builds on the existing infrastructure previously developed through the Human Connectome Project (HCP) Aging consortium. The AABC will acquire demographic, genetic, physi- ologic, health, and neurocognitive information in conjunction with cutting edge functional and structural neu- roimaging data (magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and now magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS)) from a large cohort of individuals (n=1,000) across the lifespan. The overarching goal of the AABC is to determine structural and functional brain connectivity trajectories associated with vulnerability and resilience to develop- ing late life dementia. While cognitive decline and dementia are generally considered conditions of late life, the risk for developing late life impairment begins at conception and continues to accumulate throughout the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Project Narrative Adverse childhood experiences (ACES) is a major public health problem that exacts tremendous cost to the United States each year. In this study, we will examine prenatal infant and early childhood mental health consultation in a short-term home visiting program. Primary outcomes of the proposed randomized control trial (RCT) will include the prevention of child maltreatment (child abuse and neglect) and exposure to adult intimate partner violence.
PROJECT_TITLE: Embedding Mental Health Consultation Within Prenatal Home Visiting to Prevent Child Maltreatment and Violence Exposure

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Plasmodium vivax, one of the parasites that causes malaria, was considered absent from Sub-Saharan Africa until recently. To date, no studies have attempted to systematically measure the prevalence of P. vivax in the region, to determine the origin of this re-emergent population, or to estimate its potential threat to public health. This proposal uses both an epidemiological and population genetics approach to determine who is being infected, where infections are occurring, where infections originated, and the history and extent of ongoing transmission.

PHR: Project Narrative  The widespread use of antiretroviral therapies has significantly increased the lifespan of people living with HIV. Despite their effectiveness, there is a growing concern that antiretrovirals are the cause of a variety of comorbid conditions, including osteoporosis. The current proposal seeks to develop a small animal model to investigate the role of HIV and antiretroviral therapy on bone loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Our goal is to uncover molecular mechanisms underlying myopathic chronic intestinal pseudo-obstruction and megacystis microcolon intestinal hypoperistalsis syndrome, life-threatening forms of visceral myopathy characterized by smooth muscle weakness. Heterozygous missense mutations in gamma smooth muscle actin (ACTG2) are the most common cause of visceral myopathy, but the mechanisms of disease are unknown. Using innovative strategies, including recombinant expression of actin in human cells, advanced quantitative image analysis in human intestinal smooth muscle cells, and visceral smooth muscle- specific differentiation of stem cells, this project investigates mechanisms of ACTG2 mutation-induced visceral myopathy and could lead to new drug screening approaches and novel therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Project Narrative Hospital-based violence intervention is a unique and effective strategy for targeting difficult to reach and high- risk violently injured patients. This project evaluates Bridging the Gap (BTG), a promising hybrid intervention model that provides a hospital-based violence intervention, a hospital-and community-based firearm counseling program, and 6-months of intensive community case management. It will conduct a rigorous randomized control trial to determine the effectiveness of BTG for reducing firearm-related violence and injury in adult victims of violence, as well as evaluating the economic benefits of BTG to determine its scalability as a firearm-related violence and injury intervention strategy.
PROJECT_TITLE: Preventing Retaliatory Gun Violence in Violently Injured Adults: A RCT of a Hospital-Based Intervention

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative  Chronic neuroinflammation provoked by amyloid-beta (A?)-activated microglia and macrophages contribute to the etiology of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and can be a pathogenic factor for which early-stage diagnostic markers and treatment targets may be found. Because m6A is the most abundant mRNA modification in gene-specific translation regulation, we will delineate new wide-spread mechanisms that underlie additional, non-histone modifying (epigenetic) functions of G9a in m6A-mediated translation regulation of A?-induced neurotoxic inflammation, a potential early-stage pathological mechanism in AD. Our results will provide both new diagnostic/prognostic markers to identify patients with early stage AD and new druggable targets for precision, early intervention of AD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this preliminary R21 study, we will evaluate whether disturbed sleep, as measured by poor multidimensional sleep health, augments the effects of depression on biological aging. These preliminary data will seed our scientific understanding of the sleep and molecular senescence pathways through which depression exposure contributes to diseases of aging and related comorbidities. From a clinical standpoint, these data will inform the development and dissemination of sleep-based interventions to ameliorate the downstream effects of depression on senesce-associated morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Child maltreatment, adult intimate partner violence (IPV), and youth violence are pervasive, preventable public health issues with lifelong negative social, behavioral, and physical health outcomes. Economic security policies are promising primary prevention strategies for violence that provide economic support to low-income families, including African American families who experience persistent disparities in poverty and family and youth violence. Our study proposes a series of rigorous, quasi experimental analyses to evaluate the effectiveness of Temporary Assistance for Needy Families, Minimum Wage, and Earned Income Tax Credit in preventing family and youth violence and reducing violence disparities.
PROJECT_TITLE: Evaluating family economic policies as primary prevention strategies to prevent family and youth violence

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREV AND HEALTH PROMO
PHR: NARRATIVE The overarching mission of the proposed University of Wisconsin-Madison Prevention Research Center (UWPRC) is to improve the health of low-income women, infants and families through the conduct of high-quality applied health promotion and disease prevention research with a focus on achieving health equity. The UWPRC will accomplish this by engaging multidisciplinary campus researchers, public health practitioners, community- based and governmental organizations and families to develop a research and translational agenda. The agenda will emphasize policy and systems strategies at the foundation of the CDC Health Impact Pyramid where there is broad population impact.
PI_NAMEs: EHRENTHAL, DEBORAH BETH (contact); MAHONEY, JANE E;
PROJECT_TITLE: Expanding the Evidence-Base for Prevention Strategies to Improve the Health of Women, Infants, and Families

PHR: Significant resources have been devoted to the immediate rehabilitation needs of persons undergoing lower- limb amputation, but there needs to be greater consideration for the early identification and modification of potential risk factors responsible for long-term development of secondary health conditions. Individuals with unilateral lower-limb amputation place greater demands on their sound leg during ambulation for body support and forward progression, which is believed to contribute to the development of secondary physical conditions after long-term prosthesis use. While asymmetry due to limb loss is inevitable, reduction in this asymmetry and the consequential higher loading on the intact limb would also seem to be desirable. However, the development and implementation of novel solutions for prosthesis users should consider the effect of gender on the incidence and prevalence of these disabling health conditions. This work is directly applicable to the Veteran Health Administration?s Patient Care Mission because the results may improve the gait and quality of life of Veterans.

PHR: Psychotic symptoms occur in over 50% of individuals with Alzheimer?s disease and constitute a major concern for public health, yet the underlying disease mechanisms remain unclear. The goal of this proposal is to identify robust and predictive biomarkers for psychosis in Alzheimer?s disease using a novel data-driven computational framework. The proposed work can transform our understanding of brain circuit mechanisms underlying psychosis in Alzheimer?s disease and ultimately lead to the development of more effective and precise diagnostic and treatment strategies for these debilitating neuropsychiatric symptoms in Alzheimer?s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to develop an optimized protocol to integrate higher resolution anatomic information from balanced steady-state free-precession (bSSFP) MRI with 4D flow MRI data in an automated analysis pipeline to examine the hemodynamic and anatomic factors between bicuspid aortic valve (BAV) and trileaflet aortic valve (TAV) patients with aortic stenosis. We aim to develop and validate a respiratory-controlled bSSFP sequence, automate the integration of 4D flow data with anatomic bSSFP data, and calculate important functional metrics such as vessel area changes and the wall force dynamics over the cardiac cycle. Finally, we aim to implement a pilot study to show differences in AS patients with BAV and TAV that may lead to improved clinical staging and management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) is a debilitating disease with progressive muscle weakness and degeneration as well as cognitive deficits. With hopes of improvements in the life span in the near future, cognitive deficits need to be looked at from a brain imaging window. Consequently, we propose to capture high- resolution brain-images of children and find the relationships of the brain structure and function with cognition and behavior along with a spatial localization of the gene-expression associations with brain connectivity in DMD.

PHR: NARRATIVE In this project we will use sequential in vivo and ex vivo imaging to produce high-resolution three dimensional maps of the vasculature and the connective tissues of the intraorbital optic nerve in humans, monkeys, and mice. We will quantify the effects of acutely elevated IOP on the function and biomechanics of the vasculature exvivo in all three species, and also test the effects of experimental glaucoma on vessel morphology and function in mice and monkeys. We will test the hypothesis that features of the vasculature and its relationship with the connective tissues predisposes certain regions to compromised perfusion, and that this susceptibility is amplified by elevated IOP.

PHR: Project Narrative Established in 2009, the NYU-CUNY Prevention Research Center is seeking a third cycle of funding, with a research and translation agenda focused on advancing and scaling effective community health worker (CHW) and other community-clinical linkage intervention models to improve access to care and reduce chronic disparities among socially disadvantaged populations. This application (1) builds on our established, community-engaged bench of public and private partnerships, (2) expands our institutional commitment and research depth in implementation research and systems science, and (3) introduces a new partnership with the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene to perform a public health practice-based research evaluation of a novel CHW-facilitated trauma-informed intervention to improve the health of justice-involved populations.
PROJECT_TITLE: NYU-CUNY Prevention Research Center

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use in pregnant women has increased over the past decade, highlighting the importance of efforts to understand how environmental and other exposures during pregnancy affect brain development and child outcomes. The PRELUDE consortium for the HEALthy Brain and Child Development study will recruit 2720 pregnant women in the 2nd and 3rd trimester and follow their children to age 10, using neuroimaging, behavioral assessments, EEG, biosample collection, and assessments of parent-child interaction and the home environment. This research will lead to greater understanding of factors affecting early childhood brain development, allowing targeted interventions and improved outcomes for mother-child dyads.

PHR: Project Narrative: Calmodulin (CaM) is a multifunctional Ca2+ binding protein that plays important roles in a wide range of intracellular signaling. Recent studies have provided evidence that mutations in CaM can be linked to human cardiac arrhythmias. The current proposal will use state-of-the art techniques including computational modeling and molecular dynamics to decipher the mechanisms underlying these newly described human CaM mutations.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The public health significance of our proposed ENRICH intervention is high, given the aging population and the poor outcomes experienced by older adults recovering from hip fracture. The patient-centered development and implementation of the ENRICH program represents an important paradigm shift in hip fracture rehabilitation, and provides a framework for promoting high quality aging in place for other disabled older adult populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of the proposal is to improve the understanding of motivations for service members and veterans owning firearms, storing them in unsafe conditions and using them to hurt others or themselves. In the short term, this research will elucidate the relationship between firearm use and suicide to identify veterans in need of suicide prevention strategies. The broader impact of this study is the development of a comprehensive understanding of risks contributing to firearm mediated suicide, thus improving risk identification capabilities in the military and civilian population.
PROJECT_TITLE: Firearm Behavioral Practices and Suicide Risk in U.S. Army Soldiers and Veterans

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's Disorder (AD) is one of the most pressing public health issues as the world's population continues to age, but there is no known effective prevention or cure exists. The Alzheimer's Disease Sequencing Project (ADSP) has sequenced a large number (n>17,000) of AD patients and normal healthy elderly controls. Leveraging the rich resources from ADSP, we propose to comprehensively detect genomic copy number variations (CNVs), find CNV and AD association for different ethnicities, and further facilitate the identification of genetic therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed exploratory research is directed toward improving the safety of front line service workers (FLSWs) by reducing motor vehicle crashes involving these workers. We propose to examine how perceptual grouping of flashing warning lights with other features associated with FLSW vehicles, specifically paint and retroreflective colors, affect driver behavior. Combinations that elicit shorter identification times will provide drivers with more time to judge situations in work areas, and consequently to avoid FLSWs and their vehicles.
PROJECT_TITLE: Coordination of Vehicle Lighting and Markings for Improved Worker Safety
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section

PHR: Medication assisted treatment (methadone, buprenorphine, naltrexone) is available for Opioid Use Disorder; however, many patients do not fully respond, and adjunctive treatments that increase adherence are needed. Our goal is to develop a brain stimulation device that improves response to medical treatment in this disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Child abuse and neglect (CAN) is a major public health concern, which is prevalent in the United States and linked to a ranged of negative outcomes such as disrupted early brain development, physical and mental health problems, compromised intellectual and cognitive development, emotional, psychological, and behavioral concerns, and elevated risk of death in childhood and adulthood. The proposed research during this K01 award period will address serious gaps in our knowledge of the relationships of community conditions and public policies with CAN report rates by national and statewide data analyses and literature reviews. Continued research on ecological factors for CAN in large population-level data and policies addressing those factors will enhance our ability to prevent CAN.
PROJECT_TITLE: Public Policies, Community Conditions, and Child Abuse and Neglect: National and Statewide Data Analyses and Literature Reviews

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will provide crucial perspective on a key driver of depressive symptoms for Americans above age 50 over the past quarter-century of fluctuating economic conditions, yielding information to help guide policy and interventions to improve mental health in the years leading up to and after retirement. The proposed analytic approach lays the foundation for identifying multiple targets for interventions. Since intervening on employment to mitigate the effect of job loss on depressive symptoms may improve mental health and quality of life in the years leading up to and following retirement, the project is relevant to the part of the NIA's mission that pertains to supporting social and economic research on aging and the part of NIH's mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

PROJECT_TITLE: Quantifying the burden of depressive symptoms in older Americans that is attributable to involuntary job loss: a counterfactual approach

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Numerous studies and a recent Institute of Medicine report have raised concerns about the quality of end-of- life (EOL) care provided to older adults in the United States, especially those with Alzheimer?s Disease and Related Dementias and other life-limiting conditions. Medicare Advantage, the managed care option for Medicare beneficiaries, contains many financial incentives that could encourage provision of high-quality end- of-life care. We compare rates of potentially burdensome and inappropriate EOL care among Medicare Advantage enrollees compared to those in Fee-for-Service Medicare and test whether better outpatient management accounts for these differences to determine whether managed care represents a promising model to improve end-of-life care.

PHR: Narrative We propose A Chicago Center of Excellence in Learning Health Systems Research Training (ACCELERAT) to develop the next generation of health system transformation leaders. ACCELERAT is anchored by a tightly integrated team of Northwestern University researchers and Northwestern Medicine health care quality experts, along with the living laboratory of the 11 health care institutions across Chicago which constitute the PCORnet Clinical Data Research Network, the Chicago Area Patient Centered Outcomes Research Network (CAPriCORN). ACCELERAT will serve as a national leader in teaching core learning health system research competencies aimed to train future leaders to transform care delivery and advance patient- centered research while also delivering quality health care.
PI_NAMEs: FRANKLIN, PATRICIA D; KHO, ABEL N (contact);
PROJECT_TITLE: A Chicago Center of Excellence in Learning Health Systems Research Training (ACCELERAT)

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this study is to design, implement, and pilot test a Multi-faceted persistent Opioid use Prevention Program (MOPP) - an intervention to support safer opioid prescribing, self-administration and monitoring, and reduce persistent opioid use and opioid use disorder for patients transitioning to the community setting after major orthopedic surgery. The MOPP includes: 1) pharmacist-led discharge counseling of patients and caregivers and communication with post-discharge providers; 2) standardized opioid prescribing discharge order sets for each surgery type; 3) a post-discharge pain management follow-up visit embedded within routine post-operative orthopedic care for managing pain and opioid use; and 4) a patient engagement pain management mobile app for assessing pain, function, and possible development of opioid use disorder. In this Supplement, we plan to create a dedicated Spanish-language version of the app, over- enroll Latino and Spanish-speaking patients, and add a 3rd stage to the study so that we can evaluate baseline disparities in pain management by language and ethnicity, determine the incremental benefits of the Spanish- language app, and determine the ability of the intervention to reduce disparities by language and ethnicity on pain management and opioid use.

PHR: The overall objective of this SPiRE proposal is to test feasibility of a novel interventional approach using transpelvic magnetic stimulation to prevent erectile dysfunction (ED; major form of male sexual dysfunction) and urinary incontinence (UI) that are frequently seen in prostate cancer survivors. Our proposal will also test feasibility of development of novel imaging techniques to determine morphological changes of cancer surgery? related penile smooth muscle, urethral sphincter and supporting pelvic striated muscles. Findings of this feasibility study will enable us to further test our hypotheses in a future randomized clinical trial. If this intervention is proven to be efficacious in a randomized trial, it will have important implications for rehabilitation in the future. Thus, establishing the foundation for a future translational trial is of utmost importance to VA healthcare users.

PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer?s disease and Alzheimer?s disease-related dementias, a group of age-associated disorders characterized by progressive deterioration of brain function, affect millions of people in the US. This proposal investigates how loss of pericytic laminin leads to neurovascular dysfunction (blood brain barrier disruption, cerebral blood flow reduction, and brain influx/efflux function impairment) and neurodegeneration, and explores the underlying molecular mechanisms. Successful completion of this study will elucidate the fundamental roles of pericytic laminin in neurovascular function and neurodegeneration, and identify novel molecular targets with therapeutic potential in Alzheimer?s disease and Alzheimer?s disease-related dementias.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will investigate the role of the early secretory pathway protein TMED9 in the accumulation of a mutant protein, MUC1-fs, in the toxic proteinopathy MUC1 Kidney Disease (MKD). Understanding protein accumulation in this rare genetic kidney disease may identify new therapeutic targets for this toxic proteinopathy, other toxic proteinopathies, and more common kidney pathologies that lack therapeutic solutions. Further, elucidation of the mechanism of MUC1-fs accumulation in MKD will provide insight into general mechanisms of proteostasis and kidney biology in health and disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE International travel may not only increase the risk of infection for an individual traveler, but may also contribute to the global spread of infections. This continuation application focuses on Global TravEpiNet -- a consortium of clinics providing pre-travel health advice, the driving force behind the Heading Home Healthy Program, and a platform for quantitative assessments of travel-related illnesses and interventions. GTEN?s mission is to advance the care of U.S. international travelers, with the goal of preserving and advancing the health of the American public.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Poor access to high-quality post-intensive care unit (ICU) recovery services is a major problem for thousands of older Americans living in rural communities who survive critical illness each year. They and their families commonly experience a nightmare of uncoordinated care, poor health, reduced independence, reduced quality of life, and high ongoing healthcare utilization. To address these problems, the proposed research will develop and pilot test a scalable ICU recovery intervention, called TeleRecovery, in which a nurse practitioner and oc- cupational therapist will deliver transitional care, family training and support, and skills-based rehabilitation to rural-dwelling older adults, starting at the time of transfer out of the ICU and continuing via telehealth after dis- charge until successful graduation back to their primary care teams
PROJECT_TITLE: Tele-Recovery: Engaging Stakeholders to Adapt and Pilot Test a Scalable Transitional Rehabilitation Intervention for Older, Rural ICU Survivors

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research has enormous public health implications given the tremendous burden of child sexual abuse on social, emotional and physical well-being. Evidence-based primary prevention interventions to eliminate child sexual abuse are needed and this study has the opportunity to demonstrate the efficacy of the Health Relationships Project (HRP) that has been operating for over 30 years, in 30 U.S. states, elevating it to the echelon of evidence-based programming. The innovative and novel stepped wedge cluster randomized trial of HRP conducted in 16 high need Washington, DC public charter schools, carried out by a highly skilled academic/community-based partnership, will have the methodological rigor and community input to make contributions to the field about how to implement and sustain a highly regarded and feasible school-based primary prevention intervention for child sexual abuse.
PROJECT_TITLE: Evaluation of the school-based Healthy Relationships Project for primary prevention of child sexual abuse among children pre-K through 5th grade

PHR: Alzheimer?s disease (AD) is a complex age-dependent disorder that requires multiple approaches to understand at a molecular level in order to develop novel diagnostics and disease modifying treatments. We will reveal how the major brain cell types (astrocytes and neurons) change at the protein level in AD and during aging and thus provide new targets for therapeutic and diagnostic strategies.

PHR: Cognitive resilience to Alzheimer?s disease (AD) and brain aging is a phenomenon whereby an individual?s cognitive functioning is better than predicted based on chronological age, genetic risk, and/or advanced neuropathology. Understanding the protective factors that improve cognitive resilience requires comprehensive identification of the protein components of unique brain cell types ? an analysis that cannot be performed longitudinally in human patients. In this project, we will combine human clinical and molecular data with proteomic data from neurons and immune cells from the hippocampus of mice that are resilient and susceptible to cognitive decline to identify novel proteins and complexes that could ultimately be therapeutically targeted to delay or prevent cognitive symptoms in AD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREV AND HEALTH PROMO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (in layperson language) The research projects contained in LIFESPAN-D will determine the health and cost-related effects of two large federal nutrition assistance programs (SNAP and WIC) on diabetes outcomes across the life span. Food insecurity is a common, potent factor that leads to type 2 diabetes among low-income populations and contributes to socioeconomic and racial/ethnic difference in health for people with diabetes. We will take advantage of new policies in SNAP and WIC rolling out in California so as to measure the effects of these programs on (a) diabetes care and diabetes complications (such as heart attacks, kidney failure, amputations) among older adults who already have type 2 diabetes, as well as (b) the development of pregnancy-related diabetes or type 2 diabetes or among pregnant mothers and adults with prediabetes, respectively.
PROJECT_TITLE: Evaluation of Natural Experiments of Nutrition Assistance to Prevent and Control Diabetes among Low-Income Communities

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maternal obesity is associated with adverse short- and long-term metabolic outcomes in the offspring. Lifestyle interventions of diet and exercise initiated before a planned pregnancy can ameliorate the health burden that obesity imposes in mother and child. This proposal aims to determine how maternal adipose function and neonatal stem cell metabolism improve after pregravid intervention, with the purpose of examining potential markers as predictors of long-term metabolic health in the offspring.

ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: Melanoma is one of the five most frequently diagnosed cancers in VA patients. Veterans appear to be at higher risk of melanoma due to deployment to tropical/subtropical zones with high ultraviolet (UV)-index climates and exposure to certain chemicals. Despite recent advances in the treatment of melanoma, existing therapies are not able to fully manage melanoma incidences or fatalities. Therefore, new molecular targets and treatments will be required to effectively manage this cancer. The goal of this study is to define the role and mechanism of the protein SIRT6 in melanoma. SIRT6 plays complex roles in several other types of cancer, but its function in melanoma has not been fully established. We will investigate the role of SIRT6 and the therapeutic significance of inhibiting SIRT6 ? alone and in combination with existing melanoma therapies ? in several clinically-relevant models. The outcomes of our proposed study may lead to the development of novel diagnostic, prognostic and therapeutic approaches that will improve the management of melanoma in Veterans.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent data has emerged which suggests a relationship between certain infectious agents and Alzheimer's Disease development and progression. Among these agents, Chlamydia pneumoniae stands out as one of the most likely to be involved. In this proposal we seek to understand what potential role C. pneumoniae infection may play in AD using mouse models.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Progression of HIV disease and premature deaths among persons living with HIV (PLWH) have been attributed foremost to insufficient engagement in medical care and adherence to HIV treatment regimens. In response, this study will test the efficacy and implementation factors of WiseApp, an evidence-based self-management medication adherence tool with Spanish-speaking PLWH in New York City and the Dominican Republic. This application has considerable public health relevance because it is delivered to an ethnic minority group who are disproportionally affected by HIV.
PROJECT_TITLE: Dissemination of the WiseApp for Improving Health Outcomes Across Settings

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Child and family violence are prevalent, costly, and serious public health problems which have been linked to household economic stress, which has also been greatly increased during the Covid-19 pandemic. Increasing household income and reducing food insecurity during periods of under- or unemployment (including the pandemic) may prevent multiple forms of family violence, improving the health, safety, and well-being of children and women. This research will rigorously evaluate the impacts of three important, yet under-studied economic assistance programs?the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children (WIC), and Unemployment Insurance (UI)?on the primary prevention of child abuse and neglect (CAN) and intimate partner violence (IPV) during the 2001-2020 period.
PROJECT_TITLE: Estimating the impact of SNAP, WIC, and UI in the primary prevention of multiple forms of family violence: a causal and computational approach

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study is likely to result in a feasible and effective strategy for the training of behavioral health staff and other school personnel in under-resourced rural schools. Linking PBIS with state-of-the-art mental health supports and well-trained school personnel will likely lead to improvement and sustainment of student mental health and academic engagement in rural schools.
PROJECT_TITLE: Development and Pilot Testing of a Remote Training Strategy for the Implementation of Mental Health Evidence-Based Practices in Rural K-8 Schools

ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative: Down syndrome (DS), caused by triplication of human chromosome 21, is the single most common risk factor for Alzheimer?s disease (AD) and people with DS typically develop early-onset AD and dementia by their 60s. Here, we propose to employ a novel human microglial chimeric mouse brain model that is created by transplantation of human DS induced pluripotent stem cell-derived microglia to study the role of human microglia in AD/DS in vivo. Results from this study will help us better understand the mechanisms underlying the AD in DS and may steer AD therapeutic interventions into a new direction of aiming at preventing microglial senescence or rejuvenating microglia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative:  Human HLA class II molecules are expressed on B cells, dendritic cells and macrophages, mediate important immune cell interactions and adopt two different shapes or conformations. In addition, monoclonal antibodies against HLA class II molecules can be used therapeutically to treat diseases such as B cell leukemia or lymphoma. The goal of this project is to define the conformer-reactivity of existing and newly developed HLA anti-class II monoclonal antibodies to provide the tools for the analysis of HLA class II conformation and immune function. 1

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exercise and skeletal muscle contraction are a cornerstone intervention for the treatment and prevention of clinical hyperglycemia and type 2 diabetes, via their ability to stimulate glucose uptake from the blood. These experiments will define how contraction-stimulated glucose uptake is regulated at the post-translational level, with particular focus on the roles of the p300 and CBP acetyltransferase enzymes. Knowledge gathered will bring forth novel insights into maximizing skeletal muscle glucose uptake, including during and after exercise.

PHR: Project Narrative: Alzheimer?s disease (AD) and related dementia syndromes (ADRD) represent an enormous challenge for patients, families, caregivers, and health care systems. Due to availability, cost, contraindications, and a number of other factors, currently available clinical diagnostic tools leave many people presenting with mild memory loss (and their families) with substantial uncertainty regarding their risk and likely rate of progression moving forward. In this project, we assess whether novel blood-based biomarkers of ADRD can be used to improve diagnosis and predict prospective rates of cognitive decline and thereby serve as powerful clinical and research tools.

PHR: Project Narrative The goal of these studies is to determine whether tau accumulation in serotonin neurons causes affective and sleep disturbances, leading to chronic sleep deprivation and hyperexcitability in serotonin neurons and accelerating the spread of tau pathology to the entorhinal cortex. The resulting loss of 5-HT input to the EC also enhances excitability of EC neurons that project to the hippocampus, promoting spread to this region and precipitating cognitive decline. Ultimately, this investigation may identify neural substrates underlying the early non-cognitive symptoms of AD which could lead to better treatments for this devastating disease.

PHR: NARRATIVE  Synaptic connections between neurons form the basis of network connectivity in the brain, and synaptic plasticity is widely believed to underlie adaptive behavior and learning. However, the dynamic range and modulation of synaptic strength in vivo is essentially unknown, raising a major challenge to our understanding of nervous system function. Here, we combine conceptual and methodological innovations to drive a pioneering exploration of the relationship between synaptic transmission and ongoing behavior.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cesarean delivery, when overused, is harmful to women and newborns, and raises healthcare costs without appreciable benefit; yet, despite significant efforts to reduce overuse, persistent and scalable improvement has been elusive. Organizational culture change strategies have been successful in improving outcomes in other areas of healthcare, but tend to receive little attention in statewide cesarean reduction initiatives as evidence- based tools to facilitate change are lacking. This proposal seeks to use rigorous user-centered design and implementation science principles to develop a ?Culture Change Toolset? to target the most upstream causes of L&D units? failure to adopt and sustain change in cesarean delivery rates.
PROJECT_TITLE: Supporting Vaginal Birth in Illinois: the Role of Unit Culture

PHR: Project Narrative  Surgical skill develops over the entire duration of a surgeon?s career, and well beyond their supervised training period. Currently, no methods for objective assessment of skill performance exist to identify and accelerate improvement in skill and, in turn, improve patient outcomes. This project develops a novel usable video-based personalized surgical learning platform, automated using artificial intelligence methods, for surgeons to effectively improve their skill.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding the impact of an academic detailing program and the degree to which the program improves safe and appropriate opioid prescribing practices for chronic pain among primary care providers is expected to contribute to reductions in fatal and nonfatal opioid overdose from prescription opioids. Thus, this proposal is relevant to the part of the mission from the National Center for Injury Prevention and Control in regard to evaluation of strategies that will directly improve the ability of state and local health departments to implement and improve interventions that can be immediately translated into action to prevent fatal and nonfatal opioid overdose from prescription and/or illicit opioids.
PROJECT_TITLE: Impacting the Prescribing of Opioids through Academic Detailing

IC_NAME: National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases (NCIRD)
PHR: Project narrative This project will provide national estimates for burden of acute respiratory infection in terms of incidence, mortality, hospitalization and economic cost among elderly population in India which is currently lacking. The project will provide information on barriers for adoption of influenza vaccination in India. The data collected in this project will help in carrying out advocacy and will inform the policy makers for possible intervention for prevention and control of Influenza. One of the positive spin-offs of this project will be capacity building among regional field sites and laboratories working in the area of influenza and other respiratory pathogens and creation of a sustainable network
PROJECT_TITLE: Strengthening Evidence-based Advocacy for Influenza Prevention and Control in India.

PHR: Relevance PWID continue to have high rates of HIV and high mortality rates in the US and internationally. As we have found high rates of people who actively use drugs in the social networks of MAT patients in the US, study findings have strong relevance to the development of MAT and HIV prevention and care interventions in the US as well as internationally.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Management of chronic conditions with families is complex and offers a myriad of opportunities for system failures to occur that can lead to patient harm; such failures can have lethal results. We have identified key opportunities to reduce the 2 most egregious harms in this setting?medication errors and treatment delays?in children with two model conditions, type 1 diabetes and autism spectrum disorder. In collaboration with Mad*Pow, an award-winning design firm, and University of Wisconsin Systems Engineering Initiative for Patient Safety, we will redesign processes for management of medications and serious illnesses between the clinic and home, and prepare to disseminate nationally through our networks.
PI_NAMEs: KIRKENDALL, ERIC STEVEN; WALSH, KATHLEEN ELIZABETH (contact);
PROJECT_TITLE: Ambulatory Pediatric Safety Learning Lab

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: T cell anergy is a critical component of the immune system that allows for tolerance to self and is a vital mechanism frequently broken in a disease context like autoimmunity. Loss of the transcription factor Runx1 results in an increased frequency of anergic T cells, and these cells are capable of suppressing other T cells in their surrounding environment. This study aims to uncover the mechanisms Runx1 utilizes to regulate immune tolerance and thereby regulate immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hazardous drinking and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) are commonly co-occurring conditions that are prevalent and difficult to treat. Concordant with NIAAA initiatives (i.e., Strategic Plan 2017-2021, Goal 4: Treatment), this proposal focuses on elucidating the underlying risk factors that may influence the development and maintenance of this co-occurrence by developing and refining a brief, integrated intervention to concurrently target hazardous drinking and PTSD symptoms. Anxiety sensitivity is a malleable, cognitive- affective vulnerability factor that may underpin (i.e., explain) hazardous drinking and PTSD comorbidity; thus, the proposed research aims for the applicant to assist on developing and evaluating a proof-of-concept randomized controlled trial and test the relative efficacy of a novel, computer-based personalized feedback intervention among hazardous drinkers with subclinical PTSD and elevated anxiety sensitivity.
