IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Empiric antibiotic selection decisions in nursing homes (NHs) are frequently suboptimal, threatening resident safety by increasing risks of adverse drug events and antibiotic resistance. Cumulative susceptibility reports based on patient cultures, known as antibiograms, are increasingly used in NHs to help guide empiric antibiotic decisions. Most NHs collect an insufficient number of cultures to permit development of a facility-specific antibiogram. In this study, we propose to develop and evaluate an alternative approach to characterizing local susceptibility patterns in NHs, called a weighted incidence syndromic combined antibiogram (WISCA). This work will also lead to the development of a toolkit to support the implementation and evaluation of WISCAs in NHs. Outcomes from this work will help support future studies examining the effects of WISCAs on antibiotic decisions in NHs. We are optimistic that this and subsequent research in this area will lead to tangible improvements in the quality and safety of antibiotic use in NHs.
PI_NAMEs: CRNICH, CHRISTOPHER J (contact); FURUNO, JON P; JUMP, ROBIN ; NACE, DAVID A.;
PROJECT_TITLE: Developing a novel antibiogram tool to improve empiric antibiotic prescribing in nursing homes
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREV AND HEALTH PROMO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE Given limited resources for the prevention and management of cardiovascular risk factors, it is important to understand how social determinants of health influence disease risk. This study seeks to prioritize those social determinants of health that are associated with a greater burden of diabetes and separately, hypertension, which may then be used in the development of targeted prevention programs and policies.
PROJECT_TITLE: Prioritizing county-level social determinants that contribute to the greater burden of diabetes and hypertension in the US

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Healthcare costs for falls have reached 55 billion dollars annually in the US with falls in older adults impacting nearly every family, in every sector, of every community. Leveraging 911 fall calls as activation events could transform our ability to identify high risk individuals and significantly impact fall prevention strategies. At the completion of this study, a scalable EMS fall prediction tool will be developed to elucidate the impact that frailty, cognitive impairment and the home environment have on emergency fall events in order to activate and transform effective fall prevention solutions in the homes of vulnerable older patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is no effective treatment to alleviate neurobehavioral and memory decline for patients with MCI or early stage of Alzheimer?s disease (AD). Recent studies highlight a substantial loss of monoamine neurotransmitter inputs into the hippocampus during the early disease course and their contributions to cognitive functions, suggesting that restoration of monoamine neurotransmitters has significant therapeutic values to treat such symptoms. In this application, we will optimize the dosing regimen of our novel biogenic drug delivery system using commensal gut bacteria to give L-DOPA in a non-pulsatile manner in a mouse model of AD and assess pharmacokinetics and toxicity, in order to evaluate this as one of potential treatment strategy for AD.

IC_NAME: National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases (NCIRD)
PHR: Project Narrative Fast and scalable production of vaccine components is urgently needed for protecting public health against existing and emerging pathogens. In the proposed work we combine our experience in mass rearing production of insects and genetic engineering with CRISPR-Cas9 to produce influenza antigens in yellow mealworms and black blow flies. Our approach will generate a novel non-mammalian genetic model for fast and high-throughput scale vaccine development.
PROJECT_TITLE: Rapid mass production of human influenza vaccine in insects using genome editing

ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Incontinence associates with military service and post-traumatic stress disorder in both male and female Veterans. Overactive bladder (OAB) incontinence is disproportionately experienced by Veterans and women, is correlated to depression among Veterans, and women are increasing as a proportion of the Veteran population. Urinary incontinence will continue to affect Veterans disproportionately as the Veteran population ages. This project will demonstrate the use of low intensity, focused ultrasonic neuromodulation (UNS) for noninvasive treatment of OAB through tibial nerve stimulation. The effect of UNS on neural and bladder activity will be compared to electrical stimulation of the tibial nerve. UNS from a wearable cuff could offer at-home OAB treatment which would greatly expand access to treatment for Veterans who have limited mobility, income, or live in rural locales. Future work could use the UNS technology platform to stimulate new nerve targets for drug- free treatment of other challenging conditions such as peripheral neuropathic pain of trunk or limbs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative (three sentences) Neurodegenerative diseases and CNS injuries (stroke) are devastating because of the limited regenerative capacity of the mature tissues. The complexity of the structure and function of the nervous system is achieved through extensive developmental processes and is maintained in part due to the resiliency of the cells to maintain function and resist activating cell death processes. Here we will investigate if processes to resist degeneration, i.e., senescence further promotes tissue degeneration in neurodegenerative disease and if removal of senescent neurons improves outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Human genome engineering has widely anticipated promise as a healthcare strategy, but technologies in development are unlikely to safely or efficiently introduce a gene into the human genome. Starkly missing from transgene introduction strategies is an approach based on what is already quite successful across eukaryotic evolution: gene insertion by synthesis of an RNA-templated complementary DNA (cDNA). The evolutionary success of RNA template-specific, DNA site-specific LINE/non-LTR retroelement insertion begs to be engineered to develop a transgene introduction technology for human gene therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a common chronic autoimmune disease consisting of inflammatory arthritis. Patients with RA are susceptible to developing interstitial lung disease (ILD), which results in substantial excess morbidity and mortality. This research will investigate whether RA-related autoantibodies and articular inflammation contribute to subclinical and clinically apparent RA-ILD across the disease course of RA (pre-RA, early RA, established RA). Discoveries made through this research are directly relevant to the National Institutes of Health?s mission by providing insight into RA and RA-ILD pathogenesis that may ultimately lead to RA-ILD screening and prevention strategies for this devastating complication of RA.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will complete historical dose reconstruction of per and polyfluorinated substances (PFAS) in serum concentrations in residents of two communities with drinking water contaminated by PFAS. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glaucoma is the most common cause of irreversible blindness and will affect more than 100 million people between 40 to 80 years old by 2040. Based on our previous work that revealed the significant therapeutic potential of ER stress modulation for glaucomatous degeneration of optic nerve and retinal ganglion cells (RGCs), the proposed experiments will continue to develop novel neuroprotective strategies to preserve RGC and ON integrity and visual function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID) are the second leading cause of dementia, and a major contributor to Alzheimer?s disease (AD), the most common cause of dementia. Non-invasive biomarkers will be critical for the development of prevention and treatment strategies for VCID. In response to RFA-NS-21-005, a strong partnership between Washington University School of Medicine and the University of Texas, Southwestern Medical Center (WU-UTSW) has been developed to serve as a new site for the Small Vessel VCID Consortium. Because VCID sits at the interface between cerebrovascular risk and age-related dementia, this partnership leverages strengths in both the cerebrovascular and Alzheimer?s disease (AD) research infrastructures at WU and UTSW. We have assembled a group of stroke and AD clinicians, clinical investigators, and scientists that that have diverse expertise in VCID and AD pathobiology, clinical trials implementation and management, fluid biomarker collection and measurement, MR image acquisition and processing, informatics and data sharing, and statistics. The collective expertise of the WU-UTSW group will not only permit the implementation of the current VCID biomarker study, but will also provide unique proficiencies in refining the design of the current and future biomarker studies for VCID.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative: Despite considerable effort to advance quality improvement, performance measurement, and a recent pivot toward paying for value intended to benefit the public, US healthcare continues to underachieve -- paying more for less value than its peers while putting patients at risk of physical, emotional and financial harm. Widespread dissatisfaction with care measurement is only amplified in primary care, where better alignment is needed so that assessment and payment policies reinforce what patients and clinicians know to be valuable: continuity, comprehensiveness, and the avoidance of low value services. Starting with a focus on low value care, we will convene a nationally-representative group of primary care and LVC measurement experts to establish criteria for evaluating candidate indicators and measures, and select a defined set for dissemination and implementation by payers.
PROJECT_TITLE: Advancing & Improving Measurement and Value in Primary Care (The AIM-PC Starfield Summit)

PROJECT_TITLE: Michigan Youth Violence Prevention Center: Building Evidence for Gun Violence Prevention

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Through mentored research career development of the next generation of interdisciplinary team members, leaders, and innovators in dissemination and implementation science and learning health systems, the Stakeholder-Partnered Implementation Research and Innovation Translation (SPIRIT) K12 Program will advance our knowledge of delivery and implementation strategies for proven interventions in real-world practice and community settings. In closing the gap between evidence-based interventions and their uptake across diverse settings and populations, including historically underserved populations who manifest wide disparities in health status, SPIRIT will contribute to improved health system performance as well as patient outcomes and overall quality of life of adults and children, and their families, who live and often struggle with a broad range of chronic conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Rotator cuff tears in the shoulder occur at the fibrocartilage interface that connects tendon to bone. While the tendon and bone can be surgically reattached, the interface does not heal, leaving the rotator cuff susceptible to re-failure. This project will develop and thoroughly characterize a stratified biomaterial to guide functional repair of the fibrocartilage interface linking tendon and bone.

PHR: Project Narrative Meniscal defects occur frequently in adults, with tears occurring in at least 60 out of every 100,000 patients. However, the meniscus lacks native healing capacity, and severe tears are treated through removal of meniscal tissue via partial meniscectomy. The proposed research seeks to build a fragmented multifiber assembly scaffold to promote tissue regeneration which will provide a critical step towards bringing tissue engineering approaches that promote meniscal healing closer to clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is growing consensus that community gun violence exposure and its consequences may extend to youth even if they do not report it and even if they do not hear or see it in person. Because objective statistics on gun violence at the small-area level have not been available for use in population research, existing studies have largely relied on self-reported survey items which prohibit examination of this broader conceptualization of exposure. The proposed project will examine the population prevalence and health-related consequences of youths' exposure to community gun violence, regardless of whether the violence was experienced firsthand, and assess possible points of early intervention associated with variations in the impacts of community gun violence exposure.
PROJECT_TITLE: Prevalence of community gun violence exposure and consequences for adolescent well-being: identifying sources of heterogeneity to disrupt the cycle of violence

PROJECT_TITLE: Core-003

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Uveitis is a sight-threatening intraocular disease that affects young working-age individuals, and is caused by a myriad of different etiologies that can present with overlapping features, resulting in a complex and difficult diagnostic process. The proposed project explores the enormous advantages of metagenomic next generation sequencing to develop a thoroughly validated approach for sensitive, unbiased and comprehensive detection of known uveitis-causing pathogens, which could additionally shed some light into novel etiologies of uveitis in the large number of cases that remain negative after extensive laboratory workup. We hope this work will ultimately provide an unparalleled all-in-one diagnostic assay validated for clinical application that translates into improved care for patients suffering from this debilitating disease.

PHR: If this pilot study finds that our Rage Against the Pain (RAP) program is feasible and acceptable to Veterans who experience chronic low back pain, it will provide an innovative approach to address a top priority of the VA ? using complementary and integrative health (CIH) programs for pain management and opioid use reduction. The next step is to test the effectiveness of the program and issues around its broader implementation in VA using a Hybrid Type I trial. Our long-term goal is to develop a scalable and sustainable alternative yoga program to help Veterans with chronic pain who may not find other available pain management options to be appealing or effective. Eventually, we envision offering these classes both on and off VA campuses. Were this to come to fruition, the VA could use the program as a community outreach strategy to interest and engage Veterans in the community in the VA system of care. Ultimately, we hope that this program could improve access to quality care for Veterans.

PHR: NARRATIVE The thalamus shares extensive connectivity with the cortex and is involved in on going cortical functioning, including communication between cortical areas [1,35,47,53]. The proposed experiments will provide new data on the role of both direct and transthalamic circuitry in corticocortical communication using Pulvinar as an exemplary HO thalamic nucleus. Understanding the function of each pathway will have important implications for our view of cortical processing and may provide circuit-level context for interpreting cognitive deficits associated with HO thalamic nuclei, such as those seen in Schizophrenia [19-25].

PHR: Project Narrative Aging is associated with significant declines in muscle mass, strength, and physical performance, all of which lead to disability, loss of independence, and poor clinical outcomes. Currently, health care providers have no treatment options to offer their patients to slow declines in physical function. Evidence suggests that statins could be an effective treatment for preserving physical function by preventing disabling chronic conditions; however, a large number of patients discontinue statins because of side effects including muscle pain and weakness. Thus, determining whether statins can preserve physical function and independence in older adults is needed to inform treatment guidelines for the use of statins in older adults.

PHR: Pathologic ?-synuclein spreading from the gut to the brain is an important driver to aging-associated ?- synucleinopathy, a group of neurodegenerative diseases with no effective therapy. It remains largely unknown how aging-associated blood-borne components modulate the initiation and progression of ?-synucleinopathy. Using the heterochronic blood exchange (HBE) approach, we will study how two aging-associated HBE- modulated plasma proteins (FGL1 and sLAG3) affect the pathogenesis of ?-synucleinopathy. If successful, our discoveries will facilitate the development of early diagnosis and therapy for ?-synucleinopathy, based on detecting and modulating these two blood-borne aging-associated factors. Our ultimate goal is to discover new ways to help people live longer healthier lives by modulating rejuvenation and age-acceleration factors.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: A major constraint on the evolution of very large bodies and long lifespans is an increased risk of developing cancer, because larger bodies have more cells that can potentially turn cancerous and long lives increases the time to acquire a cancer-causing mutation. There are no correlations, however, between body size and cancer risk or lifespan and cancer risk across species this lack of correlation is often referred to as `Peto's Paradox'. The proposed research will discover some of the genetic and molecular mechanisms that broke the constraint on the evolution of large bodies and/or long lifespans in elephants, whales, and bats and gain new insights into the biology of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will assess how the neocortex controls activity and sensory processing in the thalamus. The neocortex, thalamus, and their connections comprise the vast majority of the human brain, and their bidirectional interactions are thought to be critical for sensation, perception, control of movement, and cognition. Communication problems between the neocortex and thalamus are common features of many neurological and psychiatric diseases, so the results of my research will contribute to a base of knowledge that may lead to improved treatment strategies.

PHR: Project Narrative: Alzheimer?s disease (AD) is incurable and the most common form of age-related dementia; failures of recent clinical trials highlight need for continued research into novel therapeutic targets, such as microRNAs (miRNA) on the amyloid-? (A?) precursor protein (APP) and tau protein. While a great deal of study has been done on the roles of miRNA in AD, these have generally not investigated the metabolic functions of miRNAs; however, we have recently discovered an miRNA, miR346, which stimulates APP translation but does so as part of cellular iron (Fe) homeostasis; therefore, we propose studying specific interactions among miR346, Fe homeostasis, tau protein, and an additional miRNA (miR298) to elucidate both the normal and pathogenic roles of miRNAs in Fe homeostasis in the brain. This proposal is significant by identifying specific novel physiological roles for miR346 and miR298 and elucidating novel regulatory mechanisms associated with AD pathology, specifically potential synergy of APP and tau in a vital cellular function and their co-regulation by common miRNA species, pointing to potential ?one bullet, two target? approaches where treatment by a single substance could restore normal levels of multiple proteins and readjust affected pathways in AD.

PHR: This project will develop and implement a strategy to identify and recruit a probability sample of LGBT older adults, assess the quality of the resulting sample, identify and develop survey measures of social relationships and experiences to be administered in a follow-up interview of this sample, and conduct a controlled randomized field test of in-home vs. remote interviewing for the follow-up interviews. The product of this work will be a sampling methodology, screening process, set of measures, and field approach?optimized where appropriate through randomized experiments?tailored to conduct the first ever U.S. national study of LGBT older adults using an address-based probability sample with a high response rate (NLAP), to be submitted separately based on the results of this application.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: The generation of coordinated behaviors requires a balance in the output of competing neuronal circuits. By studying the developmental regulation of this balance in the C. elegans embryo, our goal is to understand these processes at the level of the individual neuron and synapse. Through this, we hope to better understand how related processes may function or fail in human development and disease.

PHR: Project Narrative West Virginia, our target population, ranks at or near the bottom in many US health indicators (e.g., cardiovascular and cancer morbidity/mortality) and their associated risk factors, and is at the epicenter of the US opioid crisis. The WV Prevention Research Center, inclusive of a highly committed and experienced Community Partnership Board, will collaborate with state and local health departments and other multisector partners to conduct applied public health research, evaluation, technical assistance, and training. Our intended outcomes include a sustained PRC infrastructure; increased capacity in prevention research; and environmental, policy, and practice-based changes improve population health.

IC_NAME: National Center for Complementary & Integrative Health
PHR: Project Narrative Adaptive control of behavior is critical for survival and requires not only brain control of muscle activity, but also descending control of organism physiology and internal organ function. We will dissect the neural circuits and principles governing the learning and adaptive ?motor? control of internal organ function by investigating conditioned insulin release and conditioned immunosuppression, mediated by the innervation of the pancreas and spleen, respectively. We will employ state-of-the art viral tracing methods to map first, second and third- order innervation of spleen and pancreas, RNA sequencing to characterize neuron identity, in vivo calcium imaging to measure neuronal activity in descending circuits, and chemo- and optogenetic tools to causally test how descending circuits impact splenic and pancreatic function.

PHR: Narrative  Understanding the role of policy and environmental factors in diabetes at the community level will allow for better interventions to reduce disparities in diabetes, and help improve the health of the public: as the Coordinating Center for the CDC's multi-site program Community Characteristics Associated with Geographic Disparities in Diabetes and Cardiometabolic Health, we will contribute the expertise in both scientific content and management to further this understanding. The Coordinating Center will support a variety of activities, including operations, analytics, as well as information technology activities, with a primary goal of facilitating a collaborative relationship across the study's multiple sites.

PHR: Project Narrative Injury from falling is a serious concern for the elderly and other populations at risk such as Parkinson or Epilepsy patients. We are developing a device that will read electrical brain (EEG) signals and, together with motion sensors, will be able to predict a fall more accurately than existing methods used today to trigger micro-airbags that protect the wearer from injury. This project will serve as a proof of concept to show that adding an EEG signal to the fall detection algorithm (which has never been done before) can improve the accuracy and reliability of existing products in the market.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative  The firearm death rate in the United States is typically the highest among western industrialized nations, with 21,789 intentional violence-related firearm deaths in 2017, one third of whom are in the 15-29 year old age range (CDC, 2019). We collected longitudinal data from two urban samples at high risk for weapons crimes and gun violence exposure (Flint, MI, and Jersey City, NJ), covering developmental periods from age 7 to 27. Because we used similar measures in both studies (e.g., violence/weapon exposure, social cognitions about violence and weapon exposure, violent and weapon-related behavior), we can use a robust approach to integrating data across the samples to understand how risk factors for gun violence at multiple levels of the social context (including gun violence at the neighborhood level) affect the development of violence-related and weapons-related social cognitions, that in turn shape use of guns and other weapons into early adulthood. We expect that the findings will have substantial implication for enhancing the impact of community- and school-based prevention programs targeting firearms violence specifically and youth violence more generally.
PROJECT_TITLE: Exposure to Violence and Subsequent Weapons Use: Integrative data analysis across two urban high-risk communities

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Every day millions of people, many of whom are enjoying an active retirement and leading otherwise normal lives, must take oral medications to control their risk of blood clots due to heart disease or other conditions. However, because there is no reliable home test to provide current information on their blood clotting status, many of these patients will require hospitalization because of an unintentional (and avoidable) bleeding incident. The rapid, low? volume blood coagulation analysis platform developed and validated in this proposal promises to give these patients and their doctors the assurance that their medication dosage meets their changing needs in the comfort of their home as frequently as needed.

PHR: Project Narrative Sexual and gender minorities (SGM) experience greater physical, socioeconomic, and clinical health disparities than their heterosexual and/or cisgender counterparts and are widely underrepresented in aging research. Of the few research projects conducted among SGM adults living with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) or SGM caregivers of people with ADRD, there has never been a nationally collaborative, concerted effort either to enroll SGM individuals in aging related research or collect data pertaining to ADRD from SGM patients or SGM ADRD caregivers. This proposal will focus on increasing engagement, recruitment, inclusion, and retention of SGM individuals in clinical aging related research using a community based participatory approach, and data collection from in person activities, online data collection and the implementation of a national research registry.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research examines the long-term effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on health care delivery, quality and equity for people living with multiple chronic conditions. In a unique national community health center practice ?laboratory? caring for more than 2.6 million patients, time-series analyses will reveal the evolution of practice innovations such as telehealth, integrated mental health services, and patient outreach, and will discover their effect on patient care quality and equity. Comparative case studies sampled from the quantitative data will identify and characterize transportable practice innovations to advance equity of care for health disparity populations living with multiple chronic conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREV AND HEALTH PROMO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Providing health coverage for 37 million American adults who are poor, aged, or disabled, policy decisions made by state Medicaid programs can have a profound impact on the health and healthcare of people living with diabetes. Our proposed center will combine multidisciplinary strengths in diabetes care, health policy, data science, and causal inference and will leverage existing, unique access to national UnitedHealth Group Medicaid managed care claims and harmonized EHR data, state Medicaid, and Medicare claims from 3 states. With these assets, we will utilize rigorous natural experimental designs for the timely and policy-relevant evaluation of 1) the health and economic effects of different state-level managed care approaches for medication prior authorization and medication refill durations for diabetes medications; and 2) the medium- to longer-term effects of ACA coverage expansion on diabetes care and outcomes.
PROJECT_TITLE: Effects of Medicaid Coverage and State-Level Delivery Approaches on Healthcare Quality, Outcomes, and Costs for Adults with Diabetes

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malfunction of ?2?4 has been shown to cause retinal diseases such as night blindness and cone dystrophy. This project is aimed to elucidate detailed molecular mechanism underlying ?2?4?s function in retina and to advance our understanding on the pathology of night blindness and cone dystrophy for better therapeutics development. The results from the proposed research will also provide valuable molecular insights into retinal synapse formation and function and hence facilitate the optimization of the current transplantation therapy of which the biggest challenge is to re-establish the connectivity between the transplanted photoreceptors and the host retinal neurons.

PHR: Project Narrative Various adverse and protective environments may affect child development. The Healthy Brain and Child Development National Consortium (HBCD-NC) will follow 7,500 mothers and their children from 24 locations across the U.S. from before birth to 10 years of age to better understand which harmful and protective environments exert the greatest impact on child development. This study will help to improve the health and development of children across the nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This is an application for an administrative artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML) supplement [PA- 20-272 and NOT-OD-21-094] to parent award 5R01DC016612, Lee, KiBum (PI). To address the challenges associated with studying a complex inner hair cells (IHCs) environment with only a limited number of observations, such as induced measurement bias and irreproducibility of experimental results, we propose to develop a conditional adversarial network to recapitulate the transcriptomes of inner and outer hair cells to supplement downstream analysis. Then, we will validate our AI/ML experiments by comparing the transcriptomes of differentiated iMOP cells to the generated transcriptomes by examining the Pearson correlation between marker genes and sequencing experiments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This award will assist Dr. Riana Pryor in becoming an independent investigator identifying strategies to minimize the negative impact of challenging environments on worker health and safety by providing enhanced training and expertise to achieve the following training aims: 1) develop expertise in the use of wearable technologies to monitor worker fatigue and prevent injury, and 2) acquire expertise in the impact of repeated heat exposures on human health. A hot work environment leads to fatigue, hyperthermia, and dehydration, increasing injury risk and reducing productivity. The proposed study aims will provide data to inform the NIOSH recommendations for fatigue mitigation and to meet long-term health needs of workers during consecutive days of heat stress.
PROJECT_TITLE: Short- and long-term health consequences of workers during consecutive days of heat stress

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glaucoma, which is associated with vision-related disability and poor quality of life, disproportionately impacts individuals of low socioeconomic status and those belonging to racial minorities in the United States, but disparities in vision- and health-related outcomes resulting from glaucoma have not been studied. Additionally, the impact of frailty on these outcomes are not clearly understood. Examining the relationship between sociodemographic characteristics, frailty, eye care utilization and vision- and health-related outcomes will identify barriers associated with glaucoma care and have important implications for healthcare policy and patient-specific risk-stratification, ultimately leading to improved outcomes.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative A significant number of patients are harmed or die every year because of unsafe, inappropriate or inadequate healthcare delivery. This study focuses on how registered nurses, the largest health workforce component, with identified potential to improve patient safety, can be effectively organized into specific care models to significantly improve the quality and safety of care delivery. By leveraging sophisticated analytic methods that capture the dynamic interdependency of contextual factors in nursing practice, this study will be the first to examine nursing as a care delivery model to increase care quality and safety, to measure its effectiveness, and provide specific `recipes' of successful care model configurations that health systems can match to their needs to achieve intended quality and safety outcomes.
PROJECT_TITLE: Organizing nursing to improve care quality and safety: a hybrid implementation-effectiveness study
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Diagnostic errors in primary care are costly and can be attributable to failures or delays in follow up on diagnostic testing, referrals, and patient symptoms. The proposed research seeks to ?close the loop? on this public health problem by employing system engineering methods in three diverse healthcare practices to create a system that provides highly reliable follow-up of diagnostic tests, referrals, and symptom evolution. Results will be disseminated broadly so as to improve diagnostic safety nationally.
PI_NAMEs: BENNEYAN, JAMES C; PHILLIPS, RUSSELL SCOTT (contact); SCHIFF, GORDON DAVID;
PROJECT_TITLE: R18 Closed Loop Diagnostics : AHRQ R18 Patient Safety Learning Laboratories

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Our work is expected to lead to methodological advancements in high dimensional risk modeling with incomplete data, which is instrumental in the individualized health care. Accompanied by user-friendly software, it will offer researchers state-of-art statistical tools for risk prediction with high-dimensional predictors. Applications of these methods by researchers in biostatistics and epidemiology are expected to help answer important scientific questions through predictive modeling beyond EHR data analysis, and ultimately to contribute to improved health care.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis is life-threatening disorder caused by an unregulated systemic response to an infection. Sepsis survivors often experience chronic functional and cognitive deficits, yet there no targeted therapies to prevent the onset, progression, or severity of these symptoms. This proposal will test whether a protein that resides on brain microvessels is a viable therapeutic target to prevent chronic neurological impairment in sepsis survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Dynamic CT perfusion studies are utilized to make decisions about invasive treatments for stroke. Traditional post-processing methods rely on the selection of a vessel to represent the blood flow to the brain, which unfortunately leads to systematic errors in analysis. The goal of this study is to evaluate a new stroke post-processing method that accounts for the spatial information in the dynamic images, relying on the physics of fluid flow and diffusion to generate perfusion maps.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Dozens of genetic loci have been implicated in Alzheimer?s disease risk, yet the underlying causal genes, variants, and biological mechanisms involved in disease development remain unclear. This proposal combines patient-derived induced pluripotent stem cells, precise genome editing, and innovative transplantation techniques to experimentally investigate the impact of prioritized genes, variants, and enhancers on the physiology of disease-relevant microglia both in vitro and in vivo. This approach has the potential to both greatly enhance our understanding of genes and pathways causally involved in disease development and lay the foundation for future researchers interested in translating the results of genome-wide association studies from pure statistical association to biological function.

PHR: There has been a significant growth in the number of women Veterans that are served by the Veterans Health Administration (VA) in the past 30 years, and this number is expected to continue to grow. Due to injury, disease and aging, the number of women who require mobility devices (canes, walkers, wheelchairs, scooters) has also increased. Yet, little is known about what needs women Veterans have related to mobility devices. Further, Public Law 114-223 (2016) specifically noted that VA should ensure that sufficient research dollars are appropriated for prosthetic research specific to women Veterans. In this project, we will assess women Veterans? needs for mobility devices through a national survey and follow-up interviews with a sample or respondents. In addition, we will interview key stakeholders in VA regarding women Veterans? needs and ways VA can address them based on survey findings. The result will be a set of recommendations to address women Veterans? needs for mobility devices.

PROJECT_TITLE: Assessing Women Veterans' Needs for Mobility Devices

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cells within an organism are surrounded by the extracellular matrix, which not only acts as physical scaffolding to maintain tissue structure but also provides essential signaling cues to facilitate proper tissue homeostasis. Recently, work from our lab showed that an enzyme that re-models extracellular matrix network can influence stress resistance and immune response. We propose to investigate the mechanisms by which cells can sense such changes in the extracellular matrix and thus modulate cell and organismal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of the proposed project is to conduct rigorous longitudinal clinical validation of MarkVCID-selected biomarkers in a diverse cohort free of dementia, and to investigate the associations of these biomarkers with SVD neuropathologic indices, working synergistically with other consortium sites and contributing scientific expertise, experimental infrastructure, and scientific guidance. Rigorously validated, high-quality SVD biomarkers will have broad clinical implications including refined participant selection and enhanced monitoring of the treatment response in clinical drug and prevention trials, as well as long term implications in the advancement of diagnosis, prevention and treatment of SVD related cognitive decline and dementia in aging.

PHR: Mutations in Complement Factor H (CFH) that interfere with heparan sulfate (HS) binding are major risk factors for age-related macular degeneration (AMD), the leading cause of blindness in the developed world. Although, the roles of CFH and HS in AMD are not understood, preliminary data demonstrate that interactions between HS and a CFH homolog are required for cilia compartment organization in C. elegans sensory neurons and this function appears to be conserved in human photoreceptors. The molecular genetic dissection of these novel CFH and HS functions proposed here will provide substantial insight into a previously unappreciated mechanism for AMD pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Narrative  Interventions to address the opioid crisis and reduce the rate of overdose will require engaging front- line clinicians to help them both treat pain more safely without overusing opioids and increase the use of treatments for opioid use disorder. This proposal builds on an existing collaboration between a leading implementation research team and the Oregon Health Authority Public Health Division. We will rigorously evaluate clinician-facing interventions implemented over the next 3 years, assessing their impact on clinicians? knowledge and behavior and how those changes are reflected in opioid prescriptions, engagement of patients in treatment for opioid use disorder, and reduced harms from overdoses.
PROJECT_TITLE: Engaging clinicians to improve opioid safety and reduce overdose risk

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Dysregulation of IL-17-secreting CD4+ (Th17) cells is linked to a variety of autoimmune and chronic inflammatory diseases. We have shown that the plant natural product derivative, halofuginone (HF), potently and selectively suppresses Th17 responses by binding the mammalian prolyl-tRNA synthetase, EPRS, and silencing Stat3 translation. Using both genetic and chemical biology approaches, our studies will elucidate the transcript-selective translational regulatory mechanisms that underlie HF?s bioactivity, which in turn will advance our understanding of the protein synthetic machinery and cellular responses to amino starvation, while informing new approaches to treat Th17-mediated immune pathologies.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project narrative As evidence about the impact of social and economic factors on health grows, health care organizations are increasingly experimenting with strategies to better integrate social and medical services in order to improve health outcomes. To help inform these efforts, this study will enable key stakeholders to strengthen the quality and utility of integrated social and medical data in an existing multi-sector care coordination platform. We will then evaluate the impacts of the data integration platform on chronic disease management and prevention for primary care, population health management, and community health improvement activities in low income, racially diverse populations.
PI_NAMEs: FICHTENBERG, CAROLINE M; HESSLER, DANIELLE MARIE (contact);
PROJECT_TITLE: Using social and medical data integration to improve primary care and population level chronic disease prevention and management

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our novel public health systems approach leverages partnerships among public health, public safety, and health systems to provide accessible, scalable, and effective treatments for stimulant use disorder. At the conclusion of the proposed study, we will have conducted a rigorous evaluation of a secondary prevention strategy implemented at a systems-level to prevent stimulant related overdoses. Our findings will provide empirical evidence for a replicable intervention to increase initiation, guide treatment provision, and reduce morbidity and mortality associated with the overdose crisis.
PI_NAMEs: AL-TAYYIB, ALIA  (contact); RINEHART, DEBORAH ; SIMPSON, SCOTT ALAN;
PROJECT_TITLE: Beginning Early and Assertive Treatment for Methamphetamine Use Disorder (BEAT Meth): A comprehensive systems-level secondary prevention strategy to prevent stimulant related overdoses

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREV AND HEALTH PROMO
PHR: Project Narrative Reducing Cancer Disparities within the Black community in Jackson, MS through Community-Led Tobacco- Related Social Norm Change will evaluate Project BAT (Black people Against Tobacco), an ongoing community-led intervention to empower low-income African American and Black communities to change social norms around tobacco utilization and promote optimal health and cancer prevention throughout the community. There is broad understanding of the function of norms around tobacco use as well as what the threshold for ?tipping points? of norms generally are, but the impact of using a community-engaged model to drive social norm change among Black and minority communities remains unexamined. Through our proposed rigorous evaluation of Project BAT, which addresses the myriad environmental factors that contribute to tobacco use, we seek to demonstrate to the research community that social norms change is achievable through community-based action.
PROJECT_TITLE: Reducing Cancer Disparities within the Black community in Jackson, MS through Community-Led Tobacco-Related Social Norm Change

PHR: Relevance  Dementias cause profound cognitive, emotional, and functional deficits. As the disease progresses, people with dementia become increasingly dependent on caregivers, who are at heightened risk for mental and physical health problems. Commercializing assistive technology that monitors worrisome behaviors, improves safety, and reduces social isolation in the home environment can improve the lives of caregivers and people with dementia worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative  The Department of Energy and predecessor agencies have been involved in the research, production and testing of nuclear weapons since the 1940s. During that time, numerous facilities, both government and privately-owned, were constructed or leased across the country to support the effort, generating large quantities of radioactive and hazardous materials that resulted in the contamination of many of the facilities and surrounding areas.  In 1994, to protect the staff and workers doing DOE cleanup and waste management work, legislation was enacted to allow the Department of Energy to fund NIEHS to develop Worker Training programs that would assure workers, other facility personnel, and community responders the knowledge and skills to protect themselves and their communities from hazardous conditions in the workplace.  The National Partnership for Environmental Technology Education (PETE) and its Community College Consortium for Health and Safety Training (CCCHST) has been continuously supported by NIEHS since 1995 to provide quality training that is efficient, consistent, flexible, and cost-effective for the multiple tiers of contractors at DOE sites including the Oakridge complex, Pantex, the Savannah River Site, with Los Alamos National Lab soon to be added, annually providing 7,000 students with 400 courses for a total 50,000 contact hours of training, with an average 75 courses delivered online.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative For clinicians, using patient health information exchanged across healthcare systems is often cumbersome and disruptive. Integrating such information directly and seamlessly in the electronic health record (EHR), where clinicians spend most of their time, can put relevant and timely information at their fingertips, and possibly make care more efficient and effective. This project will generate foundational evidence for how this type of integration impacts healthcare processes and outcomes.
PROJECT_TITLE: Improving healthcare processes and outcomes by directly integrating health information exchange data in the clinical workflow

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The nation?s opioid epidemic has remained a public health emergency since 2017, marked by high rates of opioid use and abuse among adults and a correlated rising incidence of Neonatal Opioid Withdrawal Syndrome (NOWS) in infants exposed to opioids in utero. There are no FDA-approved pharmacotherapies for the treatment of NOWS to manage the distressing symptoms from the condition which results in reliance on off-label use of narcotic medications not formulated for use in neonates, containing ingredients which are not recommended in infants due to safety concerns and lacking well-studied dosing recommendations that adequately characterize the benefits and risks of treatment, particularly their effects on the developing brain. The proposed research program will complete manufacturing and clinical trial activities necessary to evaluate and support approval of a pediatric-appropriate formulation of lofexidine, a non-opioid medication approved for mitigation of opioid withdrawal symptoms in adults, as a first line-therapy in NOWS patients through 2 clinical trials to i) identify an optimal dosing regimen of lofexidine for treatment of NOWS and ii) evaluate the risks and benefits of its use in improving withdrawal symptoms, limiting infant exposure to other off-label narcotic medications and shortening the infant?s overall stay in the hospital.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE/PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal directly addresses the public health burden of the rising rates of significant falls in older adults which are the leading cause of traumatic morbidity and mortality in the elderly. Specifically, the use of an automated screening tool harnesses existing data resources and information systems to use the ED to better coordinate care between the ED and existing preventive resources in the health system. Beyond improving care for older adults with falls, this study will demonstrate the promise of using information technology to deliver public health interventions in the ED setting without diverting provider resources from the core ED mission of providing quality acute care.
PROJECT_TITLE: Preventing Future Falls in Older Adult ED Patients: Evaluating the Implementation and Effectiveness of a Novel Automated Screening and Referral Intervention

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The proposed research will significantly advance our understanding of how human gut bacteria affect the development and progression of autoimmune and inflammatory diseases, in particular, inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Specifically, this work will define new molecular pathways that causally connect the bacterial metabolism of bile acids (cholesterol-derived compounds that are produced by the host and metabolized by the resident microbiota) and the differentiation and function of T cells (immune cells that play critical roles in host immune homeostasis and disease). This research will lay the groundwork for the development of new therapies for autoimmune and inflammatory diseases that target the microbiota.

PHR: Overall Project Narrative The strategic goal of the Precision Aging Network is to develop the essential scientific knowledge and appropriate technologies to predict individual brain health risks and to discover personalized solutions to maximize cognitive healthspan. Because of the enormous heterogeneity in brain and cognitive functions among older individuals, the urgent challenge for science, medicine and healthcare providers is to discover interventions that are individually effective in delaying or preventing the onset of symptoms that arise from age- related cognitive impairment or brain disorders such as Alzheimer?s disease (AD) and AD-related dementias. To achieve this we will determine how specific categories of risk relate to brain aging and cognitive outcomes.

PHR: Narrative Optic neuritis is an inflammatory, autoimmune condition that results in demyelination of the optic nerve. It is often one of the first signs of multiple sclerosis. The animal model used in the proposed studies is unique in that it allows differentiation of the causative effects of interleukin-2 from standby effects in the context of an environmental factor (a virus). Confirmation of the preliminary data that pinpoint requirements for specific types of receptors on specialized subsets of immune cells will suggest a framework for more focused, and thus more effective, strategies for targeted immune therapy.

PHR: Clinicians widely use medical x-ray imaging for injury and disease detection within the body. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT Black female adolescents are disproportionately affected by teen dating violence (TDV) victimization. Race- and gender-based discrimination, a common occurrence in Black female adolescents? lives, may play a role in TDV victimization. The proposed study examines interpersonal, structural, and internalized race- and gender- based discrimination experienced by 15-17 year old Black female adolescents and how these experiences re- late to their perceptions of and experiences with TDV victimization.
PROJECT_TITLE: The Role of Race and Gender Based Discrimination in Black Female Youth?s Perceptions of and Experiences with Teen Dating Violence

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Musculoskeletal disorders (MSDs) are among the most frequent and costly of all nonfatal workplace injuries and illnesses, across virtually all US industry sectors. Responding to a clear need to develop improved methods of estimating exposure to occupational risk factors for MSDs, this research will validate a new computer vision-based method of measuring worker postures and movements using only standard video as input. The results will provide flexible platform upon which to build practical applications to support the efforts of occupational safety and health professionals in protecting the health of our nation's workforce.
PROJECT_TITLE: Using computer vision and deep learning to measure worker kinematics

IC_NAME: National Center for Complementary & Integrative Health
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the proposed project is to conduct a randomized clinical efficacy trial (RCT) of a novel guided imagery tobacco cessation intervention delivered by phone. The results of our feasibility trial conducted in Arizona demonstrated feasibility and potential impact but was not powered to detect efficacy. Therefore, a fully powered RCT is warranted and will be conducted in collaboration with partners in Arizona, New York, and West Virginia.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid use disorder (OUD) affects more than 2 million Americans, resulting in more than 80,000 overdose deaths last year and an estimated annual societal cost of $1 trillion. Despite these significant harms, fewer than 35% of affected individuals receive treatment. The OASIS platform will engage both patients and their primary care clinicians with a set of innovative educational resources specifically designed to counter the insidious effects of stigma and to empower individuals on both sides of the clinical encounter to initiate evidence-based treatment. We believe OASIS has the potential to improve outcomes for patients with an OUD and produce significant cost savings across the healthcare system.

PHR: Project Narrative: Immunotherapy drugs are most effective when used in combination but can be very toxic. Here we propose a new approach to confine immunotherapy drugs to tumors, by binding the drugs to the most common vaccine adjuvant, alum. Alum-bound therapeutics can be injected intratumorally and stimulate an immune response that attacks cancer throughout the body, providing a promising strategy to create safer and more effective immunotherapies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vascular leaks are early events in Alzheimer?s disease (AD) and related vascular dementias, causing extravasation of the abundant blood protein fibrinogen (FGN) into the brain where it is converted to fibrin (FN), forming FN clots. On FN a cryptic epitope (Fib?377-395, aka FN P2) is exposed which binds and activates the CD11b/CD18 receptor on macrophages and microglia driving chronic neuroinflammation, contributing to neuronal loss and cognitive decline. Therini Bio is developing a novel therapeutic antibody that blocks the neuroinflammation mediated by FN P2, and in this proposal, the anti-FN P2 therapy will be tested in standard preclinical safety models in preparation for and support of AD clinical trials.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deaths linked to the synthetic opioids fentanyl and its derivatives increased over 10-fold between 2013 and 2020, and are now double those caused by heroin. The proposed work addresses the urgent need for a safe rapidly acting reversal agent for synthetic opioids with a new mechanism of action that improves treatment compared to the standard of care, naloxone. Such an agent would save lives and improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Despite effective treatments, over 50% of patients with Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) will relapse, thus making relapse a crucial barrier to long-term recovery. Following detoxification, the consequences of chronic alcohol use in the brain have been shown to persist into a period known as prolonged withdrawal. This project aims to better understand the neurocircuitry alterations in prolonged withdrawal by focusing on two brain regions implicated in this stage of sobriety: the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (BNST) and the insula.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impaired driving is a critical public health and safety issue among young drivers, and an issue for which prevention materials are needed. The proposed Phase II project will complete development of Plan My Ride, a web-based, immersive, skill-building, online training and virtual reality video experience for high school and college age drivers that uses a theory-driven approach to target attitudes, beliefs, and skills to prevent impaired driving. This project will result in the development of an effective, evidence-based, scalable impaired driving prevention program that teaches behavioral skills.
PI_NAMEs: SCHMIDT, ALLISON MARIE; STELTER, REBECCA LYNN (contact);
PROJECT_TITLE: Plan My Ride: A brief, immersive, skill-building impaired driving prevention program for young adult drivers

PHR: The purpose of this award is to support the research, training and service activities of Dr. Courtney Van Houtven, who is an experienced Department of Veterans Affairs investigator. Dr. Van Houtven leads research studies that test care models to improve the function and independence of older adults with functional limitations and the function of their informal caregivers. The overarching goal of her research agenda is to enable at-risk Veterans to remain at home as safely as possible and for as long as possible. This research is important because there are 9.8 million Veterans over age 65 and 5.5 million Veterans receive informal care in order to remain at home. Dr. Van Houtven?s research will continue to study how we can best provide care for Veterans at risk of permanent nursing home entry, including the best means of supporting their caregivers.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research program proposes to develop a novel disease-modifying compound for the treatment of Alzheimer?s disease. We have identified, BMS-984923, a highly potent, orally bioavailable silent allosteric modulator of the metabotropic glutamate receptor subtype 5 with promising preclinical efficacy and safety data indicating the potential to reverse synaptic loss and restore cognition in humans with Alzheimer?s disease. We plan to assess the safety and tolerability of BMS-984923 for the treatment of early Alzheimer?s disease and investigate the use of synaptic density, measured with positron emission tomography, as an early marker of therapeutic response to treatments that target synapse restoration.

PHR: NARRATIVE Although almost half of the over 1.5 million Medicare beneficiaries who enroll in hospice each year have Alzheimer?s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD), hospice is poorly suited to the needs of people with dementia. Hospice care for people with dementia is both more expensive and lower quality than for other populations, such as those with cancer. The proposed study will evaluate how recent changes in the way Medicare pays for hospice impacts the quality and costs of care for hospice enrollees with dementia compared to those with cancer, which will help determine how to provide the highest-value hospice care for the hundreds of thousands of people with dementia enrolled in hospice every year.

PHR: Project Narrative This project will investigate how RNA binding proteins boost protein expression in photoreceptor cells to enable vision, an unexplored aspect of the photoreceptor cell biology. Our work will allow us to better understand how photoreceptors function and how blinding disease develops. We expect that the results of this study will open new ways to treat blinding diseases.

ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Poverty has a devastating effect on Veterans? health and well-being. Through the Shallow Subsidy program, Veterans and their families living in 15 high-cost communities throughout the country who are experiencing housing instability can receive long-term rental assistance and job training with the long-term financial self- sufficiency. The impact of the Shallow Subsidy program on Veteran housing, healthcare cost, health, income, and employment outcomes as well as Veteran experience with this new program is not known. Through this project, we will generate important information about the Shallow Subsidy program. We will use nationwide data to describe the geographic variation in Shallow Subsidy services and expenditures throughout the different, eligible communities. We will measure the impact of Shallow Subsidy on Veteran outcomes as well as the cost-effectiveness of the program relative to usual care. Finally, we will interview Shallow Subsidy participants to better understand barriers and facilitators of the program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Project Narrative Handgun carrying is widely recognized as a key risk factor for firearm-related injury and violence among youth living in urban areas. Our knowledge of the culture, scope, and developmental patterns of handgun carrying, as well as its determinants and consequences, among youth living in rural communities is strikingly limited. The goal of this project is to fill this knowledge gap and provide actionable evidence for informing strategies that can prevent firearm-related injury and promote safety among adolescents in rural communities.
PROJECT_TITLE: Culture, Longitudinal Patterns, and Safety Promotion of Handgun Carrying Among Rural Adolescents: Implications for Injury Prevention

PHR: The proposed CDA-2 will provide Dr. Colvonen with the training, expertise and data to advance research aimed at improving insomnia, PTSD, and mental health treatment among Veterans. This project is the first to examine whether integrating insomnia and PTSD treatment will enhance sleep, PTSD, and quality of life outcomes. Such benefits would further the VA's commitment to improving the mental health, recovery, and community reintegration of Veterans detailed in the 2014-2020 VHA Strategic Plan. Findings from the proposed study offer a unique opportunity to determine the malleability of mechanisms (e.g., Total sleep time, Sleep efficiency) that can improve recovery outcomes among this vulnerable population and to inform future treatment development and research. Improved PTSD, insomnia, and quality of life outcomes can decrease risk of chronic impairment and ultimately help affected Veterans live richer, more productive lives.

PHR: We will leverage an existing data set of diverse, well phenotyped, Latinos from the Hispanic Community Health Study/Study of Latinos, to study the association of circulating blood metabolites with cognitive decline. We will develop and study prediction models based of blood metabolites, and assess the role of genetics and genetic ancestry on both blood metabolites and their association with cognitive decline. Our results will form a basis for a larger study of genetic and omics mechanisms underlying Alzheimer?s disease in diverse US Latinos.

PHR: NARRATIVE The growing availability of endophenotypic data in cohort studies of Alzheimer?s disease (AD) provides an exciting opportunity to further characterize the genetic architecture of this devastating disease. However, there is a pressing need to develop and apply advanced harmonization approaches to align AD-related endophenotypes across cohorts. The goal of this coordinated national initiative ? the AD Sequencing Project Phenotype Harmonization Consortium, or ?ADSP-PHC? - is to provide a centralized database of robust endophenotypes for large-scale genomic analyses that will accelerate the identification of novel targets for therapeutic intervention in AD.

PHR: Project Narrative Black young adults use marijuana more frequently and are more likely to have a cannabis use disorder than White young adults, yet very few studies have examined why these differences exist. The proposed project tests a cascading model that examines stress and discrimination exposure, emotional reactivity, and marijuana cognitions, inside the laboratory and in the natural environment, as contributors to health disparities in marijuana use and problems. Results of the project can help inform intervention efforts by identifying modifiable and proximal treatment targets for Black young adults and will ultimately lead to a reduction in the pronounced health disparities in marijuana use and cannabis use disorder.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dr. Ledoux?s research portfolio addresses three broad clinical foot problems that are important to Americans in general and veterans in particular: 1) The pathophysiology and treatment of ankle/midfoot arthritis. 2) The diagnosis, quantification, and treatment of severe foot deformities. 3) The poor understanding of the effect of diabetes on the plantar soft tissue and the subsequent increased risk of diabetic neuropathic ulceration. Veterans have a significantly higher prevalence of foot problems, including arthritis and flatfoot, than non-veterans. Similarly, diabetes affects roughly 10% of the general population, but 25% of veterans. The average age of the veteran population (58 years old) is much older than the general population (38 years old) and likely contributes to the higher prevalence of these foot pathologies. The sum of Dr. Ledoux?s research aims to explore conservative and surgical treatment options for these three important clinical maladies. He, and his research team, have developed state-of-the-art techniques for addressing these issues.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fractures in elderly people are an important public health issue, especially as incidence increases with age, and the population of elderly people is growing. Treatments to accelerate geriatric bone healing are missing, exposing the elderly to a high risk of degenerative decline. Fibroplate is developing a new biological treatment that could be easily administered to accelerate fracture healing in older adults and promote fast recovery.

PHR: Project Narrative We propose that development of myeloid malignancies including clonal hematopoiesis, MDS and AML associated with IDH1/2 mutations involves epigenetic alterations in the bone marrow stroma that provide necessary support for mutated clonal hematopoietic stem cells to evolve. We will determine DNA methylation changes in the bone marrow stroma of IDH1/2-mutant MDS patients; examine the role of epigenetically modified stromal cells in development of IDH1/2-mutant MDS and determine whether epigenetic modifications in the aging bone marrow stroma transform engineered clonal IDH1/2 mutations in healthy HSCs to MDS- initiating events. These studies may identify stroma-derived signals to be targeted therapeutically in combination with current IDH1/2 inhibitors to improve treatment of IDH1/2 mutant MDS patients or, in the future, to prevent MDS development.

PHR: Project Narrative Despite the deleterious effects of aging on physical and cognitive health, many people?s emotional lives become more positive with age. A subset of people, however, experience negative emotional outcomes including depression and loneliness that have significant consequences for physical health and increase risk of morbidity and early mortality. The goal of this project is to investigate one possible mechanism that might subseve these effects ? the possibility that robust social environments and the quality of social relationships promotes healthy aging ? in a robust animal for human social, cognitive, affective, and neurobehavioral aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: STATEMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The proposed research is relevant to public health because, as our population ages, the financial and societal burden of neurodegenerative diseases will greatly expand over the coming decades. This proposal seeks to generate knowledge and resources around a broad-based understanding of tau metabolism. The proposed research is relevant to the NIH's mission of extending healthy life and reducing the burdens of illnesses like neurodegeneration, since its findings will enhance related efforts to target tau clearance and develop therapies for neurodegenerative diseases such as FTD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: This study evaluates the Help Wanted Prevention Intervention, a primary prevention program for help-seeking individuals who self-identify as having sexual interest in children. This study proceeds in three phases including beta-testing of study procedures (10 participants), a randomized control trial (300 participants), and revision of the intervention with review and feedback (10 participations). Ultimately, this study will determine whether Help Wanted is efficacious in reducing child sexual abuse perpetration behaviors and improving the psychosocial well-being of help-seekers.
PROJECT_TITLE: Help Wanted: Evaluating a Prevention Intervention for People with Sexual Interest in Children

PHR: Greater exposure to stressful situations, coupled with limited access to the financial and social resources needed to manage stress in healthy ways are believed to contribute to persistent racial/ethnic disparities in Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD). Our study combines personalized and objective indicators of the body's response to stressful experiences with multi-modal neuroimaging and longitudinal cognitive assessments in a unique multi-ethnic cohort. Our findings will inform stress management interventions and precision medicine initiatives designed to prevent ADRD and/or slow its progression

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE mTOR is a key regulator of stem cell function and lifespan. Our studies demonstrate that mTOR-dependent regulation of hematopoietic stem cell aging is complex, with low levels of mTOR signaling in HSCs required to limit their aging, while high levels of mTOR activity in bone marrow endothelial cells required to suppress HSC aging. Given the differences in cell-intrinsic and -extrinsic mTOR-dependent mechanisms that regulate HSC aging, as well as recent evidence that the hematopoietic system directly regulates lifespan, we will determine the molecular and cellular basis of mTOR-dependent effects on HSC aging and organismal health- and lifespan.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dendrites and axons serve critical roles in neuronal networks, encoding and integrating information to drive appropriate behaviors; however, no current method exists to record their dynamics in large cellular populations during free behavior. Miniature multiphoton microscopes have been presented in the literature which are capable of resolving dendrites and axons, but many practical limitations in field of view, working distance, and axial fo- cusing have limited their utility to neuroscience investigations. In this proposal, I will design, build, and test a transformative multiphoton miniature microscope capable of resolving calcium dynamics from hundreds of cells and their processes simultaneously during free behavior and social interaction.

ORG_NAME: VA WESTERN NEW YORK HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) is among the most common injuries sustained by Veterans of Operations Enduring and Iraqi Freedom. It is also highly co-morbid with mental health conditions, such as post-traumatic stress disorder and depression. While mTBI alone is not typically thought to cause lasting deficits in personal functioning or cognitive abilities, Veterans with a history of mTBI nonetheless report chronic psychological distress, as well as subjective difficulties with attention, concentration, poor frustration tolerance, and decision- making. Although current clinical practice guidelines for mTBI emphasize primary care-based symptom management, there are presently no evidence-based interventions to treat mental health symptoms in this setting. This research proposal therefore seeks to adapt and pilot test a brief, primary care-based intervention to reduce psychological distress in Veterans with mTBI by augmenting problem-solving skills, and helping them to develop specific cognitive and behavioral skills to improve upon their self-reported cognitive inefficiencies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current standard procedures for testing hearing loss are limited in that they cannot identify individuals who exert extra effort ? a phenomenon that negatively impacts quality of life, social communication and mental health. The goal of the proposed research is to refine new techniques in physiological and behavioral assessment of speech perception and listening effort to validate a new approach to identifying individuals who use an extra moment to process speech in an effortful way. The results could lead to diagnostic procedures that better reflect real-world difficulties experienced by those with hearing loss.

ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Obesity affects more veterans than the general population and even more so among veterans using VA health care services. Moreover, the number of obese older veterans has markedly increased because of both the increase in the aging of the veteran population and the percentage of older veterans who are obese. In older veterans, obesity aggravates the age-related decline in physical function resulting in frailty that leads to loss of independence in activities of daily living. However, lifestyle therapy resulting in weight loss in obese older adults remains controversial because of concerns about harmful effects of weight loss on muscle and bone mass in this population. Metformin, a drug widely used to treat diabetes, could slow the aging process and improve health span, the part of a person?s life during which they are in good health. It is possible that the addition of metformin to lifestyle therapy will reverse frailty and preserve muscle and bone mass in obese older veterans, thereby prevent their loss of independence and decrease need for admission to a VA nursing home care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREV AND HEALTH PROMO
PHR: Project Narrative We aim to improve quality of life and well-being among breast and prostate cancer survivors by simultaneously targeting anti-racism training in clinical settings and using universal social determinants of health screening and referral to address such needs. Community health workers utilizing health information exchange in DC will be central to improving community-clinical linkages and decreasing social isolation among cancer survivors. Our long-term goal is to decrease cancer outcome disparities in the Washington DC region.
PROJECT_TITLE: Scaling Social Determinants of Health Screening, Social Support and Anti-Racism Training to Reduce Inequities in Minority Cancer Survivor Health and Wellbeing in Washington, DC

PHR: NARRATIVE (ADMINISTRATIVE CORE) The Washington State University (WSU) and the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine (LSTM) propose to use their collective administrative and technical experience in Kenya and excellent relationships with the Kenya Medical Research Institute (KEMRI) to support KEMRI in the management of the KEMRI/CGHR Research Platform (KRP), cost-effectively and sustainably. The platform includes the population-based health and demographic surveillance systems, laboratories, clinical research centers, offices, and shared services. Following extensive discussions with KEMRI that led to this joint application, we agreed to implement a highly cost-effective management plan that develops strong organizational capacities within KEMRI, which is required to assume successful and sustainable management of the KRP infrastructure in support of their public health research in Kenya. In addition, we demonstrate clear technical expertise to lead the Research Core areas identified in the RFA, using the same approach of twinning experienced WSU and LSTM scientists with KEMRI and CDC counterparts to design, implement, and publish finding from the studies, an approach designed to train and mentor KEMRI scientists in applying and managing research funding.
PROJECT_TITLE: GH21-003, Advancing Public Health Research in Kenya

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Improving the rate of completion of Activities of Daily Living (ADL) has a known positive impact on the quality of life, health, and healthcare costs yet, consistently completing ADLs, and without stress, for people living with dementia (PLWD) and their carers remains a challenge. This proposal seeks to establish and test a new modality for accomplishing ADLs with dignity and greater ease by leveraging the engagement and communication properties of a personalized 3D virtual world, DevaWorld, which memory care residents helped to design. We will expand the DevaWorld platform with scenes that mimic real-world ADLs, which participants will interact with, including assisting virtual world personas with tasks, while collecting data to assess tolerability, feasibility, and shifts in capacity for both members of the care dyad.
